Text

ï»¿Miss Brown by [Vernon Lee]89-vernon lee 1884 [AUTHOR OF EUPHORION , BELCARO]236-author of euphorion , belcaro , ETC .

IN THREE VOLUMES VOL . I. TO [HENRY JAMES]90-henry james , [I]0-i DEDICATE , FOR GOOD LUCK , [MY]0-i FIRST ATTEMPT AT A NOVEL .

BOOK I.

[MISS BROWN]91-anne .

CHAPTER I.

IT was melancholy to admit that [Italy]1-italy also had ceased to interest [him]237-him , thought [Hamlin]93-hamlin , as [he]93-hamlin smoked [his]93-hamlin cigarette on [the hillside above [the Villa Arnolfini]2-the villa arnolfini]238-the hillside above the villa arnolfini ; melancholy , although , in truth , [he]93-hamlin had suspected as much throughout the journey , and , indeed , before starting . Pale , milky morning sky , deepening into luminous blue opposite the fast?rising sun ; [misty blue?green valley bounded by unsubstantial Apennine peaks and [Carrara crags]240-carrara crags]239-misty blue?green valley bounded by unsubstantial apennine peaks and carrara crags ; yellow shimmer of vines and of maize , green sparkle of pine and fir branches , glitter of vermilion sand crumbling under [his]93-hamlin feet among the sear grass

and the brown cistus tufts , all these things seemed to have lost for [him]93-hamlin their emotional colour , their imaginative luminousness . [He]93-hamlin tried to realise the time when all these things had given [him]93-hamlin a thrill , had gone to [his]93-hamlin head , nay , when the mere sense of being in [Italy]1-italy had done so ; but now the very words " thrill "[93-hamlin] and " intoxication "[93-hamlin] seemed false , disgusting , and vulgar . Formerly , at least , such things had soaked into [him]93-hamlin , dyed [his]93-hamlin mind with colour , saturated it with light ; instead of remaining , as now , so separate from [him]93-hamlin , so terribly external , that to perceive them required almost an effort . [He]93-hamlin and [the world]241-the world had been becoming paler in the last three years ; it was melancholy , but that seemed quite natural and in keeping ; and besides , a washed?out world , [a man with worn?out feelings , have quite as much psychologic interest for [a poet as the reverse]243-a poet as the reverse]242-a man with worn?out feelings , have quite as much psychologic interest for a poet as the reverse .

[Walter Hamlin]93-hamlin had never been [your]244-your splash?of?scarlet and dash?of?orange?and?skyblue , lust?and?terror kind of lyrist ; but [he]93-hamlin had begun [his]93-hamlin poetical career with a quiet concentra ?

tion of colour , physical and moral , which had made [his]93-hamlin earliest verses affect one like so many old church windows , deep flecks of jewel lustre set in quaint stiff little frames , with a great deal of lead between , and supreme indifference to anatomy and perspective . And as [a painter]245-a painter perhaps just because , despite [his]93-hamlin own contrary opinion [he]93-hamlin certainly had less original genius as [painter]246-painter than as [poet]247-poet [he]93-hamlin had continued in this habit of gemlike harmonies of colour ; but in [his]93-hamlin poetry , and in [his]93-hamlin reality as [a man]248-a man , it struck [him]93-hamlin that [he]93-hamlin had little by little got paler and paler , colours turning gradually to tints , and tints to shadows ; pleasure , pain , hope , despair , all reduced gradually to a delicate penumbra , a diaphanous intellectual pallor , of which this utter listlessness , this indifference even to having grown indifferent , was , as it were , the faint key?note . [The world]241-the world was a pale and prismatic mist , full of vague , formless ghosts , in which it was possible to see only as far as to?day ; and , indeed , why wish to see that paler to?day called

to?morrow ? Perhaps there was a little depression added to [Hamlin]93-hamlin s usual listlessness . It had given [him]93-hamlin a kind of little shock to see [Melton Perry]94-perry again , after those twelve or thirteen years ; bringing back to [him]93-hamlin the time when [he]93-hamlin had been the most brilliant and eccentric of [that little knot of ? sthetic undergraduates , at whose strange doings as [Greek gods]251-greek gods , and [ProvenÏal poets]252-provenÏal poets , and [Norse heroes]253-norse heroes , [Oxford]95-oxford had murmured in those philistine days , and which had welcomed [young Hamlin]93-hamlin , with [his]93-hamlin girlish beauty and pre?Raphaelite verses , as a sort of mixture of [Apollo]96-apollo and [Eros]97-eros , sitting at the head of the supper?table dressed in green silk , with rose garlands on [his]93-hamlin head]250-that little knot of ? sthetic undergraduates , at whose strange doings as greek gods , and provenÏal poets , and norse heroes , oxford had murmured in those philistine days , and which had welcomed young hamlin , with his girlish beauty and pre?raphaelite verses , as a sort of mixture of apollo and eros , sitting at the head of the supper?table dressed in green silk , with rose garlands on his head , while [Perry]94-perry led a chorus of praise , dressed in indigo velveteen , with peacocks feathers in [his]93-hamlin button?hole , and silver?gilt grasshoppers in [his]93-hamlin hair . [Poor old Perry]94-perry ! Absurd days those were , thought [Hamlin]93-hamlin , as [he]93-hamlin walked slowly towards [the house]254-the house , through the grass and hemlock bending with dew , pushing aside the fig branches and vine trails along the narrow path between [the

terraced olives]255-the terraced olives ; absurd days those , and at which [he]93-hamlin could now , having grown grave and listless , only faintly smile . Still the sight of [Perry]94-perry had brought back to [him]93-hamlin that recurring sense that [all those absurd lads of long?gone days]256-all those absurd lads of long?gone days , turned [humdrum dons , and parsons]257-humdrum dons , and parsons , and [squires]258-squires for the most part , had had a something , a spontaneity , an aristocratic fibre , a sort of free?bornness , which [he]93-hamlin missed among the clique?and?shop shoddy ? stheticism with which [he]93-hamlin now associated , and which sang [his]93-hamlin praises as [those boys]259-those boys had sung them so many years before . Professional poetry ! professional art ! faugh ! thought [Hamlin]93-hamlin ; it was that feeling which had been making [London]3-london odious to [him]93-hamlin of late , and sent [him]93-hamlin abroad , [he]93-hamlin knew not whither . [He]93-hamlin was [a poet]260-a poet [himself]93-hamlin , and [a painter]245-a painter also , to be sure ; but somehow [he]93-hamlin liked to feel and yet it oppressed [him]93-hamlin that [he]93-hamlin was not of the same stock as [[his]93-hamlin fellow?workers]262-his fellow?workers that [he]93-hamlin had [his]93-hamlin coats made by [less romantic tailors]263-less romantic tailors , and cut [his]93-hamlin hair and beard in less pictorial style . The sense of [his]93-hamlin difference from all those pen ?

and?pencil?driving [men of genius]264-men of genius , those reviewer?poets and clerk?poets , [those once?a?week?studio?receiving painters]265-those once?a?week?studio?receiving painters ; the sense of the dust and smoke , as it were , of [the ? sthetic factory]266-the ? sthetic factory , had been choking [him]93-hamlin of late : [he]93-hamlin would rather go and associate only with well?dressed numskulls , go and flirt with [empty?headed Faubourg St Germain ladies]267-empty?headed faubourg st germain ladies , or [emptier?headed Monte Carlo ladies]268-emptier?headed monte carlo ladies [he]93-hamlin would not touch pen or brush for years . It had been silly to accept [Perry]94-perry s invitation to spend September at [the Villa Arnolfini]2-the villa arnolfini ; [he]93-hamlin had accepted , thinking of [Perry]94-perry as [he]93-hamlin had been , a wild , roistering , half?French creature , brought up at [Louis?le?Grand]4-louis?le?grand , and telling wicked French stories . Good heavens ! what a change ! When [the wretched , thin , wasted , depressed?looking creature , fit for a medieval picture of mansuetude]269-the wretched , thin , wasted , depressed?looking creature , fit for a medieval picture of mansuetude , had greeted [him]93-hamlin by night at [the nearest station]270-the nearest station , and had driven [him]93-hamlin in [the gig]271-the gig , [he]93-hamlin had been quite unable to realise that this was indeed [Melton Perry]94-perry . But [he]93-hamlin had understood all , all , when , in [the bleak drawing?room]272-the bleak drawing?room , in the glare of an ill ?

trimmed lamp , [that lank , limp , lantern?jawed leering creature with a Sapphic profile]273-that lank , limp , lantern?jawed leering creature with a sapphic profile had come forward and seized [him]93-hamlin by both hands , and kissed [them]274-them , crying

" [Dear Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin , [I]269-the wretched , thin , wasted , depressed?looking creature , fit for a medieval picture of mansuetude must kiss the hands that have opened the paradise of body and soul to [so many of [us]1712-us]1711-so many of us . "[269-the wretched , thin , wasted , depressed?looking creature , fit for a medieval picture of mansuetude] [She]269-the wretched , thin , wasted , depressed?looking creature , fit for a medieval picture of mansuetude , and [her]269-the wretched , thin , wasted , depressed?looking creature , fit for a medieval picture of mansuetude speech , and the damp dab on [his]93-hamlin hands , had passed before [him]93-hamlin like a nightmare ; [he]93-hamlin felt that [he]93-hamlin would never be able to disassociate [Mrs Melton Perry]94-perry from that horrible smell of ill?trimmed , flickering oil?lamp . It seemed to [him]93-hamlin dreadful a sort of hideous , harpy?like proceeding that [[his]93-hamlin old friend]275-his old friend should have thus been metamorphosed . " [You]93-hamlin see , "[94-perry] [Perry]94-perry had said , " [I]94-perry must paint things well not the sort of things [I]94-perry exactly admire , because , [you]93-hamlin see , there s [Mrs Perry]94-perry and [the children]1713-the children [five girls]1714-five girls , and [last year s baby]1715-last year s baby . "[94-perry]

[Perry]94-perry s depressed voice had remained in [Hamlin]93-hamlin s ears . This was the end of [a bright , original fellow married for love]276-a bright , original fellow married for love , too ! And

[six children]277-six children ! [Hamlin]93-hamlin had already made up [his]93-hamlin mind that [he]93-hamlin could not possibly hold out long at [the Villa Arnolfini]2-the villa arnolfini . That [Mrs Perry]94-perry , with [her]94-perry leering Sapphic profile , [her]94-perry almost amorous admiration , the limp gown , [the five girls]278-the five girls , and [last year s baby]1715-last year s baby , the all?pervading smell of oil?lamp , were too much for [him]93-hamlin . In three days , [he]93-hamlin calculated , [he]93-hamlin might decently , on some pretext , slip off to [Florence]5-florence . And then why , from [Florence]5-florence [he]93-hamlin might go to [America]6-america . [He]93-hamlin thought all [those big hotels]280-those big hotels , with [the fifteen hundred inmates and thirteen brass bands]281-the fifteen hundred inmates and thirteen brass bands , all that tremendous strain , telegraph?telephone vulgarity , might be refreshing .

[Hamlin]93-hamlin had got to [the bottom of [the hill]283-the hill]282-the bottom of the hill , and in front of [him]93-hamlin , nestled among the olives and the vines , rose [the Villa Arnolfini]284-the villa arnolfini , a time ? and [weather?stained Tuscan country?house]285-weather?stained tuscan country?house , with [its]285-weather?stained tuscan country?house rose?hedges gone wild among the beans and artichokes , its grotesque ivy?draped terra?cotta statues , [its]285-weather?stained tuscan country?house belvedere towers , from whose crannied sides and yellow lichened tiles

the pigeons swept down on to the lawn of overgrown grass , thick with dew in the blue morning shadow . [It]285-weather?stained tuscan country?house had a sort of half?romantic , half?idyllic charm , which [Hamlin]93-hamlin could not help recognising : [it]285-weather?stained tuscan country?house certainly was better than [an American hotel]286-an american hotel , with [ten lifts]287-ten lifts , [thirteen brass bands]288-thirteen brass bands , and [fifteen hundred inmates]289-fifteen hundred inmates . But , like everything else , it was a snare ; for behind those sleepy?looking green shutters were the pink and blue chromo?lithograph [pot?boilers of [Melton Perry]94-perry]290-pot?boilers of melton perry , were [the five girls]278-the five girls and [the last year s baby]292-the last year s baby , nay , were the Sapphic leer and limp dresses of [Mrs Melton Perry]94-perry [herself]94-perry .

Making these reflections , [Hamlin]93-hamlin pushed open [the green and blistered house?door]293-the green and blistered house?door and entered [the wide hall]294-the wide hall , with rickety eighteenth?century chairs and tables marshalled round the walls . There was one good thing about [[his]93-hamlin hosts]295-his hosts , [he]93-hamlin thought , and that was , that [they]295-his hosts had no common breakfast , but invited [[their]295-his hosts guests]296-their guests to do whatsoever [they]295-his hosts pleased in the early morning . [The hall]297-the hall was very silent , and [Ham]98-ham ?

lin wondered how [he]98-ham should get any breakfast . It struck [him]98-ham that [he]98-ham had better go and ring the bell in [[his]98-ham bedroom]298-his bedroom . But on going [upstairs]299-upstairs [he]98-ham found there was no sign of a bell either in [it]298-his bedroom or in [the vast scantily furnished drawing?room]300-the vast scantily furnished drawing?room , where a thick layer of dust reposed on tables and mirrors , and the smell of last night s oil?lamp still lingered . [He]98-ham saw the open door of [[Perry]94-perry s studio]301-perry s studio ; [it]301-perry s studio was empty , and so was [the adjoining dressing?room]302-the adjoining dressing?room , where boots and canvases littered the floor . But on the mirror was a paper , on which was written in the largest characters : " [I]94-perry am gone to sketch at [the Lake of [Massaciuccoli]7-massaciuccoli]1716-the lake of massaciuccoli ; shan t be back till lunch ; please look after [Hamlin]93-hamlin . "[94-perry]

" Confound it ! "[93-hamlin] thought [Hamlin]93-hamlin , " am [I]93-hamlin to be left in t?te???t?te with [Mrs Perry]94-perry all the morning ? "[93-hamlin] But since [Melton Perry]94-perry thought nothing of leaving [[his]98-ham guest]303-his guest alone all the morning , [he]98-ham too [the guest]304-the guest might surely be permitted to slip away after breakfast from the effusive ? stheticism of [[his]98-ham hostess]305-his hostess .

Hav ?

ing

Having

found no sign of life on [the first floor]306-the first floor , [Hamlin]93-hamlin went down?stairs once more , and proceeded to ramble about in search of breakfast , or , at least , of [some servant]307-some servant . The ground?floor seemed to consist entirely of [servants rooms]308-servants rooms , [offices]309-offices , and strange garners , where sacks of potatoes , garden?tools , silkworm?mats , and various kinds of pods were gathered together . They were all empty ; and empty likewise was [the kitchen]310-the kitchen , [its]310-the kitchen brass saucepans and huge spits left invitingly for [any one who might care to step through the open garden?door]311-any one who might care to step through the open garden?door . But next to [the kitchen]310-the kitchen was a sort of nursery , at least so [he]93-hamlin judged from [the children]1713-the children s chairs and battered dolls lying about and here a table was spread with cups and saucers and jugs , and a cut loaf and a plate of figs . " This looks more like it , "[93-hamlin] thought [Hamlin]93-hamlin , wondering what had become of the inmates of this mysterious abode of sleep . Suddenly [he]93-hamlin heard [children]314-children talking in [a room at the end of [the passage]316-the passage]315-a room at the end of the passage , and a sort of subdued , deep , melancholy chant , like some church song . [He]93-hamlin went

to the door whence came the sounds , and knocked gently . The childish chattering did not stop , nor the fitful gusts of chant deep , nasal , but harmonious and weird , with curious , sudden , metallic falsetto notes , less like the voice of [a woman]317-a woman than of [a youth]318-a youth . [Hamlin]93-hamlin knocked again , and receiving no notice , boldly opened the door and stood on the threshold . [He]93-hamlin was struck by the sight which met [him]93-hamlin . [The room]319-the room was low and vaulted , with walls entirely frescoed with dark?blue skies sprinkled with birds , mountains like cheeses , [rivers]320-rivers , [box?like houses]321-box?like houses , [people]322-people fishing , and plentiful ducks and parrots on perches ; a faint green shimmer of leaves came through the open windows ; [three or four little yellow?headed children]323-three or four little yellow?headed children were scrambling on the floor , struggling violently over the funeral of a doll in a biscuit?tin . In the middle of [the room]319-the room was a large deal table , covered with singed flannel , on the corner of which stood a brasier with some flat?irons , and a heap of crumpled pink pinafores ; and behind this table , [her]317-a woman tall and

powerful figure , in a close?fitting white vest and white skirt , standing out against the dark?blue painted wall and the green shimmer from outside , was [a young woman]325-a young woman bending over a frock which [she]325-a young woman was ironing , [her]325-a young woman bare brown arms going up and down along the board ; [her]325-a young woman massive and yet girlish body bending with the movement , and singing that strange chant which [Hamlin]93-hamlin had heard from outside .

" [I]93-hamlin beg [your]1713-the children pardon , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin , in Italian , as [he]93-hamlin stood in the doorway . [The children]1713-the children looked round , tittered , and made remarks in shrill whispers ; [the girl]327-the girl stopped [her]327-the girl work , stood erect , putting [her]327-the girl iron on the brasier , and stared full at [Hamlin]93-hamlin with large wide?opened eyes of strange dark?greyish blue , beneath heavy masses of dark lustreless hair , crimped naturally like so much delicate black iron wire , on [her]327-the girl narrow white brow . " [I]93-hamlin beg [your]1713-the children pardon , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin again ; " but can [you]1713-the children tell [me]93-hamlin how [I]93-hamlin may get some breakfast ? "[93-hamlin]

[He]93-hamlin could not help smiling in proffering this innocent request , so serious and almost tragic was the face of [the girl]327-the girl . " It s [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin , "[1713-the children] tittered [the children]1713-the children , rolling under the table , and hanging to the table?cloth . [The young woman]330-the young woman eyed [Hamlin]93-hamlin for a second in no very gracious manner ; then answered , with a certain contemptuous listlessness in [her]330-the young woman slightly hollowed pale cheeks and beautifully curled but somewhat prominent lips " [I]330-the young woman don t know anything about [your]93-hamlin breakfast , [sir]1717-sir . "[330-the young woman] [She]330-the young woman spoke , to [his]93-hamlin surprise , in perfect English , with only the faintest guttural Italian accent . " [Mr Perry]99-mr perry went to sketch at [Massaciuccoli]7-massaciuccoli early this morning , and took [the boy]1718-the boy with [him]99-mr perry ; [Mrs Perry]94-perry may never be disturbed till nine ; and [the cook]1719-the cook is gone to [Lucca]8-lucca for provisions . "[330-the young woman] " That s very sad , "[93-hamlin] remarked [Hamlin]93-hamlin , laughing , and looking at this curious and picturesque being .

[The girl]327-the girl seemed annoyed at being discovered

in that guise , for [she]327-the girl pulled down [her]327-the girl white sleeves quickly .

" [I]330-the young woman suppose [the cook]1719-the cook has orders about [your]93-hamlin breakfast , "[330-the young woman] [she]330-the young woman said , in a tone which seemed to put an end to the conversation ; and [she]330-the young woman took up [her]330-the young woman iron once more . " [Mrs Perry]94-perry did not think [you]93-hamlin would want anything so early ; [the cook]1719-the cook will be back about nine . "[330-the young woman] But [Hamlin]93-hamlin would not be shaken off ; the fact was , [he]93-hamlin enjoyed watching this beautiful sullen creature much as [he]93-hamlin might have enjoyed watching a cat whom [he]93-hamlin had disturbed in its sleep . " Nine o clock ! "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said ; " that s a long time to wait . Couldn t [you]94-perry give [me]93-hamlin something to eat ? [I]93-hamlin saw a table spread in [the next room]1722-the next room . "[93-hamlin] [The girl]327-the girl put down [her]327-the girl iron with a sort of subdued irritation of manner . " It s [the children]1713-the children s breakfast , [sir]1717-sir , "[327-the girl] [she]327-the girl answered ; " [we]1713-the children have neither tea nor coffee . "[327-the girl] " [We]1713-the children have milk , "[333-the eldest of the little girls] said [the eldest of [the little girls]334-the little girls]333-the eldest of the little girls pertly , " and figs . "[333-the eldest of the little girls]

" Milk and figs ! "[93-hamlin] exclaimed [Hamlin]93-hamlin ; " why , that s a breakfast for the gods ! and won t [you]327-the girl , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin went on rather appealingly " won t [you]327-the girl share a little of it with [me]93-hamlin ? "[93-hamlin] " [You]93-hamlin are [[Mrs Perry]94-perry s guest]1725-mrs perry s guest , "[327-the girl] said [the girl]327-the girl more sullenly than ever , " and of course [you]93-hamlin are welcome to anything [you]93-hamlin choose . "[327-the girl] [Hamlin]93-hamlin felt rather taken aback . " Indeed ! "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said . " [I]93-hamlin don t wish to do anything against the habits of [the house]254-the house , or disagreeable to [you]93-hamlin . "[93-hamlin] " It is not against any rules , "[327-the girl] [she]327-the girl answered . " If [you]93-hamlin will excuse [me]327-the girl , [I]327-the girl will see whether the milk is heated . [The children]1713-the children will show [you]93-hamlin the way . "[327-the girl]

CHAPTER II .

[HAMLIN]93-hamlin felt rather contrite and humiliated as [he]93-hamlin sat down at the square table , with [the two eldest children]336-the two eldest children , pert little rosy and flaxen things , on either side of [him]93-hamlin , and [the three little ones]337-the three little ones staring at [him]93-hamlin , and then suddenly making convulsive dives under the table?cloth and behind [each other]338-each other s shoulders opposite . [He]93-hamlin was the furthest possible removed from [the kind of young man who persecutes [pretty housemaids]340-pretty housemaids]339-the kind of young man who persecutes pretty housemaids . Whatever vagaries [he]93-hamlin might have had in [his]93-hamlin life , they were not of that sort ; and now , although [he]93-hamlin had merely intended to ask for some breakfast , [he]93-hamlin found [himself]93-hamlin somehow in the position of pushing [his]93-hamlin presence upon [a servant girl]341-a servant girl . [He]93-hamlin was vexed with [himself]93-hamlin , and became very grave ,

scarce ?

ly

scarcely

answering the chatter of [the children]1713-the children by [his]93-hamlin side .

" And [you]93-hamlin know , "[343-the eldest child] said [the eldest child]343-the eldest child , [a pretty little minx of eleven]344-a pretty little minx of eleven , fully conscious of [her]343-the eldest child charms , " [mamma]1728-mamma told [us]1729-us [you]93-hamlin were [the great poet]1730-the great poet , and [she]1728-mamma read [us]1729-us a poem of yours about [Sir Troilus]100-sir troilus . [Mamma]101-mamma always reads poetry to [us]1729-us and [we]1729-us liked it so much , and [I]343-the eldest child liked all about where [he]100-sir troilus kisses [the lady]1731-the lady so much , and [her]1731-the lady purple dress with the golden roses , and then about [Love]102-love , where [he]100-sir troilus comes and takes [her]1731-the lady by the throat , and chokes [her]1731-the lady , and makes [her]1731-the lady feel like a furnace . [Mamma]101-mamma says it s just like love . " And [you]93-hamlin know , "[347-the younger] insisted [the younger]347-the younger , in [her]347-the younger little , impertinent lisp , " [mamma]1728-mamma said [we]1737-we should put the myrtles , because [you]93-hamlin made poems about myrtles ; and [we]1737-we were to have had on [our]1737-we best frocks , and met [you]93-hamlin in [the hall]297-the hall , and "[347-the younger] " Hush , [Winnie]104-winnie ! "[347-the younger] " And thrown roses on the floor before [you]93-hamlin ; only then [papa]1741-papa got a telegram saying [you]93-hamlin were coming by [the late train]1742-the late train , and [we]1737-we had to go to bed "[347-the younger] [Miss Winnie]104-winnie s revelations and [[her]104-winnie sister]348-her sister s expostulations were interrupted by the entry of [the nurse]349-the nurse , or [governess]350-governess , or whatever else [she]104-winnie might be , carrying a large jug of milk . [She]104-winnie had slipped on a skirt and loose jacket of striped peasant cotton , which at a distance looked like a dull , rich purple . [She]104-winnie sat down at the head of the table , and began silently helping the hot milk . " May [I]93-hamlin cut the bread for [you]104-winnie ? "[93-hamlin] asked [Hamlin]93-hamlin , feeling quite shy from [her]104-winnie silence .

" [I]104-winnie don t think [you]93-hamlin will know how to do[104-winnie]

it , " [she]104-winnie answered . "[104-winnie] [We]351-we have only yesterday s bread at this hour , until [the cook]1719-the cook returns from [market]353-market . " When the milk was helped and the bread cut , [she]104-winnie said , rather sharply[1719-the cook]

" Now , [children]314-children , say [your]93-hamlin prayer . "[1713-the children] [The children]1713-the children immediately set up a shrill chorus ; [the elder , who wished to show off]355-the elder , who wished to show off , slowly [the little ones , who were hungry]356-the little ones , who were hungry , quicker ; an absurdly pseudo?poetical thanksgiving , which reminded [Hamlin]93-hamlin of the sort of poetry presented to [rich foreigners]357-rich foreigners by [needy Italians on creamy , embossed , and illuminated paper]358-needy italians on creamy , embossed , and illuminated paper . [He]93-hamlin was struck by the fact that [the girl]327-the girl did not join , but waited passively through this religio?poetical ceremony ; doubtless , [he]93-hamlin thought , because [she]327-the girl was [a Catholic]360-a catholic . " That s mamma s Tuesday hymn , "[104-winnie] said [Winnie]104-winnie ; " [she]327-the girl makes a different one for each day of the week . "[104-winnie]

Whereupon [the children]1713-the children fell vigorously to [their]1713-the children breakfast of bread and milk . Heaven knows when [Hamlin]93-hamlin had eaten bread and milk last probably , [he]93-hamlin thought , not since [he]93-hamlin

had been out of frocks ; but it seemed to [him]93-hamlin pleasant and pastoral . [He]93-hamlin would have enjoyed this improvised breakfast had [the children]1713-the children chattered less incessantly [Hamlin]93-hamlin did not care for [children]314-children , and had [he]93-hamlin not continued to feel rather as if [he]93-hamlin had been courting [a nursemaid]364-a nursemaid . [The young woman]330-the young woman had as much as [she]330-the young woman could do in pouring out more milk , giving out more figs , and cutting more slices of bread and butter for [the children]1713-the children ; and [her]330-the young woman conversation was entirely engrossed in admonitions to [them]1713-the children not to spill [their]1713-the children milk , not to jump on [their]1713-the children chairs , not to talk with [their]1713-the children mouths full , and so forth . [She]330-the young woman seemed determined , in [her]330-the young woman sullen indifferent way , to make [Hamlin]93-hamlin understand that [he]93-hamlin might intrude [[his]93-hamlin person]367-his person at that breakfast?table , but that [he]93-hamlin had no chance of intruding [his]93-hamlin personality upon [her]330-the young woman notice . But [her]330-the young woman very indifference afforded [Hamlin]93-hamlin an opportunity , and , as it were , a right , to examine [her]330-the young woman appearance : [one]368-one may surely look at [a person who obstinately refuses to notice one]369-a person who obstinately refuses to notice one . [She]330-the young woman was very beautiful , and even more than

beautiful strange . [She]330-the young woman seemed very young , certainly , thought [Hamlin]93-hamlin not more than nineteen at most ; but [her]330-the young woman face , though of perfectly smooth complexion , without furrow or faintest wrinkle , was wholly unyouthful ; the look was not of age , for [you]370-you could not imagine [her]330-the young woman ever growing old , but of a perfect negation of youth . [Hamlin]93-hamlin tried to think what [she]330-the young woman might have been as [a child]371-a child , looking round on the childish faces about [him]93-hamlin , but in vain . The complexion was of a uniform opaque pallor , more like certain old marble than ivory ; indeed [you]370-you might almost imagine , as [she]330-the young woman sat motionless at the head of the table , that this was [no living creature]372-no living creature , but some sort of strange statue cheek and chin and forehead of Parian marble , scarcely stained a dull red in the lips , and hair of dull wrought?iron , and eyes of some mysterious greyish?blue , slate?tinted onyx : a beautiful and sombre idol of [the heathen]373-the heathen . And the features were stranger and more monumental even than the substance in which they seemed carved by

some sharp chisel , delighting in gradual hollowing of cheek and eye , in sudden cutting of bold groove and cavity of nostril and lip . The forehead was high and narrow , the nose massive , heavy , with a slight droop that reminded [Hamlin]93-hamlin of the head of [Antinous]105-antinous ; the lips thick , and of curiously bold projection and curl ; the faintly hollowed cheek subsided gradually into a neck round and erect like a tower , but set into the massive chest as some strong supple branch into a tree?trunk . [He]93-hamlin wondered as [he]93-hamlin looked at [her]330-the young woman ; and wondered whether [this strange type , neither Latin nor Greek , but with something of Jewish and something of Ethiopian subdued into a statuesque but most un?Hellenic beauty]374-this strange type , neither latin nor greek , but with something of jewish and something of ethiopian subdued into a statuesque but most un?hellenic beauty , had met [him]93-hamlin before . The nearest approach seemed to be certain mournful and sullen heads of [Michaelangelo]106-michaelangelo , the type was so monumental , and at the same time so picturesque ; and as [he]93-hamlin looked at [the girl]327-the girl , it seemed , despite its strangeness , as if , at some dim distant time , [he]93-hamlin had seen and known it well before .

[He]93-hamlin looked at [her]327-the girl with the curiosity of [an artist examining a model]376-an artist examining a model , or [a poet trying to solve a riddle]377-a poet trying to solve a riddle ; there was , [he]93-hamlin felt conscious , nothing insolent or offensive in [his]93-hamlin stare . Yet [he]93-hamlin felt [he]93-hamlin must break the silence ; so , with real indifference , [he]93-hamlin suddenly asked " How is it that [you]327-the girl speak English so marvellously well ? [No one]1744-no one would ever guess that [you]327-the girl were not English . "[93-hamlin] " [I]327-the girl am English , "[327-the girl] answered [the girl]327-the girl . English nationality had explained many otherwise unaccountable mixed types to [Hamlin]93-hamlin ; but this took [him]93-hamlin by surprise , and left [him]93-hamlin utterly incredulous . [This girl]379-this girl certainly was [no Englishwoman]380-no englishwoman [a Jewess]381-a jewess , perhaps . No , never ; [no Jewess]382-no jewess was ever so pure and statuesque of outline : some Eastern , dashed with Hindoo or Negro ; they were much coarser , more common , of far more obvious , less subtle beauty . " [You]379-this girl mean English by adoption , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin suggested , " surely not by blood ? "[93-hamlin]

" [[My]108-scotch mother]1745-my mother was [an Italian]1746-an italian . [I]108-scotch think [[her]1745-my mother[108-scotch]

family]1747-her family came from [Sicily]9-sicily or [Sardinia]10-sardinia , or somewhere , where there are [Spaniards]383-spaniards and [Moors]107-moors , " [she]0-i answered ; "[108-scotch] but [[my]0-i father]384-my father was [Scotch]108-scotch . " And [he]389-he was [a bad , bad man]1757-a bad , bad man , "[346-the eldest] went on [the eldest]346-the eldest , composedly . " [He]389-he used to drink quantities of acquavite ; and one day when [he]389-he had[346-the eldest]

[Hamlin]93-hamlin listened as the cruel words dribbled out , and stared at the childish face . [He]93-hamlin had never taken any interest in [children]314-children ; but [he]93-hamlin had never thought that [a child]371-a child could be so deliberately as it seemed to [him]93-hamlin malignant . " And is it true , "[104-winnie] interrupted [Winnie]104-winnie , " that [you]93-hamlin are going to do [our]1758-us picture ? CHAPTER III .

WHEN breakfast was over , and [she]395-she had made [the children]1713-the children fold up [their]1713-the children napkins , [the nurse]349-the nurse took what remained of figs , bread , and milk to lock up in [the kitchen]310-the kitchen . [Mildred]111-mildred , [the eldest of [the little Perrys]400-the little perrys]399-the eldest of the little perrys , sidled up to [Hamlin]93-hamlin , as [he]93-hamlin stood on the doorstep leading into [the vineyard]401-the vineyard , lighting a cigarette , and asked whether [he]93-hamlin would not like to see [[her]111-mildred garden]402-her garden .

[Hamlin]93-hamlin looked down upon [the innocent?looking little fiend]403-the innocent?looking little fiend with a sort of disgust and contempt . " Thank [you]111-mildred , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said ; " [gardens]1761-gardens aren t much in [my]93-hamlin line . "[93-hamlin] [The little thing]404-the little thing scowled at this rebuff of [her]111-mildred fascinations . But a sudden thought struck [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " Yes , by the way , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said , " [I]93-hamlin do take an interest in [gardens]1761-gardens sometimes . Come and show [me]93-hamlin [yours]404-the little thing . "[93-hamlin]

[Mildred]111-mildred slipped [her]111-mildred arm through [his]93-hamlin [a long?legged , fair?haired , pre?Raphaelite child]405-a long?legged , fair?haired , pre?raphaelite child , in much?darned stockings and patched pinafore [Winnie]104-winnie , [the second , a rounder , more comfortable , cherubic beauty]406-the second , a rounder , more comfortable , cherubic beauty , seized [his]93-hamlin hand . " This is [[my]104-winnie garden]1763-my garden ! "[104-winnie] cried [Winnie]104-winnie , dragging [him]93-hamlin along , and pointing to the melancholy little patch . " [I]104-winnie have marigolds , and sunflowers , and red beans and potatoes . "[104-winnie] " And this is [mine]111-mildred , "[111-mildred] said [Mildred]111-mildred , raising [her]111-mildred big blue eyes . with ; [we]411-us want tomato seeds , " clamoured [Winnie]104-winnie .[411-us]

" Hush , [Winnie]104-winnie ! [I]111-mildred wonder [you]104-winnie re not ashamed ! "[111-mildred] cried [Mildred]111-mildred . " They are very good sort of [gardens]1761-gardens , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin , fishing in [his]93-hamlin waistcoat for loose silver , while [the children]1713-the children looked at [him]93-hamlin with beaming eyes ; " here [I]93-hamlin hope [your]104-winnie tomatoes may prosper and prove eatable . "[93-hamlin] Then [he]93-hamlin suddenly turned to [Mildred]111-mildred . " Come here , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin ordered , " [I]93-hamlin want to speak to [you]111-mildred ; "[93-hamlin] and [he]93-hamlin sat down on a stone bench under [a plane?tree]413-a plane?tree , in which [the cicala]414-the cicala was sawing away with all [his]93-hamlin might . [Mildred]111-mildred stood in front of [him]93-hamlin , wondering , half hoping for the usual request that [she]111-mildred should sit for [an angel or a fairy]415-an angel or a fairy .

" Look here , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin , quietly ; " [I]93-hamlin want to know how [you]111-mildred would feel if [[your]111-mildred papa]1767-your papa had been in the habit of drinking too much acquavite , and had shot [himself]1767-your papa after trying to murder [[your]111-mildred mamma]1768-your mamma , and [some nasty little girl]1769-some nasty little girl blurted it all out at breakfast to [a perfect stranger]1770-a perfect stranger ? "[93-hamlin]

[The child]416-the child flushed with surprise and anger ; [she]416-the child looked as if [she]416-the child would have scratched [Hamlin]93-hamlin s eyes out . But [he]93-hamlin looked steadily in [her]416-the child face , and [he]93-hamlin was [a stranger]417-a stranger , [a gentleman]418-a gentleman , [a man]248-a man , and not [[her]416-the child papa]420-her papa ; circumstances which entirely overawed [her]416-the child . [She]416-the child recovered [her]416-the child composure marvellously , and answered after a moment s reflection , " [[My]416-the child papa]1771-my papa is [a gentleman]418-a gentleman , and [[Annina]110-annina s papa]1773-annina s papa was [a common man]1774-a common man [a mascalzone]1775-a mascalzone , "[416-the child] with considerable triumph at [her]416-the child dignified argument .

" [[Your]416-the child papa]1767-your papa is [a gentleman]418-a gentleman , "[93-hamlin] replied [Hamlin]93-hamlin , sternly ; " [I]93-hamlin have known [him]1767-your papa long before [you]416-the child were born . But remember , if [you]416-the child say cruel things which hurt [people]322-people s feelings , whether [they]322-people be [gentle people]1779-gentle people or [servants]1780-servants , however much [[your]416-the child papa]1767-your papa may be [a gentleman]418-a gentleman , [you]416-the child won t be [a lady]1783-a lady . "[93-hamlin]

And [Hamlin]93-hamlin left [the little Perrys]113-the little perrys to muse upon this moral truth . [He]93-hamlin felt quite excited ; and when the excitement had subsided , [he]93-hamlin felt quite astonished at [himself]93-hamlin . [He]93-hamlin could scarcely realise that [he]93-hamlin [himself]93-hamlin had actually been

meddling in [other people]421-other people s affairs , had been reading a lesson to [[other people]421-other people s children]423-other people s children , all about [a little girl]424-a little girl saying offensive things to [[her]424-a little girl nurse]425-her nurse . It was so strange that it quite humiliated [him]93-hamlin : [he]93-hamlin had first pushed [[his]93-hamlin company]426-his company on to [a nursemaid]364-a nursemaid , and then , unasked , fought [the nursemaid]428-the nursemaid s battle . [This confounded Perry household]429-this confounded perry household ! Was it going to turn [him]93-hamlin also into [a ridiculous caricature]430-a ridiculous caricature ? [He]93-hamlin went up?stairs and wrote some business letters , and corrected a lot of proof of [his]93-hamlin new book . Then [he]93-hamlin thought it would be pleasanter to correct the remainder in [the garden]431-the garden ; so [he]93-hamlin brought down [his]93-hamlin writing?case , and established [himself]93-hamlin on the grass behind [the house]254-the house . [The first?floor balcony]433-the first?floor balcony and the roof projected a deep shade ; and on the high grass flickered shadows of plane?trees and laurels , as through their branches there flickered the pale?blue sky . The swifts flew round the eaves with sharp noise , the cicalas sawed in the trees ; all was profoundly peaceable . But suddenly , from the first?floor windows came a vague sound of

childish sobbing , a confused murmur as if of consolation . Then a pause , after which a well?known voice arose shrill in glib Italian .

" [Annina]110-annina , how dare [you]110-annina distress [the signorina Mildred]1784-the signorina mildred ? How dare [you]110-annina say cruel things to [[my]434-the other voice poor , poor sensitive child]1785-my poor , poor sensitive child ? "[434-the other voice] " [I]434-the other voice have said nothing cruel to [the signorina Mildred]111-mildred , "[434-the other voice] answered a deep , quiet voice ; " the signorina [Mildred]111-mildred went to show [[her]111-mildred garden]402-her garden to [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin , and then came back crying . [I]434-the other voice asked [her]111-mildred what had happened , but [she]111-mildred refused to tell [me]434-the other voice . [I]434-the other voice have nothing to do with [her]111-mildred tears . "[434-the other voice] " How dare [you]110-annina tell such an untruth ? "[94-perry] shrieked [Mrs Perry]94-perry . " [The signorina Mildred]111-mildred said something about [[your]110-annina father]1787-your father at breakfast , and [you]110-annina , like [a little viper]1788-a little viper , turned round upon [the poor little darling]1789-the poor little darling . [She]111-mildred is nearly in hysterics ! [You]110-annina little serpent ! "[94-perry] " It is one of [Miss Mildred]111-mildred s usual lies , "[434-the other voice] answered [the other voice]434-the other voice calmly " una delle solite bugÏe . "[434-the other voice]

[Hamlin]93-hamlin had been admitted too much into

confidence . [He]93-hamlin took up [his]93-hamlin writing things hastily , and removed to the furthest end of [the garden]431-the garden , out of reach of the dispute .

This was the pretty result of [his]93-hamlin interference ! [He]93-hamlin had merely got [this poor devil of [a nursemaid]364-a nursemaid]436-this poor devil of a nursemaid into a scrape . It was the fit punishment for [his]93-hamlin folly in going out of [his]93-hamlin way to meddle with [other folk]438-other folk . [He]93-hamlin was very much annoyed ; [he]93-hamlin had been dragged into [a sordid woman]439-a sordid woman s squabble ; [Mrs Perry]94-perry s scolding had seemed addressed to [him]93-hamlin . At the same time , [he]93-hamlin did feel indignant that [the girl]327-the girl should be treated in this fashion : such a splendid , queenly creature slanged by a sentimental , ? sthetic fishwife , as [he]93-hamlin defined [[his]93-hamlin hostess]305-his hostess to [himself]93-hamlin . The return of [Melton Perry]94-perry interrupted [his]93-hamlin reflections . [Perry]94-perry was quite astonished to find [him]93-hamlin up , and extremely distressed at [his]93-hamlin having had no regular breakfast . " [You]94-perry see , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said , " [Mrs Perry]94-perry is very delicate in short , scarcely fit for any kind of household bother , so that "[93-hamlin]

" Oh , "[93-hamlin] answered [Hamlin]93-hamlin , " [I]93-hamlin had a capital breakfast with [[your]94-perry children]1790-your children . "[93-hamlin] Then [they]442-they fell to talking of old times ; and little by little there emerged from out of the overworked , henpecked [Melton Perry]94-perry of the present , the resemblance of [the proud and brilliant Melton Perry of the past]443-the proud and brilliant melton perry of the past .

" Of course , "[94-perry] said [Perry]94-perry , as [they]442-they sat smoking in [the sheltered studio]444-the sheltered studio " of course [I]445-i m very happy , and that sort of thing . [[My]445-i wife]1791-my wife well , [she]1791-my wife s a little impetuous , and [I]445-i don t always agree about [her]1791-my wife way of bringing up [the children]1713-the children but there s no saying that [she]1791-my wife isn t [an immensely superior kind of woman]1793-an immensely superior kind of woman . [I]445-i don t always agree with [her]1791-my wife , mind [you]94-perry ; but [she]1791-my wife has the true poetic temperament , and "[445-i] here [he]445-i made an evident effort " [she]1791-my wife keeps [me]445-i up to the mark with [my]445-i work . [I]445-i was always a lazy hound , [you]94-perry know , and all that . In short , [I]445-i know [I]445-i m quite [a singularly fortunate man]1794-a singularly fortunate man . Nevertheless , well , [I]445-i tell [you]94-perry [my]445-i frank opinion about matrimony : never do it ; the odds[445-i]

are too great . [My]0-i own belief is , that , especially for [an artist]446-an artist , it s [a fellow]447-a fellow s ruin . [Mine]0-i , [you]448-you see , is an exceptional position . But if [you]448-you take [my]0-i advice , [old man]449-old man , never marry . "[448-you]

" [I]93-hamlin don t think there is the faintest chance , "[93-hamlin] answered [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " [Women]1795-women have got to bore [me]93-hamlin long ago : all that in [my]93-hamlin poems is mere recollections of the past descriptions of a myself which has long come to an end . "[93-hamlin] " [I]94-perry m glad of it , "[94-perry] replied [Perry]94-perry . " It is a foolish thing to get tied to [a woman]317-a woman . "[94-perry] " Foolish indeed ! "[93-hamlin] thought [Hamlin]93-hamlin , looking from [[his]93-hamlin shabby , depressed old comrade]450-his shabby , depressed old comrade , to the blazing sunsets and green moonlights on the easels about [them]451-them .

CHAPTER IV .

DURING luncheon , no mention was made of [the nursemaid into whose concerns [Hamlin]93-hamlin had that morning intruded]452-the nursemaid into whose concerns hamlin had that morning intruded ; but at dinner , [Hamlin]93-hamlin s sense of the question being a sore one , and of being [himself]93-hamlin mixed up in it , gave way before [his]93-hamlin curiosity to solve the riddle of the strange?type which had taken [him]93-hamlin so by surprise .

" That is [a very strange?looking girl [you]305-his hostess have in [your]305-his hostess service]1797-a very strange?looking girl you have in your service , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin remarked to [[his]93-hamlin hostess]305-his hostess , over [their]451-them grapes and thin wine . " [The cook]1719-the cook ? "[94-perry] cried [Mrs Perry]94-perry . " Isn t [she]1719-the cook [a divine creature]1799-a divine creature ? [I]94-perry call [her]1719-the cook [[Monna Lisa]114-monna lisa s younger sister]1800-monna lisa s younger sister . "[94-perry] " [I]93-hamlin don t know [[your]305-his hostess cook]1801-your cook by sight , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin answered . " [I]93-hamlin mean [the other young woman [they]451-them call [Annina]110-annina]1802-the other young woman they call annina "[93-hamlin]

[Mrs Perry]94-perry s brow darkened . " [The nurse]349-the nurse or [governess]350-governess , [I]94-perry don t know exactly how to describe [her]1802-the other young woman they call annina , of [[your]305-his hostess little girls]1805-your little girls . "[94-perry] " [[[My]94-perry children]1806-my children s maid]1807-my children s maid , "[94-perry] answered [Mrs Perry]94-perry , with considerable emphasis . " Thank heaven , [[my]94-perry children]1806-my children have never had and shall never have [any other nurse]1809-any other nurse or [any other governess than [[their]1806-my children own mother]1811-their own mother]1810-any other governess than their own mother . "[94-perry] " Well , now , [Julia]115-julia , "[94-perry] remonstrated [[her]94-perry husband]454-her husband , " [I]94-perry think , [you]115-julia know , that s pushing it a little too far . "[94-perry] " [[My]94-perry children]1806-my children shall never learn anything from [a menial]1813-a menial , "[94-perry] insisted [Mrs Perry]94-perry , " neither to walk bodily , nor morally , nor intellectually , as long as [I]94-perry am alive . "[94-perry] " Good heavens ! "[93-hamlin] thought [Hamlin]93-hamlin , " what [a bandy?legged family]1814-a bandy?legged family [they]1806-my children are likely to turn out ! "[93-hamlin] " [I]94-perry suppose [you]93-hamlin mean [Annie]91-anne , "[94-perry] said [Perry]94-perry . " Yes , [she]91-anne s [a good girl]1815-a good girl , and [a good?looking girl]1816-a good?looking girl . "[94-perry] " [You]93-hamlin are mad , [Melton]94-perry , "[94-perry] cried [Mrs Perry]94-perry , " with [your]93-hamlin idea of goodness and good looks ! "[94-perry]

" [I]93-hamlin think [her]91-anne extraordinarily good?looking , "[93-hamlin] put in [Hamlin]93-hamlin , enjoying the authority of [his]93-hamlin own verdict . " [I]94-perry always told [you]93-hamlin so , "[94-perry] replied [Perry]94-perry . " When [I]93-hamlin say good?looking , "[93-hamlin] corrected [Hamlin]93-hamlin , " [I]93-hamlin don t mean it at all in the ordinary sense . There are dozens of [Italian girls]1817-italian girls five times as pretty as [that girl]1818-that girl , and [I]93-hamlin daresay [most people]1819-most people don t think [her]1818-that girl at all attractive . "[93-hamlin] " Yes , "[94-perry] burst out [Mrs Perry]94-perry , " vulgar minds and eyes never appreciate the higher beauty . [They]1819-most people see only the body . "[94-perry] " This is exactly a question of the body , "[93-hamlin] went on [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " [That girl]1818-that girl is one of the most singular types [I]93-hamlin have ever come across . [She]1818-that girl is like [some of [[Michaelangelo]106-michaelangelo s women]1822-michaelangelo s women]1821-some of michaelangelo s women , but even stranger [a superb creature]1823-a superb creature . "[93-hamlin] The revelation of [[her]94-perry maid]455-her maid s beauty by so great an authority as [Hamlin]93-hamlin quite dazzled and delighted [Mrs Perry]94-perry .

" All [[our]1824-our servants]1825-our servants are handsome , "[94-perry] [she]94-perry said ; " [the cook]1719-the cook s the finest Leonardo da Vinci type when [you]93-hamlin see [her]1818-that girl [you]93-hamlin will want to do [her]1818-that girl[94-perry]

picture , [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin , as [Venus Mystica]116-venus mystica , " and [Mrs Melton Perry]94-perry set [her]94-perry meagre features and wide?opening mouth into a mystic smile , intimating that [she]94-perry knew a great deal about [Venus Mystica]116-venus mystica , and [[her]94-perry guest]1827-her guest doubtless likewise .[116-venus mystica]

" And [the footman]1828-the footman "[94-perry] . . . [she]94-perry went on . " Errand?boy , "[94-perry] corrected [Mr Perry]99-mr perry , suddenly , emboldened by [[his]99-mr perry friend]456-his friend s presence . " [The footman]1828-the footman is quite a type of manly beauty [a young Hercules]1830-a young hercules , such a neck and shoulders and arms and a head like a cameo . [I]99-mr perry always make it a rule to engage only [handsome servants]1831-handsome servants , because it spiritualises the minds of [[our]1832-our children]1833-our children to be brought up constantly surrounded by beautiful human forms . "[99-mr perry] " [I]93-hamlin see , "[93-hamlin] answered [Hamlin]93-hamlin drily , entirely neglecting [his]93-hamlin opportunity of making the usual reply to this remark namely , that [the young Perrys]457-the young perrys were so abundantly provided with beautiful human form in the person of [[their]457-the young perrys mother]458-their mother that any other was superfluous . " [That girl [you]93-hamlin noticed]1834-that girl you noticed has rather a curious history , "[99-mr perry] said [Perry]99-mr perry .

" Indeed ! "[93-hamlin] answered [Hamlin;"she]117-hamlin;"she looks as if [she]1834-that girl you noticed ought to have some sort of tragic past a kind of Brynhilt or [Amazon]118-amazon . "[93-hamlin] " It s tragic enough if [you]93-hamlin like , but it s unfortunately not at all poetical , "[99-mr perry] replied [Perry]99-mr perry . " There is poetry in all suffering , [Melton]99-mr perry , "[459-his wife] corrected [[his]93-hamlin wife]459-his wife gravely .

" Well , [this girl]379-this girl is [the daughter of [a Scotch mechanic]1837-a scotch mechanic]1836-the daughter of a scotch mechanic , [a very clever fellow]1838-a very clever fellow , [I]119-drel scoundrel believe , who fell in love with [the Italian maid of [some old friends of ours]1840-some old friends of ours]1839-the italian maid of some old friends of ours , and followed [her]379-this girl to [Italy]1-italy . [He]93-hamlin got a very good position in [the docks]1749-the docks at [Spezia]13-spezia , but then [the other chaps]1842-the other chaps caballed against [him]93-hamlin , and made [him]93-hamlin lose [his]93-hamlin place . [They]1842-the other chaps had to live from hand to mouth for a long while , doing odd jobs for [the railway company]1843-the railway company ; [he]93-hamlin squandered [his]93-hamlin money also on inventions , so , little by little , [he]93-hamlin and [[his]93-hamlin wife]459-his wife and [children]314-children got into great distress . Then [he]93-hamlin took to drinking , [poor devil]1846-poor devil ! [I]119-drel scoundrel m sure [I]119-drel scoundrel should have done so long before ; and one day that [he]93-hamlin had again been done out of a place by [some Italian[119-drel scoundrel]

scoun]1847-some italian scoun ?

[drel

scoundrel]119-drel scoundrel

, [he]460-he tried to throw [[his]460-he wife]459-his wife out of the window , and then shot [himself]460-he . It was a dreadful business . "[460-he]

" [He]93-hamlin was [a great republican]1848-a great republican , [poor dear]1849-poor dear , "[94-perry] added [Mrs Perry]94-perry . "[93-hamlin] " [Darling Miss Curzon]120-miss curzon ! "[94-perry] exclaimed [Mrs Perry]94-perry . " [Miss Curzon]120-miss curzon was [an excellent old woman]1866-an excellent old woman , "[94-perry] went on [Perry]94-perry : " [she]120-miss curzon took [Annie]91-anne when [she]91-anne was eleven , and kept [her]91-anne in [[her]120-miss curzon house]1863-her house and educated [her]91-anne till [her]120-miss curzon own death two years ago ; "[94-perry] and [Perry]94-perry sighed , as [he]462-he peeled a hard white peach .

"[94-perry] " So [she]1869-this child has been with [you]94-perry ever since ? "[94-perry] " Yes , "[94-perry] answered [Perry]94-perry , sharply ; " and [I]94-perry should like [her]1869-this child to remain for [the children]1713-the children s sake , only that [I]94-perry feel [the girl]327-the girl ought to look out for some better place . "[94-perry] And [he]463-his turned rather gloomily to [[his]463-his wife]459-his wife .

[Mrs Perry]94-perry answered [his]463-his look with one of sweet and ineffable astonishment . [She]94-perry naturally viewed all [her]94-perry property , [servants]1780-servants , [children]314-children , [husband]467-husband , c. , as emanations from [herself]94-perry that is to say , from perfection , and consequently as

more perfect than other folk s property , [servants]1780-servants , [children]314-children , [husbands]470-husbands , although occasionally falling short of this ineffable origin ; and [she]94-perry accepted , with alacrity and pleasure , the belief in the transcendent beauty of [the nursemaid whom [she]94-perry had shrieked at only a few hours before]471-the nursemaid whom she had shrieked at only a few hours before . [She]94-perry was quite reconciled to [her]94-perry , evidently .

" And what is [this girl]379-this girl s name ? "[93-hamlin] asked [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " [Anne]91-anne , "[94-perry] answered [Perry]94-perry " [Anne Brown]91-anne . "[94-perry]

CHAPTER V.

THUS it came about that [Walter Hamlin]93-hamlin , of [Wotton Hall]15-wotton hall , [pre?Raphaelite poet and painter]472-pre?raphaelite poet and painter , made acquaintance with [Anne Brown]91-anne , [nurse]473-nurse , or as [Mrs Perry]94-perry defined [it]474-it , [[children]314-children s maid at [the Villa Arnolfini]284-the villa arnolfini]476-children s maid at the villa arnolfini .

The whole of the two following days , [Hamlin]93-hamlin neither saw nor particularly remembered [the strange girl whose champion [he]93-hamlin had constituted [himself]93-hamlin against [the little Perrys]113-the little perrys]478-the strange girl whose champion he had constituted himself against the little perrys . An old chaise , with an older pony , was produced from [the neighbouring farmhouse]479-the neighbouring farmhouse , and [Mr]480-mr and [Mrs Melton Perry]94-perry took it by turns to drive [[their]481-their guest]482-their guest along [the dusty roads]483-the dusty roads to [the old town of [Lucca]8-lucca]484-the old town of lucca , to [various villas]485-various villas , and other sights of [the neighbourhood]486-the neighbourhood . In the evening [Perry]94-perry led [[his]93-hamlin friend]456-his friend out for a stroll among [the vineyards]488-the vineyards and

the olives , and across [the low hills covered with bright green pines and dark cypresses]489-the low hills covered with bright green pines and dark cypresses . At the end of the third day , [Hamlin]93-hamlin , while smoking after dinner with [[his]93-hamlin host]490-his host , insinuated to [Perry]94-perry that [he]93-hamlin really thought [he]93-hamlin must be pushing on to [Florence]5-florence . A look of blank terror overspread poor [Perry]94-perry s face .

" Nonsense ! "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin cried " don t say that ; don t leave [me]93-hamlin in the lurch yet . "[93-hamlin] " [You]94-perry see , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin , hypocritically , " [I]93-hamlin intend going to [America]6-america ; and [I]93-hamlin really think [I]93-hamlin ought to do a little work before leaving [Italy]1-italy . "[93-hamlin] " What sort of work ? "[93-hamlin] " Why , [I]93-hamlin suppose [I]93-hamlin think [I]93-hamlin ought to take this opportunity of working a little at one of [my]93-hamlin pictures for the next Grosvenor . "[93-hamlin] " Which picture ? "[94-perry] asked [Perry]94-perry , eagerly . " [I]94-perry really scarcely know . [I]94-perry suppose [I]94-perry ought to be making some studies for [Circe]122-circe and [the child Comus]1877-the child comus . "[94-perry]

" [Child Comus]123-child comus ! "[94-perry] exclaimed [Perry]94-perry . " Why , [I]94-perry ve the very thing [you]491-you want here at hand .[94-perry]

Such a Comus for [you]491-you ! There s not a model in all [Florence]5-florence will suit [you]491-you so well ; it s [[the farmer]492-the farmer s son]493-the farmer s son . Such legs , and such a chest ! "[94-perry]

" [I]93-hamlin don t intend doing [him]493-the farmer s son naked , "[93-hamlin] answered [Hamlin]93-hamlin , whose strong point was not anatomy . " Naked or not , [he]493-the farmer s son s what [you]491-you want . The head , since [you]491-you don t care for legs and chest . [You]491-you shall have [him]493-the farmer s son to?morrow ; and [you]491-you can work much better here than in that swelter at [Florence]5-florence "[93-hamlin] " In short , "[94-perry] burst out [poor Perry]94-perry , " don t leave [me]94-perry yet , [old fellow]1878-old fellow . [You]491-you don t know what it is for [me]94-perry to have [you]491-you [here]1733-here [I]94-perry feel quite [another man]1880-another man . It seems to [me]94-perry as if [I]94-perry were ten years younger . The fact is , don t [you]491-you know , [a man]248-a man s never the same when once married ; it s a weight round [his]248-a man neck . Don t go away yet , [dear old Watty]124-watty , for the sake of auld lang syne . "[94-perry]

[Hamlin]93-hamlin could not help being touched by the way in which [[his]93-hamlin old friend]275-his old friend threw [himself]94-perry on [his]275-his old friend compassion . [Poor old Perry]94-perry ! How

dreadfully dreary and broken?spirited [he]275-his old friend must be when all alone with [that awful wife of [his]275-his old friend]495-that awful wife of his !

" Well , [I]93-hamlin m willing enough to stay , if [you]275-his old friend ll keep [me]93-hamlin , "[93-hamlin] answered [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " That s right ! "[94-perry] cried [Perry]94-perry , squeezing [his]93-hamlin hand . " Keep [me]94-perry from growing into a turnip for a little longer , for goodness sake . "[94-perry] So the next morning [the farmer s boy]496-the farmer s boy was sent for , and [Hamlin]93-hamlin began , in a desultory way , to make some studies for [his]496-the farmer s boy picture . The fact was , [he]93-hamlin was so utterly indifferent as to all [his]93-hamlin own movements , that it was an absolute relief to be pinned down to one place by [[his]93-hamlin old friend]275-his old friend . Accordingly [he]93-hamlin unpacked [his]93-hamlin things , and prepared to stay at [the Villa Arnolfini]284-the villa arnolfini until [the Perrys]113-the little perrys should [themselves]113-the little perrys return to [Florence]5-florence in October .

Little by little [he]93-hamlin got to arrange [his]93-hamlin day so as to avoid as far as possible the dreaded t?te???t?te with [Mrs Perry]94-perry ; spending the morning lying on the sear grass or the fallen fir?needles under [Melton Perry]94-perry s sketching umbrella ; and

locking [himself]93-hamlin up during the afternoon with the pretext of [his]93-hamlin picture . Locking [himself]93-hamlin up , and sometimes unlocking the door and letting [the lank and limp lady]499-the lank and limp lady come and sit in [[his]93-hamlin improvised studio]500-his improvised studio , entertaining [him]93-hamlin with [her]499-the lank and limp lady views on life , poetry , art , love ; and invariably representing [herself]499-the lank and limp lady as [the devoted slave of [a kind of fierce and gloomy lover?husband of the Othello description]502-a kind of fierce and gloomy lover?husband of the othello description]501-the devoted slave of a kind of fierce and gloomy lover?husband of the othello description . During this first week of [his]93-hamlin stay at [the Villa Arnolfini]284-the villa arnolfini , [Hamlin]93-hamlin did not lose sight of [the Perrys strange nursemaid]504-the perrys strange nursemaid . [The girl]327-the girl s exotic , and , so to speak , tragic style of beauty , had made a great impression upon [him]93-hamlin , but a sort of impression such as only a temper entirely artistic could receive . [He]93-hamlin was interested in [Anne Brown]91-anne , but not in the whole of [Anne Brown]91-anne . [He]93-hamlin wished to see more of [her]327-the girl , but to see more only of [her]327-the girl superb physical appearance , and of that sullen , silent , almost haughty manner which accompanied it . As to anything there might be , intellectual or moral , behind [this beautiful and dramatic creature]506-this beautiful and dramatic creature , [he]93-hamlin did not

care in the least , and would much rather have seen nothing of it . So far , [she]327-the girl was striking , admirable , picturesque , consistent ; further details might merely spoil the effect . Hence it was that , although [he]93-hamlin made several sketches of [her]327-the girl head from memory , and although [he]93-hamlin rhymed the first half of a sonnet upon the strange fate which had , to put it in plain prose , given the beauty of [an Amazon]507-an amazon to [a nursemaid]364-a nursemaid , [he]93-hamlin instinctively abstained from seeking in any way to renew the acquaintance which [he]93-hamlin had made that first morning . [The picturesque and imaginative figure]509-the picturesque and imaginative figure was just in the right light and at the right distance , a single movement , and all the picturesqueness and strangeness might vanish . [Walter Hamlin]93-hamlin had had but too many instances of the melancholy results of trying to approach and become familiar with creatures who had caught [his]93-hamlin ? sthetic and poetic fancy . [He]93-hamlin often saw [her]327-the girl hurrying if [she]327-the girl might ever be said to hurry , for there was something wonderfully measured about [her]327-the girl to and fro , filling up ,

it would seem , the gaps in [Mrs Perry]94-perry s rather theoretical housekeeping ; and sometimes , passing through the ground?floor passage , [he]93-hamlin would also see [her]327-the girl ironing , like that first time , or laboriously presiding over the little Perrys lessons ; for it appeared that [Mrs Perry]94-perry s intellectual guidance of [[her]94-perry children]510-her children consisted in telling [them]510-her children the plots of novels and repeating choice poetry , leaving such mechanical matters as reading and writing to what [she]94-perry called [a menial]1813-a menial . And even more frequently [Hamlin]93-hamlin would meet [her]94-perry taking [the children]1713-the children for a walk , or sitting in [the vineyard]401-the vineyard sewing or reading , while [they]1713-the children built [houses of leaves]514-houses of leaves and sticks , and cooked dinners of maize?grains and unripe figs . [Hamlin]93-hamlin scarcely ever spoke to [her]327-the girl ; and if [the children]1713-the children forced [him]93-hamlin to remain and examine [[their]1713-the children houses]516-their houses or [their]1713-the children dinners , [he]93-hamlin would watch [the girl]327-the girl , but without the slightest desire of entering into conversation . [He]93-hamlin wished to know only as much as [he]93-hamlin could see of [her]327-the girl . But this much which [he]93-hamlin saw inspired [him]93-hamlin with a kind of respect , a respect not for [Anne

Brown]91-anne , [nursemaid]518-nursemaid or nursery?governess of [Mrs Melton Perry]94-perry , but respect for [a beautiful and solemn kind of Valkyr or Amazon]519-a beautiful and solemn kind of valkyr or amazon ; for there is no doubt that to certain temperaments not given to respect for social distinctions or religious institutions , or even the kind of moral characteristics held to be worthy of respect by [ordinary folk]520-ordinary folk , there is something actually venerable in some kinds of beauty : [the man]521-the man respects [the unknown woman]522-the unknown woman as [a goddess]523-a goddess , and respects [himself]521-the man for having discovered [her]522-the unknown woman divinity . So that , habitually and instinctively , [Hamlin]93-hamlin displayed towards [the young woman]330-the young woman a degree of courtesy which astonished [the little Perrys , who had seen [young men]526-young men flirt with various of [[their]526-young men mother s carefully selected beautiful servants]527-their mother s carefully selected beautiful servants]525-the little perrys , who had seen young men flirt with various of their mother s carefully selected beautiful servants , but never treat [them]526-young men , as [Miss Mildred]111-mildred expressed it , as if [they]526-young men were funerals passing . All of which distant respect [Anne Brown]91-anne received coldly , as if it were a matter of course ; showing astonishment only on one occasion , when [Hamlin]93-hamlin answered , being requested to lift [little Winnie]104-winnie into the branches

of an olive?tree " [You]327-the girl must first ask permission of [Miss Brown]91-anne . "[327-the girl]

[The girl]327-the girl looked up from [her]327-the girl work , and fixed [her]327-the girl great greyish?blue eyes upon [him]93-hamlin in wonder . [No one]1744-no one had ever called [her]327-the girl [Miss Brown]91-anne before .

Thus things might have continued , and [Hamlin]93-hamlin have left [the Villa Arnolfini]284-the villa arnolfini with only a few lines of a sonnet on the fly?leaf of [his]93-hamlin Vita Nuova a few scratched?out sketches of a face with strange , curling full lips , and masses of wiry hair , in [his]93-hamlin sketchbook and a daily fainter remembrance of [[Mrs Perry]94-perry s nurse]531-mrs perry s nurse ; when one day [he]93-hamlin took it into [his]93-hamlin head to construct a kind of medieval costume for [[his]93-hamlin peasant?boy model]532-his peasant?boy model , and accordingly went to [Mrs Perry]94-perry for assistance in sewing together the various shreds of old brocade and satin which [he]93-hamlin had bought at [Lucca]8-lucca , the various bits of weather?stained cotton which [he]93-hamlin had obtained by barter from [the peasants]533-the peasants . [Mrs Perry]94-perry , lying languidly on a sofa in [her]94-perry dusty boudoir , littered over with

books and reviews , afforded [him]93-hamlin a variety of valuable pieces of information upon harmonies of colours and the magic of folds ; but when it came to practical tailoring , [she]94-perry smiled with reproachful gentleness , and , clapping [her]94-perry hands , called out for [Annie]91-anne . [Annie]91-anne that is to say , [Anne Brown]91-anne emerged from [an adjacent room]534-an adjacent room , silent and sullen as usual ; but when [she]91-anne understood that the job was for [Hamlin]93-hamlin , [she]91-anne seemed suddenly to develop a certain interest in it . The pieces of stuff were spread out on the drawing?room table , and [Hamlin]93-hamlin proceeded to explain what manner of garment [he]93-hamlin wanted , [Mrs Perry]94-perry joining in from [the next room]1722-the next room with various bewildering instructions . [The girl]327-the girl immediately understood ; but the piece of work was complicated and tiresome . The stuff had several times to be sewn together , tried on to [the live model]537-the live model , and then taken down?stairs to be altered .

" Won t [you]327-the girl sit down and do it here , [Miss Brown]91-anne ? "[93-hamlin] [Hamlin]93-hamlin at length suggested .

[The girl]327-the girl hesitated for a moment , and then

settled [herself]327-the girl to sew at the table of [the empty drawing?room]539-the empty drawing?room . [Hamlin]93-hamlin went into [the studio]540-the studio next door , and tried to draw a little ; but [he]93-hamlin felt [himself]93-hamlin attracted to go and watch [the girl]327-the girl as [she]327-the girl leaned over the table , or sat with [her]327-the girl beautiful head bending over [her]327-the girl sewing . Every now and then [she]327-the girl looked up to ask [him]93-hamlin some question : a regal , tragic , out?of?our?world , almost weird face , the contrast of which with [her]327-the girl prosiac questions about seams and tucks was almost comic .

[Hamlin]93-hamlin looked at [her]327-the girl as [he]93-hamlin might have looked at [a beautiful cathedral front]542-a beautiful cathedral front ; and [he]93-hamlin began to feel that kind of anticipated regret at the thought of losing sight of something beautiful and rare , that almost painful desire to keep at least some durable likeness of it , which , in former years , had often tormented [him]93-hamlin in the midst of the enjoyment of lovely things . [He]93-hamlin did not see [his]93-hamlin way to introducing [Anne Brown]91-anne into any picture ; nay , [he]93-hamlin perhaps did not even think of [his]93-hamlin work ; but [he]93-hamlin determined that [he]93-hamlin must have a likeness of

[her]327-the girl to take away with [him]93-hamlin . Accordingly , that same evening , as [he]93-hamlin was seated with [the Perrys]113-the little perrys in front of [the villa]543-the villa , watching the stars gradually lighting themselves in the bright metallic blue sky , [Hamlin]93-hamlin suddenly turned to [[his]93-hamlin hostess]305-his hostess , and asked [her]305-his hostess whether [she]305-his hostess thought it would be possible for [him]93-hamlin to make a sketch of [Anne Brown]91-anne .

" [I]93-hamlin may want [her]327-the girl for a picture some day , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin added , half hypocritically . [Mrs Perry]94-perry s enthusiasm was immediately kindled .

" Oh ! "[94-perry] [she]94-perry exclaimed , " paint a picture of [her]327-the girl as [the Witch of [Atlas]16-atlas]1882-the witch of atlas , with a red cloak and red roses all about [her]327-the girl , and a background of cactuses and aloes all twisting and writhing , and looking as if they gibbered . Do paint [her]327-the girl like that , dear [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin and [Mildred]111-mildred and [Winnie]104-winnie will do for attendant spirits . Begin to?morrow [you]93-hamlin shall have [her]327-the girl to sit to [you]93-hamlin all day ; and [she]327-the girl has such lovely arms and shoulders , [you]93-hamlin must paint [her]327-the girl in some kind of dress that will show [them]1883-them . "[94-perry]

" [I]94-perry think it s rather cool of [you]93-hamlin to promise [Annie]91-anne as [a sitter]1884-a sitter in that way , "[94-perry] put in [Melton Perry]94-perry " especially with so few clothes on , [Julia]115-julia . "[94-perry] " Why not ? "[94-perry] asked [Mrs Perry]94-perry , in astonishment . " If [she]327-the girl is beautiful [she]327-the girl must be painted . [She]327-the girl shall begin sitting to?morrow morning . "[94-perry] " [She]327-the girl shan t do anything of the kind ! "[94-perry] exclaimed [Perry]94-perry , suddenly . " [I]94-perry don t see at all what right [we]1885-we have to dispose of [her]327-the girl . [We]1885-we pay [her]327-the girl wages as [a servant for [[our]1885-we children]1833-our children , not as a model for [[our]1885-we visitors]1888-our visitors]1886-a servant for our children , not as a model for our visitors . "[94-perry] " [I]93-hamlin never dreamed of [Miss Brown]91-anne being in any way compelled to sit , "[93-hamlin] remonstrated [Hamlin]93-hamlin , rather indignantly . " [I]93-hamlin only wanted [your]94-perry assistance in asking whether [she]327-the girl would . "[93-hamlin] " Of course [she]327-the girl will , "[94-perry] insisted [Mrs Perry]94-perry . " Why , [I]94-perry wonder what great hardship there is in sitting for one s likeness ? Haven t [I]94-perry done it hundreds of times ? When [a woman]317-a woman is beautiful , it s [her]317-a woman duty ; that s what [I]94-perry was always told . "[94-perry]

" It may be the duty of [a lady]1783-a lady , [Julia]115-julia , "[94-perry]

answered

[Mr Perry]99-mr perry , gloomily , " and it may be [yours]94-perry ; but it isn t the duty of [a servant girl]341-a servant girl the difference lies in that . "[99-mr perry]

" Well , "[94-perry] retorted [Mrs Perry]94-perry , angrily , " [I]94-perry think [you]94-perry don t show much appreciation of the honour of having [one of the greatest of living painters in [[our]1893-our house]1894-our house]1892-one of the greatest of living painters in our house , [Perry]94-perry . "[93-hamlin] " [You]94-perry shall have [a willing one]1896-a willing one , [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin ; "[94-perry] and [Mrs Perry]94-perry walked off with dignity . [Melton Perry]94-perry suddenly shook off [his]545-i languor , and started after [[his]545-i wife]459-his wife .

" [Julia]115-julia , "[545-i] [he]545-i cried , " do leave it to [me]545-i [I]545-i ll speak to [Annie]91-anne only do leave it to [me]545-i . "[545-i]

" [I]459-his wife see no reason for this , "[459-his wife] [she]459-his wife answered . " Then [I]94-perry shall speak to [Annie]91-anne at once , "[94-perry] replied [Perry]94-perry .

" There s been far too much of this turning of [servants]1780-servants into [models]1898-models in [this house]1899-this house , "[545-i] [he]545-i said , turning to [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " [Mrs Perry]94-perry can t be got to see that it isn t at all the right sort of thing . [I]545-i don t mind so much with [the others]1900-the others , for [I]545-i suppose [they]1900-the others re a parcel of sluts ; but [Annie]91-anne is another matter . [I]545-i don t mind it s being [you]99-mr perry , [you]99-mr perry know , [old fellow]1878-old fellow ; but [I]545-i object to the principle . [Annie]91-anne ! [Annie]91-anne ! [I]545-i want to speak to [you]91-anne a moment , "[545-i] and [Mr Perry]99-mr perry went into [the house]254-the house . After a moment [he]99-mr perry returned .

" [I]99-mr perry ve spoken to [her]91-anne , [Hamlin]93-hamlin , "[99-mr perry] [he]99-mr perry said . " [I]99-mr perry told [her]91-anne that [she]91-anne was just what [you]93-hamlin wanted for [the Lady Guenevere]125-the lady guenevere or [the Lady of [the Lake]17-the lake]1902-the lady of the lake , or [some lady]1903-some lady or other all a lie ; but [you]93-hamlin see [I]99-mr perry didn t wish [her]91-anne to know it was merely because [she]91-anne s handsome . [I]99-mr perry told [her]91-anne [she]91-anne was like a portrait of [one of [these persons]1905-these persons]1904-one of these persons . Please don t tell [her]91-anne [she]91-anne s not . [I]99-mr perry really expected [she]91-anne d refuse ; and [I]99-mr perry said to [her]91-anne , [Annie]91-anne , mind [you]91-anne don t let [the mistress]1906-the mistress force [you]91-anne into sitting ; don t do it to please [anybody]1907-anybody . [I]99-mr perry m[99-mr perry]

really quite surprised , for [she]548-she s such [a very reserved girl]549-a very reserved girl always ; but then [she]548-she is [an obliging creature]550-an obliging creature too , and [I]0-i think [she]548-she ll do more to please [me]0-i than perhaps [[my]0-i wife]1791-my wife , because [I]0-i always let [her]548-she understand that this isn t a good place at all , and that [she]548-she ought to try for another .
