" Thank [you]99-mr perry , "[93-hamlin] answered [Hamlin]93-hamlin , putting [his]93-hamlin hand on [Perry]99-mr perry s shoulder ; " [you]99-mr perry re [a good old creature]1908-a good old creature , [Perry]99-mr perry . "[93-hamlin]

CHAPTER VI .

[HAMLIN]93-hamlin did not succeed in doing much that first sitting . [He]93-hamlin had thought that [Anne Brown]91-anne s head would be an easy one to sketch ; but it proved just the reverse . Those salient and outlandish features , which [he]93-hamlin had thought [he]93-hamlin could catch in half an hour , were turned into caricature by the slightest exaggeration , and exaggeration was almost inevitable . [He]93-hamlin made several beginnings , and scratched them all out ; and at the end of a couple of hours [he]93-hamlin felt that [he]93-hamlin positively could not go on ; [he]93-hamlin had become quite fidgety over [his]93-hamlin work .

" [I]93-hamlin have bungled everything , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said at last , rising , " and kept [you]91-anne here for nothing ,[93-hamlin]

[Miss Brown]91-anne . The fact is , that [you]91-anne are far more difficult to draw than [I]0-i expected . "[93-hamlin]

[He]93-hamlin felt very humiliated at having , as it were , to confess [himself]93-hamlin [a bad artist]552-a bad artist before [such a model]553-such a model . " Try again , "[99-mr perry] suggested [Perry]99-mr perry . " [I]99-mr perry daresay [Annie]91-anne will sit for [you]91-anne again won t [you]91-anne , [Annie]91-anne ? "[99-mr perry] " If [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin wishes [me]327-the girl to sit , certainly , "[327-the girl] answered [the girl]327-the girl simply .

" [She]91-anne is confoundedly difficult to draw , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin , when [she]327-the girl had turned [her]327-the girl back .

" [She]91-anne s difficult because [she]91-anne s a kind of mystery , "[99-mr perry] explained [Perry]99-mr perry . " [I]99-mr perry ve felt it ever since [we]1909-we have had [her]91-anne . [One]368-one thinks there must be something behind that face , and yet it seems to be a mere blank . [My]99-mr perry belief is , that [people of this condition of life]1911-people of this condition of life often have very little character at least none in particular developed . Because , after all , it s talking and jawing about things which don t matter a pin that develops [our]1909-we character . [The people who have no opportunity for that remain quite[99-mr perry]

without character]1912-the people who have no opportunity for that remain quite without character , until some day [they]555-they are forced to choose whether [they]555-they ll be self?sacrificing creatures or mean pigs . "[556-his model]

" There s something in that , "[93-hamlin] answered [Hamlin]93-hamlin , tearing up [his]93-hamlin abortive sketches in a huff ; " but it is hard that [a man]248-a man should be unable to copy the shape of a handsome face as [he]248-a man would copy the shape of a handsome vase , without wondering what there may be inside . "[93-hamlin]

The fact was , that the utter silence of [[his]93-hamlin model]556-his model , and [his]93-hamlin own utter silence , except when begging [her]556-his model to turn a little more in this direction or that , made [Hamlin]93-hamlin nervous . [He]93-hamlin had , of course , sketched and painted [scores of people who had sat as utterly silent as [Anne Brown]91-anne]557-scores of people who had sat as utterly silent as anne brown , but then [Anne Brown]91-anne was not [a model of that kind]558-a model of that kind . Indifferent as [he]93-hamlin felt towards the hidden reality of [this girl]379-this girl , [he]93-hamlin was , nevertheless , fully conscious that [she]379-this girl was a personality , something much more than a mere form ; or rather , the form itself was suggestive of something more . It would be an easy thing to have to sketch [Michaelangelo]106-michaelangelo s Dawn , or

[his]106-michaelangelo Delphic Sibyl become living flesh , in utter silence with those eyes fixed upon one . If only [he]93-hamlin could speak to [her]379-this girl , or make [her]379-this girl speak , [he]93-hamlin was persuaded it would be much easier ; but for some unaccountable reason it seemed impossible to set up a conversation . One morning accident came to [Hamlin]93-hamlin s assistance . Strolling about after breakfast , [he]93-hamlin found in a corner of [the vineyard]401-the vineyard , where the trampled grass revealed the recent presence of [the little Perrys]113-the little perrys , a couple of books carefully buried under a heap of dead leaves just where [he]93-hamlin chanced to walk . [The children]1713-the children had evidently hidden them out of mischief . One was a cheap copy of [Dante]126-dante , with notes the other an Italian grammar . Turning to the fly?leaf [he]93-hamlin found , written in a curious hand , a stiff imitation of English tradesmen s writing , the name " [Anne Brown]91-anne . "[93-hamlin] [He]93-hamlin wiped the books , for they were wet with dew , and deposited them upon the window?sill of [the nursery]562-the nursery . At half?past nine [the girl]327-the girl came to [the studio]540-the studio . [She]327-the girl had been sitting a little while , when [Hamlin]93-hamlin ,

bending over [his]93-hamlin work , suddenly broke the silence

" [I]93-hamlin find [we]1914-we have [a common friend]1915-a common friend , [Miss Brown]91-anne , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said . [The girl]327-the girl , without stirring , opened [her]327-the girl large eyes . " [A common friend]1915-a common friend ? "[327-the girl] [she]327-the girl asked , with a scarcely perceptible agitation in [her]327-the girl quiet manner ; then added , " [I]327-the girl suppose [you]93-hamlin mean [Mr Perry]99-mr perry ; [I]327-the girl haven t many [friends]1917-friends now anywhere . "[327-the girl] " Oh ! this is [the friend of a great many people thousands besides [ourselves]1914-we]1918-the friend of a great many people thousands besides ourselves , so [you]93-hamlin need not feel jealous ; [his]99-mr perry name is [Dante]126-dante . "[327-the girl] " Indeed ! "[91-anne] answered [Anne Brown]91-anne , and relapsed into silence . But silence did not suit [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " [I]93-hamlin found two books belonging to [you]91-anne in [the vineyard]401-the vineyard early this morning , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin continued ; " and [I]93-hamlin put them on [the nursery window?sill]1920-the nursery window?sill . "[93-hamlin] " Thank [you]93-hamlin , "[91-anne] replied [Miss Brown]91-anne , in [her]91-anne taciturn manner ; " [I]91-anne missed them last night . "[91-anne]

" [I]91-anne was indiscreet enough to wonder whether[91-anne]

[you]91-anne and [I]0-i cared for the same things in [Dante]126-dante , " pursued [Hamlin]93-hamlin ; "[0-i] so [I]0-i ventured to open the book . [I]0-i found [you]91-anne had marked the passage about [Provenzano]18-provenzano . "[91-anne]

" Yes , "[91-anne] said [Miss Brown]91-anne . " How is it that [you]91-anne marked [Provenzano]18-provenzano , and did not mark [Ugolino]127-ugolino , [I]91-anne wonder ? "[91-anne] " [I]91-anne don t care about [Ugolino]127-ugolino . [He]127-ugolino was [a traitor]1921-a traitor . "[91-anne] " Do [you]91-anne consider that [traitors]1922-traitors ought to be starved to death ? "[93-hamlin] asked [Hamlin]93-hamlin , with a smile . " [I]91-anne don t think [any one]1923-any one ought to be starved to death , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne answered very seriously ; " it is too dreadful . But [I]91-anne don t care about [Ugolino]127-ugolino , because [he]127-ugolino was [a traitor]1921-a traitor ; and [the Archbishop]1925-the archbishop was [a traitor]1921-a traitor too . There is [no one to be glad or sorry about]1927-no one to be glad or sorry about . "[91-anne] " And [Francesca da Rimini]128-francesca da rimini ? Do [you]91-anne find there is nothing to care for or be sorry about in [her]128-francesca da rimini ? "[91-anne] A faint redness welled up under the uniform brown pallor of [Anne Brown]91-anne s face .

" [The husband]1928-the husband was quite right , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne said , after a pause . " [You]91-anne are very severe , "[93-hamlin] remarked [Hamlin]93-hamlin " much more severe than [Dante]126-dante . [He]1928-the husband was sorry for [them]1929-they . "[91-anne] " [They]1929-they were quite happy , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne answered . " [They]1929-they did not mind being killed ; [they]1929-they did not mind being driven about in the wind , of course "[91-anne] then [she]91-anne stopped short suddenly . " Why of course ? "[91-anne] and [Hamlin]93-hamlin went on scraping at [his]93-hamlin pencil . " Because [I]91-anne don t think [one]368-one would mind , if [people]322-people cared for one , being driven about in the wind like that . Lots of [people]322-people have been driven about in revolutions , and put into [dungeons]1933-dungeons together , and so on . If [they]1929-they had put [papa]1934-papa in [prison]1935-prison , [I]91-anne should have wanted to go in with [him]1934-papa , "[91-anne] for once [she]91-anne spoke with a certain amount of vehemence .

[Hamlin]93-hamlin looked up from [his]93-hamlin pencil?cutting . The expression which [he]93-hamlin suddenly met in [her]91-anne face made [him]93-hamlin feel that at last [he]93-hamlin had what [he]93-hamlin wanted . It was a curious mixture , possible

only in those strange features , of a kind of passionate effort with dogged determination : the head a little lifted , cheeks and lips firmly set ; but in the eyes , and even in the curl of the close?set lips , a sort of strain , as of [a person trying to inhale a larger amount of air , or to take in a larger sight]566-a person trying to inhale a larger amount of air , or to take in a larger sight . In a second it was gone .

" That is what [I]93-hamlin want ! "[93-hamlin] thought [Hamlin]93-hamlin ; " [the Amazon]1936-the amazon or [Valkyr]129-valkyr as [I]93-hamlin thought . "[93-hamlin] " Tell [me]93-hamlin why [you]91-anne care for [Provenzano]18-provenzano , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin went on , now much more interested in [his]93-hamlin work again . " Because [he]18-provenzano was so proud , and did not like to do humble things , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne answered ; " and yet [he]18-provenzano begged in [the streets]1937-the streets for a ransom for [[his]18-provenzano friend]456-his friend . "[91-anne]

[She]91-anne showed no desire to say more , and [Hamlin]93-hamlin was now engrossed in [his]93-hamlin work . [They]567-they exchanged but a few trivial remarks during the rest of the sitting . [The girl]327-the girl seemed to have contracted a habit of silence , to break through which required a positive effort . When the

sitting had come to an end , [Hamlin]93-hamlin asked whether [she]91-anne could possibly give [him]93-hamlin another .

[She]91-anne hesitated . " If [Mrs Perry]94-perry wishes it , of course , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne answered . " Excuse [me]93-hamlin , "[93-hamlin] corrected [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " [Mrs Perry]94-perry s consent may be necessary for [you]91-anne ; but for [me]93-hamlin , the sitting depends upon [your]91-anne wishes , [Miss Brown]91-anne . "[93-hamlin] " [I]91-anne don t care one way or another , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne answered hurriedly . [Mrs Perry]94-perry of course gave [her]94-perry consent . [She]94-perry had carefully collected and pieced the scattered remnants of yesterday s abortive sketches , and [Hamlin]93-hamlin found [her]94-perry pasting them on to cardboard . " Do let [me]94-perry keep them , [dear Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin , "[94-perry] cried [Mrs Perry]94-perry ; " they are the most precious things [I]94-perry possess . "[94-perry] " They are horrible rubbish ; "[93-hamlin] and [Hamlin]93-hamlin rudely tore them to shreds . " If [you]93-hamlin want something of [mine]94-perry , [I]93-hamlin will make [you]93-hamlin a sketch of [little Winnie]104-winnie only please don t keep these fearful things . "[93-hamlin]

" Thank [you]93-hamlin , thank [you]93-hamlin so much ! "[94-perry] [she]94-perry exclaimed " but oh , mayn t [I]93-hamlin keep this ? it is such a lovely head ! "[93-hamlin]

" It s the head of [Miss Brown]91-anne , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin answered angrily . " [You]93-hamlin don t care for it much on [her]91-anne shoulders , why should [you]93-hamlin care for it on [my]93-hamlin paper an abominable caricature ? Really , [I]93-hamlin must be permitted to tear it up "[93-hamlin] and [he]93-hamlin tore it into a heap of little pieces . The next day but one [he]93-hamlin had another sitting from [Anne Brown]91-anne ; and [he]93-hamlin was so pleased with [his]93-hamlin drawing , that [he]93-hamlin begged for permission to finish it in colours . During these additional sittings there was not much conversation . The Dante topic was perfectly worn to shreds , till at last it seemed as if it could be made to go no further . In despair , [Hamlin]93-hamlin remembered the Italian grammar which [he]93-hamlin had picked up together with the [Dante]126-dante . " What do [you]91-anne want with [an Italian grammer]1939-an italian grammer ? "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin asked . " [You]91-anne surely don t require to study it [yourself]91-anne , [Miss Brown]91-anne ? "[93-hamlin] " [I]91-anne want to teach some day , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne answered .

" Do [you]93-hamlin mean to teach [the Perry children]1940-the perry children ? "[93-hamlin]

" Oh no to teach , to be [a daily governess]1941-a daily governess , what [we]1942-we call a parlatrice [here]1733-here . It is not difficult . The lessons are all conversation . [Many English ladies]1944-many english ladies want those sort of lessons . [I]93-hamlin know [a girl]1945-a girl , [the daughter of [Mrs Perry]94-perry s dressmaker]1946-the daughter of mrs perry s dressmaker , who gives ten lessons every day , and and gets two francs a lesson . "[93-hamlin]

" Ten lessons a?day ! But that s fearful . What awful slavery ! Surely [you]93-hamlin don t want to do that ? "[93-hamlin] " [I]93-hamlin wish [I]93-hamlin could . [I]93-hamlin should be so happy . "[93-hamlin] " Then [you]93-hamlin want to leave [the Perrys]113-the little perrys ? "[93-hamlin] " [I]93-hamlin want to give up being [a servant]1947-a servant . "[93-hamlin] [Hamlin]93-hamlin paused , and looked at [this superb and regal creature]569-this superb and regal creature . [He]93-hamlin did not know what to say . " [You]93-hamlin don t care for [children]314-children ? "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin asked at random . " [I]570-i don t know . [I]570-i don t care for [these children]1949-these children , "[570-i] [she]570-i answered bluntly . " [I]570-i thought [women]1795-women always liked [children]314-children . "[570-i] [She]570-i smiled bitterly .

" Oh , "[570-i] [she]570-i said , " [children]314-children are worse sometimes than [grown people]1953-grown people ; and then one can t resent it , or answer bad words , or strike them , just because [they]314-children are [children]314-children . "[570-i] " Then [you]93-hamlin think [you]93-hamlin would prefer being [a teacher of Italian]1955-a teacher of italian ? "[93-hamlin] " Oh yes , [I]93-hamlin must become that some day ; [I]93-hamlin study when [I]93-hamlin have a little time . [A teacher]1956-a teacher talks with [ladies]1957-ladies , and talks about all sorts of things . "[93-hamlin] " How do [you]93-hamlin mean about all sorts of things ? "[93-hamlin] " About things which are not things to eat , or mend , or clean , about books , and places , and [people]322-people . "[93-hamlin] [Hamlin]93-hamlin could not help smiling . " Is that such a rare pleasure ? "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin asked , thinking not of [the girl with whom [he]93-hamlin was talking , but of those weary ? sthetic discussions which [he]93-hamlin had left behind [him]93-hamlin in [London]3-london]571-the girl with whom he was talking , but of those weary ? sthetic discussions which he had left behind him in london . " [Miss Curzon]120-miss curzon used to talk about books to [me]327-the girl and about music , sometimes , "[327-the girl] said [the girl]327-the girl . " [She]120-miss curzon made [me]327-the girl read Shakespeare with [her]120-miss curzon . That is long , long ago . "[327-the girl]

" And since then . Do [you]93-hamlin never talk about such things ? "[91-anne] " Never . "[327-the girl] " Never ? "[327-the girl] [Anne Brown]91-anne raised [her]91-anne eyes quietly . " Never , except with [you]93-hamlin , [sir]1717-sir . "[91-anne] [Hamlin]93-hamlin did not answer . Towards the end of the sitting , [he]93-hamlin suddenly looked up . " Have [you]327-the girl ever read [the Vita Nuova]20-the vita nuova , [Miss Brown]91-anne ? "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin asked . " What s the [Vita Nuova]20-the vita nuova ? "[93-hamlin] " It is a little book by [Dante]126-dante , in prose and verse , telling how [he]126-dante met [Beatrice]131-beatrice , and then how [she]131-beatrice died . It is much more beautiful than the Divina Commedia . "[327-the girl] [She]327-the girl looked incredulous . " Is it more beautiful than [Bertran del Bornio]22-bertran del bornio , where [he]126-dante carried [his]126-dante head like a lantern ? Or [Bocca degli Abati]23-bocca degli abati , where [they]1960-they all change into snakes ? Or [Cacciaguida]24-cacciaguida when [he]126-dante prophesies about [Dante]126-dante s exile ? "[327-the girl] " It is quite different all about beautiful things , and love . "[93-hamlin]

" [I]327-the girl don t care for that . "[327-the girl] " [You]327-the girl must read it some day , though . "[91-anne] [Miss Brown]91-anne was silent , and relapsed into [her]91-anne usual sullen appearance . " [I]94-perry say , [Hamlin]93-hamlin , [old fellow]1878-old fellow , "[94-perry] said [Perry]94-perry , as [they]573-they walked up and down in [the garden]431-the garden that evening , " do [you]93-hamlin care to see the festival at [Lucca to?morrow]8-lucca ? [I]94-perry m going to take [the children]1713-the children in for a treat , and [I]94-perry shall take [Annie]91-anne too for [she]91-anne never gets any amusement , [poor girl]1963-poor girl . [I]94-perry ve hired [a waggonette]1964-a waggonette will [you]93-hamlin be of the party ? "[94-perry] " Will [you]93-hamlin let [me]327-the girl think about it , [Perry]94-perry ? [I]327-the girl don t much go in for festivals . "[327-the girl] " This is a picturesque affair really worth seeing . "[94-perry] " By the way , "[93-hamlin] asked [Hamlin]93-hamlin , " [I]93-hamlin have nearly finished [my]93-hamlin sketch of [Miss Brown]91-anne , and [I]93-hamlin should like [I]93-hamlin suppose [I]93-hamlin ought to make [her]91-anne some little present . "[93-hamlin]

" [I]94-perry wouldn t , "[94-perry] answered [Melton Perry]94-perry sharply ; " [she]91-anne s [an odd girl]1965-an odd girl , and [you]93-hamlin might just hurt [her]91-anne feelings . [You]93-hamlin see [[her]91-anne father]1966-her father was [a republican]1850-a republican , and that sort of thing , so [she]91-anne s got[94-perry]

all sorts of notions about equality and so forth . Awful bosh , of course , but still [I]0-i think it s as well [she]575-she should have them as not . "[0-i]

" [I]93-hamlin didn t mean any money , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin , feeling [himself]93-hamlin grow red at the mere thought . " Then , if [you]93-hamlin will run the risk , give [her]91-anne some school?books . [You]93-hamlin know [she]91-anne wants to set up as [a teacher]1956-a teacher . Grammars that sort of thing . "[93-hamlin] [Hamlin]93-hamlin made a gesture of disgust . " Horrible ! to give [her]91-anne grammars ! "[93-hamlin] " It s what [she]91-anne wants . "[93-hamlin] " Why , it would seem well it would be like encouraging [her]91-anne to become [a daily governess]1941-a daily governess . "[93-hamlin] " That s just what [I]93-hamlin wish to do . "[93-hamlin] [Hamlin]93-hamlin did not answer . The idea of [Anne Brown]91-anne giving lessons at two francs the hour jarred upon [him]93-hamlin .

CHAPTER VII .

EARLY the following morning [Hamlin]93-hamlin was awakened by the wheels of the waggonette and the bells of the horses . Then came the excited voices of [children]314-children ; the sound of slammed doors and precipitate steps on [the stairs]577-the stairs ; and finally the rattle and jingle of departure . [He]93-hamlin had declined being one of the boisterous expedition to [Lucca]8-lucca , for [he]93-hamlin detested [children]314-children in general , and [the little Perrys]113-the little perrys in particular ; and a day in [the empty house]579-the empty house for [Mrs Perry]94-perry was going to see [some friends at [a neighbouring villa]581-a neighbouring villa]580-some friends at a neighbouring villa had seemed to [him]93-hamlin delightful . [He]93-hamlin opened [his]93-hamlin shutters and saw , in the crisp pale?blue morning , [the carriage]582-the carriage sweeping round the corner of [a narrow lane]583-a narrow lane , [the children]1713-the children s hats , [Anne Brown]91-anne s red shawl , [the coachman]585-the coachman s grey coat , brush rapidly along a tall box hedge .

If there was a thing [Hamlin]93-hamlin hated more than another , it was a holiday , [a crowd]586-a crowd , a lot of [people on a jaunt]587-people on a jaunt .

After breakfast [he]93-hamlin went to [the studio]540-the studio and sat down before [his]93-hamlin sketches of [Miss Brown]91-anne . They were unsatisfactory , but they were as good as [he]93-hamlin could hope to make them . [He]93-hamlin had fancied that a coloured sketch of [her]91-anne head would be all that [he]93-hamlin could possibly want ; but [he]93-hamlin now recognised that , after all , the head , beautiful and singular as it was , was yet the least part of the matter . It was [the girl]327-the girl s gait , [her]91-anne way of carrying [her]91-anne head and neck , [her]91-anne movements when at work , [her]91-anne postures when in repose a number of things of which that head gave no indication , and which , indeed , it was difficult to render in painting , since it was all movement . [He]93-hamlin had scribbled a few lines just fragmentary metaphors and scraps of description suggested to [him]93-hamlin by [Anne Brown]91-anne , and wondered what use [he]93-hamlin would make of them ; indeed , what use [he]93-hamlin could make of [Anne Brown]91-anne altogether . Here was [a

splendid model]590-a splendid model , [a splendid heroine]591-a splendid heroine , but [he]93-hamlin was in the mood neither for painting nor for poetry writing . [He]93-hamlin put a background of dark bay trees to one of [his]93-hamlin sketches , and then regretted having put it in at all . [He]93-hamlin no longer felt inclined to work ; and , all of a sudden , an unaccountable fancy struck [him]93-hamlin to follow [the holiday?makers]592-the holiday?makers to go quietly into [town]593-town to see [them]592-the holiday?makers , without , perhaps , letting [himself]93-hamlin be seen .

The sun was already high as [he]93-hamlin walked , or rather waded , along [the dusty road]594-the dusty road , with its garlands of dust?engrained vines hanging from tree to tree on either side ; its dust?stifled marsh?flowers in the ditch ; [[its]594-the dusty road white farmhouses]595-its white farmhouses , and white stone heaps , white upon white , brilliant , relentlessly white , under the deep blue autumn sky . Before [him]93-hamlin the bullock?carts , with [sleepy drivers]596-sleepy drivers prostrate on [their]596-sleepy drivers back , moved in a white cloud ; a whirlwind of dust was raised by [every cariole , heavily laden with singing and yelling peasants]597-every cariole , heavily laden with singing and yelling peasants , which dashed past . Within sight of the rampart trees , like a pleasant oasis of leafage in

[the treeless green desert of [the town]599-the town]598-the treeless green desert of the town , [the crowd of vehicles of all sorts]600-the crowd of vehicles of all sorts began . Under the red brick gate , with [its]594-the dusty road statue of Justice and motto " Libertas , "[600-the crowd of vehicles of all sorts] there was a perfect block of [carts]601-carts , [gigs , bullocks]602-gigs , bullocks , horses , and [screaming country folk]603-screaming country folk . [Hamlin]93-hamlin wriggled through , and slipped along in the scant shade of [the narrower streets]604-the narrower streets empty and desolate on that holiday ribbons of brilliant light cut into , bordered by the black shadows of overhanging roofs and balconies . A great buzz of voices came from [the square of [the cathedral]606-the cathedral]605-the square of the cathedral ; [peasants]607-peasants and [townsfolk]608-townsfolk elbowing about , [people]322-people at booths yelling [their]322-people wares , [boys]610-boys screeching on whistles and trumpets , cathedral bell tolling , and all the neighbouring church bells clattering and jangling . From the windows of [the blackened palaces]611-the blackened palaces fluttered strips of crimson and yellow brocade ; across [the street]612-the street , from [balcony]613-balcony to balcony , and from twisted iron torchholder to twisted iron bridle?ring , were slung garlands of coloured lamps for the evening s illumination ; and in the

midst of all rose [the cathedral]606-the cathedral front , [its]594-the dusty road tiers and tiers of twisted and sculptured pillarets , with the massive grey belfry soaring by [its]594-the dusty road side into the high blue sky . [Hamlin]93-hamlin pushed [his]93-hamlin way in at one of the side gates ; a rolling of organs , and quavering of choir voices , and clash of brass instruments ; a hot mouthful of heavy , incense?laden atmosphere ; a compact moving human mass beneath the Gothic arches ; beams of light flickering among clouds of dust , and incense and taper smoke high in [the arched nave]615-the arched nave ; constellations of lights on altar , and organ?loft , and chandelier , yellow specks in the mid?day twilight of [the cathedral]606-the cathedral ; something tawdry , hushed , unbreathable , and yet impressive and beautiful .

[Hamlin]93-hamlin gradually made [his]93-hamlin way to the side of the altar?steps . [This part of [the cathedral]606-the cathedral]617-this part of the cathedral was full of [[women]1795-women provincial [great ladies]621-great ladies , and [shopkeepers wives and [daughters]623-daughters]622-shopkeepers wives and daughters in [their]622-shopkeepers wives and daughters Sunday clothes , brilliant caricatures of last year s [Paris]26-paris fashions close packed together on [reserved seats]624-reserved seats , enjoying the incense , the

lights , the music , the holiness of the ceremony , the clothes of [[their]622-shopkeepers wives and daughters neighbours]625-their neighbours]620-women provincial great ladies , and shopkeepers wives and daughters in their sunday clothes , brilliant caricatures of last year s paris fashions close packed together on reserved seats , enjoying the incense , the lights , the music , the holiness of the ceremony , the clothes of their neighbours , the appealing glances of [the young men in elaborate silk and alpaca summer coats , with artistically combed?up heads of hair , sucking [their]622-shopkeepers wives and daughters canes all about the altar]626-the young men in elaborate silk and alpaca summer coats , with artistically combed?up heads of hair , sucking their canes all about the altar . [Hamlin]93-hamlin s entry , however quiet , was soon perceived , and the eyes of [all this womankind]627-all this womankind were fixed upon the sight , rare in [that country town]628-that country town , of [an Englishman]629-an englishman ; and white silk bonnets , and black lace veils , and big red fans , and fuzzy yellow and smooth black heads , leant towards each other , while questions went round in a whisper , who was [the forestiere the handsome forestiere small , slight , meagre , white , with the light hair and moustache]630-the forestiere the handsome forestiere small , slight , meagre , white , with the light hair and moustache , and that melancholy face like [a woman]317-a woman s ? [Hamlin]93-hamlin was quickly bored by all this magnificence ; jostled to pieces , stifled by the heat , and incense , and heavy smell of [the crowd]632-the crowd . [He]93-hamlin was going out , when , as [his]93-hamlin eyes wandered from the silver and lights of the altar , and the shining mitres and stoles of [the priests]633-the priests , to that sea of heads and bonnets and

hats in [the nave]634-the nave , [they]622-shopkeepers wives and daughters were suddenly and unexpectedly arrested on the side steps of the high altar just opposite to [him]93-hamlin . There , among a lot of heads , but high above [them]622-shopkeepers wives and daughters , was a head half covered with coarse black lace and crisp dark hair half turned away from [him]93-hamlin ; a majestic sweep of cheek and jaw , a solemn bend of neck . A moment later the bell tinkled for the elevation of [the Host]635-the host , the organ burst forth into a rapid jig , and [the church]636-the church was a sea of bent heads , of [kneeling and stooping men]637-kneeling and stooping men and [women]1795-women . As [the people]639-the people suddenly sank like a wave about the steps , there remained , stranded as it were , and rising conspicuous , the tall and massive figure of [Miss Brown]91-anne . [She]91-anne was standing on the altar?steps , whose orange?red baize cloth threw up faint yellowish tints on to [her]91-anne long dress of some kind of soft white wool , while the crimson brocade on wall and column formed a sort of dull red background . In the mixed light of the yellow tapers and the grey incense?laden sunbeams , [her]91-anne face acquired a diaphanous pallor , as if of a halo surrounding

it , as [she]91-anne stood , [her]91-anne hands hanging loosely clasped , looking calmly upon [the bowed?down crowd below]640-the bowed?down crowd below . One minute , and the bell tinkling again , [the people]639-the people rose with a muffled , shuffling noise , and hid [her]91-anne from [Hamlin]93-hamlin . The organ and bells were pealing , the voices and violins rising shrill , the incense curling up in grey spirals into the sunbeams among the crimson hangings . The sonnet of [Guido Cavalcanti]132-guido cavalcanti , about the Madonna picture , enshrined at Or [San Michele]27-san michele behind the blazing tapers , and in which [he]132-guido cavalcanti recognised [[his]132-guido cavalcanti lady]642-his lady , came into [Hamlin]93-hamlin s mind , with the sound of the music and the fumes of the incense ; and together with it , a remembrance , a sort of picture , hopelessly jumbled , of [Laura]133-laura in [the church at [Avignon]28-avignon]643-the church at avignon that Good Friday , and [Beatrice]131-beatrice among the blazing lights of the Heavenly Rose . The Mass was over , and [people]322-people began to stir and leave [the cathedral]606-the cathedral . Why had [she]91-anne remained standing while [all the others]646-all the others had knelt ? Perhaps from some Scotch puritanism ; it was incongruous , thought [Hamlin]93-hamlin . But at the same time

[he]93-hamlin felt that , while incongruous in one way for [she]91-anne ought certainly to have knelt like [the others]1900-the others it had in another respect completed an effect ; [this disbelieving girl]648-this disbelieving girl had [herself]91-anne become , as it were , [the Madonna of [the place]650-the place]649-the madonna of the place . [He]93-hamlin stood aside and let [the crowd]632-the crowd slowly pass out . Suddenly [he]93-hamlin saw , among the moving sea of heads , the flaxen curls of [the little Perrys]113-the little perrys the reddish beard of [Melton Perry]94-perry the head , half covered with black lace and towering above the others , of [Miss Brown]91-anne . [She]91-anne was leading [the two smaller children]652-the two smaller children , and looked anxious in [that great crowd]653-that great crowd . Up went one of the little yellow heads ; [she]91-anne had taken [the child]416-the child in [her]91-anne arms . All of a sudden [her]91-anne eyes caught those of [Hamlin]93-hamlin standing close by , and yet separated from [him]93-hamlin by an impassable gulf of [people]322-people . [Her]91-anne own lit up , and with [them]656-them [her]91-anne whole face , in a smile , which [he]93-hamlin had never seen before . At last , near the church door , [the crowd]632-the crowd bore [[his]93-hamlin friends]658-his friends straight towards [him]93-hamlin .

" What ! here after all ! "[94-perry] cried [Perry]94-perry . " Up to some mischief , [you]416-the child cunning dog ! "[94-perry]

" Up to the mischief of watching [these good people]1970-these good people s devotion , "[93-hamlin] answered [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " Why did [you]93-hamlin come ? "[1713-the children] asked [the children]1713-the children eagerly . " [I]93-hamlin suppose because [I]93-hamlin thought [I]93-hamlin should like to amuse [myself]93-hamlin after all , "[93-hamlin] answered [Hamlin]93-hamlin . [They]1713-the children were out on [the cathedral steps]660-the cathedral steps , in the full glare of the blue sky . Outside a fountain was playing , penny whistles and trumpets shrilled on all sides , and [the people at [the stalls]662-the stalls]661-the people at the stalls shrieked and bellowed out [their]661-the people at the stalls wares to [the motley crowd]663-the motley crowd pouring out of [the church]636-the church . [The children]1713-the children cast eyes of longing upon [the booths]666-the booths , decorated with tricolour flags and sprigs of green , full of gaudy dolls , and squeaking wooden dogs , and tin trumpets , and drums ; upon the tables , covered with bottles shaped like pyramids , and [china men]667-china men , and Garibaldi busts , full of red and yellow and green stuff , and with piles of cakes with little pictures of saints stuck in the middle of them .

" Buy [us]1713-the children something , "[668-the little ones] cried [the little ones]668-the little ones to [[their]668-the little ones father]669-their father and [Hamlin]93-hamlin ; and [they]1713-the children squeezed

through [the crowd]632-the crowd , and began to hesitate before the varied splendours of the fair .

" [You]327-the girl look very happy , [Miss Brown]91-anne , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin , as [they]1713-the children were waiting while [the children]1713-the children made [their]1713-the children choice . For really [the girl]327-the girl looked quite radiant , an expression of unwonted happiness , of freedom and amusement , shone through [her]327-the girl quiet , almost solemn , face , like sunshine through a thin film of mist , all the richer for being half suppressed . " It is all so beautiful , "[327-the girl] [she]327-the girl answered , looking round at [the square]673-the square surrounded by [high black palaces draped with crimson brocade]674-high black palaces draped with crimson brocade , and terraces covered with green , and at [the cathedral]606-the cathedral , carved like a precious casket , beneath the blue sky . " Not more beautiful than at [the Villa Arnolfini]284-the villa arnolfini , surely ? "[327-the girl] [She]327-the girl paused . " No , not more beautiful ; but more [I]327-the girl don t know what . "[327-the girl] " More cheerful ? "[327-the girl]

[She]327-the girl shook [her]327-the girl head . " Yes ; but not so[327-the girl]

much that ; more free more [I]0-i don t know how to call it . "[327-the girl]

[The children]1713-the children were laden with lollipops and sixpenny toys . " Come , "[94-perry] said [Perry]94-perry suddenly , very cheerful , in [his]93-hamlin unaccustomed freedom from [his]93-hamlin better half , " [you]327-the girl must choose a fairing , [Annie]91-anne . What will [you]327-the girl have ? a doll ? a beautiful yellow kerchief with purple flowers , warranted the very worst colours in creation ? some gingerbread ? a penny whistle ? No , [I]93-hamlin m sure [you]327-the girl re dying for some literature "[93-hamlin] and [he]93-hamlin turned to a stone bench under [a palace]677-a palace , where twopenny books were piled up , and quantities of leaflets of ballads , and lives of saints , and romantic histories , were strung to the wall .

" Oh ! "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said , " there s nothing for [Annie]91-anne here [she]91-anne hates [saints]1972-saints and [knights]1973-knights and poetry ; [we]1974-we must get [her]91-anne a book on the Rights of [Man]1975-man , or a History of [the French Revolution]1976-the french revolution , at [the bookseller s]1977-the bookseller s in [Via Fillungo]29-via fillungo . But this is just what suits [Hamlin]93-hamlin "[93-hamlin] and throwing

down a heap of coppers , [he]93-hamlin filled [his]93-hamlin hands with printed leaflets . " The tremendous adventures of [the Giant Ferracci]134-the giant ferracci ? , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin read ; " the lamentable history of [[Lucia]135-lucia of [Lamermoor]30-lamermoor]1978-lucia of lamermoor ; the loves of [Irminda]136-irminda and [Astolfo]137-astolfo ; the complaint of [the beautiful Fair?haired One]1979-the beautiful fair?haired one , these are the things for [a poet]260-a poet , "[93-hamlin] and [he]93-hamlin stuffed them into [Hamlin]93-hamlin s pockets .

" Don t be ridiculous , [Melton]94-perry , "[93-hamlin] cried [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " Ridiculous ! "[94-perry] exclaimed [Perry]94-perry . " Who talks of things being ridiculous ? [I]94-perry m in good earnest "[94-perry] and as [they]678-they went along [he]93-hamlin began declaiming , with appropriate gestures , a ballad composed by [some printer s prentice]679-some printer s prentice from the libretto of an old opera . [The children]1713-the children shrieked with laughter at papa s voice and faces ; and [Anne Brown]91-anne burst into a curious subdued laugh , which , although scarcely audible , was extremely childish .

As [they]678-they walked along [the narrow crowded streets]681-the narrow crowded streets towards [the inn]682-the inn where [they]678-they were to

have dinner , [Perry]94-perry kept on ahead with [the two elder children]683-the two elder children , and [Hamlin]93-hamlin hung back with [Miss Brown]91-anne and [the two younger]684-the two younger .

" Did [you]91-anne like the ceremony in [the cathedral]606-the cathedral , [Miss Brown]91-anne ? "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin asked , irresistibly drawn on to understand why [she]91-anne had not knelt like the others . " It was very beautiful , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne said ; " and such beautiful vestments ! Did [you]93-hamlin see the white and gold embroidery of [the bishop]1982-the bishop ? and the purple dresses of [the canons]1983-the canons ? oh , it was lovely ! But it makes [me]91-anne angry to see such things . "[91-anne] " Why so ? "[91-anne] " Because it is dreadful don t [you]93-hamlin think ? to see [all those people kneeling down and believing in all that nonsense]1984-all those people kneeling down and believing in all that nonsense . "[91-anne] " How do [you]93-hamlin know it is nonsense ? It seems to [me]91-anne very beautiful and consoling . "[91-anne]

[She]91-anne turned [her]91-anne big grey?blue eyes upon [him]93-hamlin . " [You]93-hamlin don t mean that [you]93-hamlin believe in all that mummery ? "[91-anne] [she]91-anne asked , searchingly and reproachfully " [you]93-hamlin who have studied so much ;[91-anne]

[you]93-hamlin don t believe that [they]685-they can make [God]138-god come down with [their]685-they mutterings and kneelings ? "[91-anne]

" [I]93-hamlin don t believe it , "[93-hamlin] answered [Hamlin]93-hamlin , with some embarrassment ; " but [I]93-hamlin think it is very beautiful , and [those who do believe in it]1985-those who do believe in it are very happy . "[93-hamlin] " But [you]93-hamlin don t think it is right that [people]322-people should believe in falsehoods , and be [the slaves of [wicked priests]1988-wicked priests]1987-the slaves of wicked priests ? "[91-anne] " How rabid [you]93-hamlin are ! "[93-hamlin] laughed [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " No , [I]93-hamlin don t believe ; but [I]93-hamlin like to see [others]1989-others believing . "[93-hamlin] " [I]91-anne don t ; "[91-anne] and after a minute [she]91-anne added , " Don t [you]93-hamlin believe in anything at all ? "[91-anne] " Perhaps [I]93-hamlin do , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said , fixing [his]93-hamlin eyes upon [her]91-anne . " [I]93-hamlin believe in beauty [I]93-hamlin believe that is the one true thing in life . "[93-hamlin] " [I]91-anne don t know what [you]93-hamlin mean , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne answered ; " but it seems to [me]91-anne dreadful that [people]322-people should believe in [priests]1991-priests and [kings]1992-kings , and all sorts of lies . "[91-anne]

[They]686-they relapsed into silence . As [they]686-they walked along , [Hamlin]93-hamlin stole glances at [[his]93-hamlin companion]687-his companion ,

walking stately and serious like [a saint]688-a saint or [a sibyl]689-a sibyl by [his]93-hamlin side . [He]93-hamlin wondered what [this girl]379-this girl would have been had [she]379-this girl lived three or four centuries back . All this common modern radicalism distressed [him]93-hamlin in [her]379-this girl it had no colour and no perfume . Yet , after all , it was but the modern accessory instead of the medieval . This was the way in which beauty and romance were wasted nowadays wasted , [he]93-hamlin thought , half consciously , yet not perhaps entirely , since it went to make up a characteristic whole .

[Melton Perry]94-perry took [them]686-they to [the chief inn of [the place]650-the place]691-the chief inn of the place for dinner . [He]93-hamlin let [each of [the children]1713-the children]693-each of the children choose whatever [she]379-this girl preferred , ordered several bottles of Asti spumante , and gave it [them]686-they to drink in champagne?glasses . [The one or two furtive English spinsters who were sipping [their]695-the one or two furtive english spinsters who were sipping their tea and reading their " murray " at the other tables of the huge dining?room , profusely ornamented with casts from the antique , and with cut?paper fiy?floppers tea and reading [their]695-the one or two furtive english spinsters who were sipping their tea and reading their " murray " at the other tables of the huge dining?room , profusely ornamented with casts from the antique , and with cut?paper fiy?floppers " Murray "[93-hamlin] at the other tables of [the huge dining?room]696-the huge dining?room , profusely ornamented with casts from the antique , and with cut?paper fiy?floppers]695-the one or two furtive english spinsters who were sipping their tea and reading their " murray " at the other tables of the huge dining?room , profusely ornamented with casts from the antique , and with cut?paper fiy?floppers , looked up with surprise at the festive party headed by [Perry]94-perry .

After dinner [the two little ones]697-the two little ones began to hang [their]697-the two little ones heads in [the hot room]698-the hot room , and gave signs of going to sleep .

" Good gracious ! "[94-perry] said [Perry]94-perry , in a consternation , " what are [we]686-they to do with [these wretched infants]1993-these wretched infants ? [They]1993-these wretched infants ll just prevent [our]686-they taking a stroll in [the town]599-the town before returning [home]1995-home . "[94-perry] " [I]91-anne think the best thing will be for [them]1993-these wretched infants to sleep a little , [sir]1717-sir , "[91-anne] suggested [Anne Brown]91-anne . " [I]91-anne will tuck [them]1993-these wretched infants up on the sofa , and stay with [them]1993-these wretched infants here while [you]1717-sir and [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin take [Miss Mildred]111-mildred and [Miss Winnie]104-winnie for a walk . "[91-anne] " But [I]94-perry can t think of leaving [you]91-anne behind , [Annie]91-anne , "[94-perry] cried [Perry]94-perry . , " [I]94-perry know how much [you]91-anne would like to see [the town]599-the town . "[94-perry]

" [I]91-anne saw part of it this morning , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne swered ; " and [I]91-anne really would just as soon stay with [the children]1713-the children [here]1733-here . "[91-anne] There was no gainsaying [her]91-anne ; so [the two men]699-the two men sallied forth with [the two elder children]683-the two elder children on a walk through [the crowded and bannered streets]701-the crowded and bannered streets ; while [Anne Brown]91-anne remained sitting in [the stuffy inn dining?room]702-the stuffy inn dining?room by the side of [the torpid little

ones]703-the torpid little ones . When [they]699-the two men were out an idea suddenly struck [Hamlin]93-hamlin : this was the opportunity of getting a present for [Anne Brown]91-anne . [He]93-hamlin left [Perry]94-perry regaling [the children]1713-the children on ices at [a cafÃ© opposite [the Church of St Michael]706-the church of st michael]705-a cafÃ© opposite the church of st michael , which rose like a great marble bride?cake into the bright blue sky , and made [his]93-hamlin way to a bookstall which [he]93-hamlin had noticed in the morning . [He]93-hamlin asked for the Vita Nuova . [The old bookseller]707-the old bookseller looked over a number of little schedules in [his]707-the old bookseller desk , and produced several copies , new and second?hand . They did not please [Hamlin]93-hamlin . At last [he]707-the old bookseller displayed a tiny Giunti volume , just delicately yellowed by age , and bound in vellum . [Hamlin]93-hamlin bought it , and secreted it in [his]93-hamlin pocket , and then joined [Perry]94-perry .

[They]699-the two men went to [the stable]708-the stable , where all the carioles from [the country]709-the country put up , and ordered the waggonette to be at [the inn]682-the inn door in an hour . But as [they]699-the two men were slowly mounting [the wide stone staircase]711-the wide stone staircase , with the eternal plaster dancing nymphs tripping it on [each landing]712-each landing , [Perry]94-perry s eye fell upon a large bill pasted upon the

opposite wall , the playbill of [the Teatro del Giglio]713-the teatro del giglio , on which , among the names of [singers]714-singers , [fiddlers]715-fiddlers , [chorus?directors]716-chorus?directors , [scene?painters]717-scene?painters , [theatre tailors]718-theatre tailors , and [hairdressers]719-hairdressers , streamed , in scarlet letters , the title " Semiramide . "[717-scene?painters]

" T ? ! "[139-perry] cried [Milton Perry]139-perry , with the Tuscan expression for a sudden bright thought ; " what do [you]699-the two men two young minxes say to going to hear an opera for the first time in [your]699-the two men lives ? "[139-perry]

" Oh , [papa]1741-papa ! "[111-mildred] shrilled [Mildred]111-mildred . " Oh , [papa]1741-papa ! "[104-winnie] echoed [Winnie]104-winnie , catching hold of [his]720-his knees " Not so quick ! [The dining?room]721-the dining?room was deserted . On a sofa

near the open window lay [the two tiny girls]722-the two tiny girls , propped up with cushions ; [Anne Brown]91-anne , surly , flopping away the flies which buzzed about [them]722-the two tiny girls , and reading a newspaper . [She]91-anne was resting the paper on [her]91-anne knees , and supporting [her]91-anne head with one hand , while the other moved slowly with the cut?paper flopper ; and in this position [the young nursemaid]723-the young nursemaid struck [Hamlin]93-hamlin as a resuscitation , but more beautiful and even stranger , of [one of [[Michaelangelo]106-michaelangelo s prophetic women]725-michaelangelo s prophetic women]724-one of michaelangelo s prophetic women .

" [I]139-perry say , [Annie]91-anne , "[139-perry] cried [Perry]139-perry , " what do [you]91-anne say to taking [these two brats]2006-these two brats to the opera this evening ? "[139-perry] [Anne Brown]91-anne started up . " To the opera , [sir]1717-sir ? "[91-anne] [she]91-anne cried , flushing with pleasure .

" Yes ; [these creatures]2008-these creatures have never been . [They]2008-these creatures re giving Semiramide to?night . [I]139-perry think it s a good opera for [children]314-children to begin with ; because it will teach [them]314-children betimes the unhappy complications which are apt to result from murdering [one s husband]2010-one s husband , and trying[139-perry]

to marry [one s son]726-one s son unawares . [I]0-i ll take [the little ones]668-the little ones back to [the villa]543-the villa in half an hour , and quiet [Mrs Perry]94-perry s feelings . It won t last late . "[93-hamlin]

" But , "[91-anne] exclaimed [Anne Brown]91-anne , " oh , how good of [you]93-hamlin , [sir]1717-sir ! but are [you]93-hamlin sure [you]93-hamlin would not like to stay for the opera [yourself]93-hamlin ? [I]91-anne could take [the little ones]668-the little ones [home]1995-home . "[91-anne]

" No , thank [you]93-hamlin , [Annie]91-anne . The fact is , [I]93-hamlin never have approved of [Rossini]141-rossini s music . Ever since [my]93-hamlin earliest infancy [I]93-hamlin have been shocked by its want of earnestness ; what [I]93-hamlin like is a symphony in P minor , with plenty of chords of the diminished seventeenth . That s the right sort of thing , isn t it , [Hamlin]93-hamlin ? "[93-hamlin]

A few minutes later [Perry]94-perry went away with [the two little girls]732-the two little girls , leaving [Mildred]111-mildred and [Winhie]142-winhie with [Anne Brown]91-anne . [Hamlin]93-hamlin accompanied [them]732-the two little girls down?stairs to the waggonette . " [I]93-hamlin will go to [the theatre]730-the theatre and secure a box , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said , " and order a trap to take [us]732-the two little girls back . "[93-hamlin]

" All right ! "[94-perry] cried [Perry]94-perry , as the waggonette rolled off . " Mind [you]93-hamlin don t let [those children]2015-those children bore [you]93-hamlin or worry [poor Annie]91-anne too much ; and don t leave [them]732-the two little girls alone the whole afternoon . "[94-perry] But , for some unaccountable reason , [Hamlin]93-hamlin did leave [them]732-the two little girls alone the whole afternoon . After [he]93-hamlin had secured the box and ordered [the carriage]582-the carriage , [he]93-hamlin felt a sort of unwillingness to go back to [the inn]682-the inn , perhaps unconsciously , to sit opposite [the Perrys nursemaid]735-the perrys nursemaid ; so [he]93-hamlin walked about [the town]599-the town till tea?time , not troubling [himself]93-hamlin to inquire whether [Anne Brown]91-anne and [the children]1713-the children might not prefer a stroll on [the ramparts]738-the ramparts to the monotony of sitting for two mortal hours in [the inn dining?room]739-the inn dining?room .

CHAPTER VIII .

AT dusk [they]732-the two little girls hurriedly drank some of the thin yellow hotel?tea ; and then hastened to [the theatre]730-the theatre across [the twilit street and square]741-the twilit street and square , where the garlands of Venetian lanterns were beginning to shine like jewels against the pale?blue evening sky . [Hamlin]93-hamlin offered [Anne Brown]91-anne [his]93-hamlin arm , but [she]91-anne asked [him]93-hamlin to give it to [Winnie Perry]143-little winnie .

" [Mildred]111-mildred shall take [mine]111-mildred , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne said " that s the best way in case of [a crowd]586-a crowd . "[91-anne]

[A crowd]586-a crowd , alas ! there was not ; [the liveried theatre]743-the liveried theatre servants doubtless the same , in yellow striped waistcoats and drab gaiters , who carried out [Semiramis]144-semiramis s throne , when the drop?scene fell made profuse bows to [the little party]744-the little party , and handed [them]744-the little party at least half?a?dozen

play ?

bills

playbills

, each as large as an ordinary flag . [The children]1713-the children had never been in [a theatre]746-a theatre before , and were in a high state of delight at the lights , the gilding , the red plush , the scraping of fiddles ; especially at being in a box , although the box on this occasion cost only about half as much as would a single seat in [an English playhouse]747-an english playhouse . Gradually [the theatre]730-the theatre filled ; the boxes with [people of quality from [surrounding villas]750-surrounding villas]749-people of quality from surrounding villas , [gentlemen displaying an ampleness of shirt?front]751-gentlemen displaying an ampleness of shirt?front , and [ladies an ampleness of bosom conceivable only by the provincial mind]752-ladies an ampleness of bosom conceivable only by the provincial mind ; the pit with [townsfolk]608-townsfolk and [officers]754-officers : [the whole company staring with eyes and opera?glasses , talking , singing , rapping with sticks and sabres]755-the whole company staring with eyes and opera?glasses , talking , singing , rapping with sticks and sabres till the overture began to roll out , when [the audience]756-the audience immediately set up a kind of confused hum , supposed to be the melody of the piece , and which half drowned the meagre orchestra .

Then the opera began an opera such as only the misery and genius of [Italy]1-italy could produce . There was a triumphal procession of [six

ragamuffins in cotton trousers and with brass kettle?covers]757-six ragamuffins in cotton trousers and with brass kettle?covers on [their]757-six ragamuffins in cotton trousers and with brass kettle?covers heads , marching round and round the stage , bearing trophies of paper altar?flowers and coffee?biggins ; there was a row of [loathsome females]758-loathsome females , bloated or fleshless , in draggled robes too short or too long , shrieking out of tune in [[the queen]759-the queen s chamber]760-the queen s chamber and [four rapscallions in nightgowns and Tam?o Shanters , and beards which would not stick on]761-four rapscallions in nightgowns and tam?o shanters , and beards which would not stick on , standing round the little spirit?lamp burning in front of [Baal]145-baal s statue ; there was the little black leathern portmanteau containing the Babylonian regalia , which [a nigger with a black?crape face]762-a nigger with a black?crape face carried after [the Prince Arsaces]763-the prince arsaces ; and there was [the " magnificent apartment in [the palace of [Nineveh]146-nineveh]2018-the palace of nineveh]2017-the " magnificent apartment in the palace of nineveh , disclosing a delicious view of [the famous hanging gardens]2019-the famous hanging gardens , "[762-a nigger with a black?crape face] as described by the libretto , and furnished solely with a rush?bottomed chair and a deal table , the table?cloth of which was so short that [Semiramis]144-semiramis was obliged to lean [her]144-semiramis arm on it to prevent its slipping off , which , however , it finally did . Moreover , an

incal ?

culable

incalculable

amount of singing out of tune and pummelling one s chest in moments of passion . No training , no dresses , no scenery , no orchestra . Still in this miserable performance there was an element of beauty and dignity , a something in harmony with the grand situation and glorious music : [a splendidly made [Semiramis]144-semiramis , quite regal in [her]144-semiramis tawdry robes , who showered out volleys of roulades as a bird might shower out its trills]764-a splendidly made semiramis , quite regal in her tawdry robes , who showered out volleys of roulades as a bird might shower out its trills ; [another young woman , plain , tall , and slight]765-another young woman , plain , tall , and slight , playing [the prince in corselet and helmet , with quite magnificent attitudes of defiance and command]766-the prince in corselet and helmet , with quite magnificent attitudes of defiance and command , with bare extended arm and supple wrist . [The two girls who played the principal parts]767-the two girls who played the principal parts were [sisters]768-sisters , and although [they]767-the two girls who played the principal parts had certainly never sung much with [a teacher]1956-a teacher , [they]767-the two girls who played the principal parts must have sung a great deal together ; and [their]767-the two girls who played the principal parts voices and style melted into each other quite as if it were all a spontaneous effusion on [their]767-the two girls who played the principal parts part . All the realities which money can get , dress , voice , training , accessories , scenery , utterly wanting ; but instead , in the midst of pauperism , something which money

can not always get , a certain ideal beauty and charm . [Anne Brown]91-anne was intensely interested in the performance ; indeed , quite as much so , though in another way , as [the children]1713-the children . During the intervals between the acts , [she]91-anne could speak of nothing but the story of [Semiramis]144-semiramis , and wonder what would happen next . [Hamlin]93-hamlin could scarcely help laughing at the concern which [she]91-anne manifested each time that [the hero Arsace]771-the hero arsace was bullied by [the wicked Assur]772-the wicked assur ; but [he]93-hamlin could not laugh at the tragic way in which [she]91-anne conceived the whole situation . To [him]93-hamlin all that florid music of [Rossini]141-rossini would already have destroyed any seriousness there might have been in the matter ; but to [Anne Brown]91-anne it seemed as if all these splendid vocalisations took the place of the visible pomp and magnificence of [Assyrian royalty]773-assyrian royalty : for [her]91-anne [the heroes]774-the heroes and [heroines]775-heroines , [the magi and satraps]776-the magi and satraps , were clad , not in the calico and tinsel of [the theatre tailor]777-the theatre tailor , but in the musical splendours of [Rossini]141-rossini . [Hamlin]93-hamlin , to say the truth , found the performance very wearisome ; [he]93-hamlin had been

bored by [Semiramide]147-semiramide too often with [Tietiens]148-tietiens and [Trebelli]149-trebelli , to find it particularly interesting at [the Teatro del Giglio of Lucca]31-the teatro del giglio of lucca . [He]93-hamlin sat looking on listlessly , not so much at [the stage]778-the stage as at [the girl who was leaning out of the box before [him]93-hamlin , watching each movement of [her]779-the girl who was leaning out of the box before him , watching each movement of her hand and neck , as she devoured the performance with eyes and ears hand and neck , as [she]779-the girl who was leaning out of the box before him , watching each movement of her hand and neck , as she devoured the performance with eyes and ears devoured the performance with eyes and ears]779-the girl who was leaning out of the box before him , watching each movement of her hand and neck , as she devoured the performance with eyes and ears . But when at last there came the grand scene between [Semiramis]144-semiramis and [[her]144-semiramis son]780-her son , whatsoever was good in the performance suddenly burst forth ; [the two young women]781-the two young women sang with a sort of spontaneous passion , a delight in the music and [their]781-the two young women own voices and [themselves]781-the two young women ; and when , [Semiramis]144-semiramis having let down [her]144-semiramis back hair as [distressed heroines]782-distressed heroines always do from utter despair , [Prince Arsaces]150-prince arsaces , not to be outdone , pulled off [his]150-prince arsaces helmet , letting down [his]783-his or [her]784-her back hair also , and [the two]785-the two sank into [each other]338-each other s arms and began the great duet , even [Hamlin]93-hamlin felt in a kind of way that this was passionate , and tragic , and grand . [Anne Brown]91-anne was seated sidewise in the front of the box , resting [her]91-anne mass

of iron?black hair on [her]91-anne hand , [her]91-anne other hand lying loosely on [her]91-anne knees . [Her]91-anne chest heaved under [her]91-anne lace mantilla , and [her]91-anne parted lips quivered . It seemed to [Hamlin]93-hamlin as if this were the real [Semiramis]144-semiramis , [the real mysterious king?woman of antiquity]787-the real mysterious king?woman of antiquity as if the music belonged in some sort of ideal way to [her]144-semiramis . When the curtain had fallen amid the yells of applause , [she]91-anne remained silent , letting [Hamlin]93-hamlin help [her]91-anne on with [her]91-anne shawl without turning [her]91-anne eyes from [the stage]778-the stage . The lights were rapidly put out .

" [We]2020-we must go , [Miss Brown]91-anne , "[93-hamlin] cried [Hamlin]93-hamlin , " otherwise [we]2020-we shall be left in the dark . "[93-hamlin] [She]91-anne turned , took [little Winnie]143-little winnie by the hand , and followed [him]93-hamlin , who led [the elder Perry child]789-the elder perry child , prattling loudly , to the stairs . There was [a great crowd]790-a great crowd going down , whistling and humming tunes from the opera . From the force of habit [Hamlin]93-hamlin again offered [Anne Brown]91-anne [his]93-hamlin arm . But instead of accepting it , [she]91-anne , so to speak , rapidly plucked [little Winnie]143-little winnie from the ground , and raised [her]789-the elder perry child in [her]91-anne arms as if [she]789-the elder perry child were a feather .

" Please let [me]93-hamlin carry [that child]2021-that child , "[93-hamlin] cried [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " Oh no , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne answered quietly . " [I]91-anne don t mind carrying [her]2021-that child at all ; but [she]2021-that child s too heavy for [you]93-hamlin , [sir]1717-sir . "[91-anne]

Out in [the square]673-the square [the carriage]582-the carriage was awaiting [them]793-they in the bright starlight , where the red and green lamps were already dying out among [the plane?trees]794-the plane?trees . In a minute [they]793-they were rattling through [the narrow streets]795-the narrow streets , and out of [the town]599-the town by the dark tree?masses of [the bastions]797-the bastions . The bells of the horses jingled as [they]793-they went ; the melancholy shrilling of insects rose from [the fields]798-the fields all round ; the vine?garlands creaked in the wind . [The two children]799-the two children were speedily asleep one with [her]800-her head on [Hamlin]93-hamlin s shoulder , [the other]801-the other wrapped in [her]800-her nurse s shawl . [Anne Brown]91-anne bent over the side of the waggonette , a dark outline , the damp night breeze catching [her]91-anne hair . [Neither]802-neither spoke . [Hamlin]93-hamlin felt a sense of guilt stealing over [him]93-hamlin ; of guilt for nothing very definite ; of guilt towards [no one else]803-no one else , but towards [himself]93-hamlin .

The drive passed like a dream . Suddenly the wheels grated on the gravel of [the villa garden]804-the villa garden ; dogs barked ; lights appeared ; [the children]1713-the children were lifted out of [the carriage]582-the carriage asleep ; and the voice of [Perry]143-little winnie whispered to [Hamlin]93-hamlin

" [I]143-little winnie caught it nicely when [I]143-little winnie came [home]1995-home [I]143-little winnie don t know why , upon [my]143-little winnie soul ! [I]143-little winnie m sure [I]143-little winnie wish [I]143-little winnie had remained and amused [myself]143-little winnie with [you]93-hamlin . "[143-little winnie] " [I]93-hamlin wish [you]143-little winnie had , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin quite seriously , always with the sense of vague guilt towards [himself]93-hamlin ; then added , " By the way , [old man]449-old man , [I]93-hamlin fear [I]93-hamlin really must go on to [Florence]5-florence to?morrow afternoon . "[93-hamlin]

CHAPTER IX .

[PERRY]143-little winnie could not at first understand [[his]143-little winnie friend]456-his friend s sudden decision , and violently combated it . But after a little while [he]143-little winnie said to [himself]143-little winnie that it must have been fearfully dull for [Hamlin]93-hamlin at [the Villa Arnolfini]2-the villa arnolfini , and that to have stayed so long was already much more than [a miserable being like [himself]93-hamlin]808-a miserable being like himself could expect . So that when [[his]93-hamlin wife]459-his wife nearly went into hysterics at the notion of [Hamlin]93-hamlin [[their]810-they poet?painter]811-their poet?painter , as [she]459-his wife called [him]93-hamlin suddenly departing , [he]93-hamlin represented to [her]459-his wife , with more emphasis than was [his]93-hamlin wo nt , that [Hamlin]93-hamlin had bored [himself]93-hamlin to death , and must be bored no longer .

" And where are [you]93-hamlin going ? "[812-the limp and sapphic lady] asked [the limp and Sapphic lady]812-the limp and sapphic lady , as [they]810-they sat at lunch .

" [I]93-hamlin have no notion , "[93-hamlin] answered [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " [I]93-hamlin know nothing beyond [Florence]5-florence for three days . [I]93-hamlin may go on to [Rome]32-rome , [Naples]33-naples , [Egypt]34-egypt , [America]6-america , [Japan]35-japan , or return to [Hammersmith]36-hammersmith . [I]93-hamlin have no notion . "[93-hamlin] " Ah , [these poets]2025-these poets ! "[94-perry] cried [Mrs Perry]94-perry ; " [they]2025-these poets never can tell whither [their]2025-these poets soul may waft [their]2025-these poets body . "[94-perry] When [they]810-they had finished , [Hamlin]93-hamlin asked whether [he]93-hamlin might say good?bye to [Anne Brown]91-anne . " [I]93-hamlin have a little farewell gift to make [her]91-anne , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin explained . [Anne Brown]91-anne was summoned into [the studio]540-the studio ; [she]91-anne evidently had only just heard the news . " Are [you]93-hamlin going away , [sir]1717-sir , really ? "[91-anne] [she]91-anne asked . " Yes , "[93-hamlin] answered [Hamlin]93-hamlin , drily ; " [I]93-hamlin expect the gig must be waiting for [me]93-hamlin already . "[93-hamlin] " And are [you]93-hamlin not going to return , [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin ? "[93-hamlin] " Oh no ; [I]93-hamlin think [I]93-hamlin shall go to [America]6-america this winter . "[93-hamlin]

[She]91-anne was silent , and stood by the table in the attitude of [a servant waiting for further orders]814-a servant waiting for further orders . " Before [I]93-hamlin go away , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin , " [I]93-hamlin want to thank [you]91-anne , [Miss Brown]91-anne , for [your]91-anne kindness and patience , which have enabled [me]93-hamlin to make a sketch which will be very valuable for one of [my]93-hamlin next pictures , and , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin added , as [she]91-anne merely nodded [her]91-anne head , " [I]91-anne want to beg [you]91-anne to accept a little gift in remembrance of all the trouble [I]91-anne have given [you]91-anne . "[91-anne] [Anne Brown]91-anne flushed , and [her]91-anne face suddenly changed , as if a whip?cord had passed across it . [Hamlin]93-hamlin took the little vellum?bound volume from [his]93-hamlin pocket . " [You]91-anne told [me]93-hamlin [you]91-anne had never read [the Vita Nuova]20-the vita nuova , [Miss Brown]91-anne , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said , " so [I]93-hamlin venture to ask [you]91-anne to accept this copy of it . [I]93-hamlin don t know whether [you]91-anne like old books ; [I]93-hamlin think them much prettier to look at . Good?bye . "[93-hamlin] [The girl]327-the girl s face cleared into a kind of radiance .

" Thank [you]93-hamlin so much , "[327-the girl] [she]327-the girl said ; " [I]327-the girl will read it often . "[327-the girl] " And think of [me]93-hamlin sometimes and the trouble [I]93-hamlin gave [you]91-anne ? "[93-hamlin] " It was [my]327-the girl duty , since [Mrs Perry]94-perry wished it , [sir]1717-sir . Good?bye a good journey to [you]91-anne . "[327-the girl] " Good?bye , [Miss Brown]91-anne . "[327-the girl]

BOOK II .

CHAPTER I.

[WALTER HAMLIN]93-hamlin did not go to [America]6-america . On leaving [the Villa Arnolfini]2-the villa arnolfini , [he]93-hamlin met at [Florence]5-florence [some artist friends]816-some artist friends , who , in [his]93-hamlin condition of utter absence of plans , easily drew [him]93-hamlin on with [them]816-some artist friends to [Siena]37-siena and [Perugia]38-perugia , thence into [the smaller Umbrian cities]817-the smaller umbrian cities , and finally into [a wholly unexplored region between [the Abruzzo]39-the abruzzo and [the Adriatic]40-the adriatic]818-a wholly unexplored region between the abruzzo and the adriatic . By the time that [their]816-some artist friends sketching and article?writing expedition was at an end , the winter had come round , and more than three months had elapsed since [Hamlin]93-hamlin had parted with [the Perrys]819-the perrys . Would [Hamlin]93-hamlin return with [[his]93-hamlin friends]658-his friends to [England]41-england ? [He]93-hamlin had often said that [he]93-hamlin had had enough of [Italy]1-italy that [he]93-hamlin would go [home]1995-home and shut

[him]93-hamlin ?

self

[himself]93-hamlin

up in [[his]93-hamlin studio at [Hammersmith]36-hammersmith]822-his studio at hammersmith , among smoke and river?fogs , seeing [not a living creature]823-not a living creature , learning Persian and studying [Sufi poets]824-sufi poets until next spring , when [he]93-hamlin would set off for [the East]42-the east , never more to return to [Europe]43-europe , except for [the Grosvenor]44-the grosvenor private view . But when the moment for return north approached , [Hamlin]93-hamlin began to hesitate ; and the very day before [[his]93-hamlin friends]658-his friends departure , [he]93-hamlin informed [them]658-his friends that [he]93-hamlin had come to the conclusion that there was still some work for [him]93-hamlin to do in [Italy]1-italy .

" [I]93-hamlin shall be in [England]41-england at the end of two months at latest , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said . And on [their]658-his friends remonstrating at [his]93-hamlin fickleness , [he]93-hamlin merely answered " [I]93-hamlin have a notion for a new picture , and [I]93-hamlin think [I]93-hamlin have found [my]93-hamlin model for it . "[93-hamlin] " The Queen of Night in [[your]93-hamlin portfolio]2028-your portfolio , "[826-one of his friends] suggested [one of [[his]93-hamlin friends]658-his friends]826-one of his friends .

[They]658-his friends had noticed and generally admired that strange head , the like of which none of [them]658-his friends had ever seen before , and [they]658-his friends had given the drawing , which [Hamlin]93-hamlin described

merely as " [a girl near [Lucca]8-lucca]2029-a girl near lucca , "[93-hamlin] the nickname of " [The Queen of Night]2030-the queen of night . "[93-hamlin]

" Yes , "[93-hamlin] answered [Hamlin]93-hamlin , " that s the one [I]93-hamlin m thinking about . "[93-hamlin] So [the rest of the party]828-the rest of the party set sail from [Civita Vecchia]45-civita vecchia ; and one drizzly , foggy morning , [Hamlin]93-hamlin got into [the train]829-the train to carry [him]93-hamlin northward to [Florence]5-florence .

During those three months , [he]93-hamlin could scarcely [himself]93-hamlin have explained when or how , strange notions had come into [Hamlin]93-hamlin s head , and a still stranger plan had finally matured in it . [He]93-hamlin had been haunted by the remembrance of [the Perrys nursemaid]735-the perrys nursemaid at [the Villa Arnolfini]2-the villa arnolfini , and gradually taken to brooding and day?dreaming about [her]735-the perrys nursemaid . [He]93-hamlin had made up [his]93-hamlin mind that [Anne Brown]91-anne was [the most beautiful girl]831-the most beautiful girl , in the strangest style , whom [he]93-hamlin had ever met . What was to be [her]91-anne future ? Of two possibilities one must be realised . Either this magnificent blossom was to be untimely nipped , [this beautiful and strange girl]832-this beautiful and strange girl was to fritter away [her]91-anne life , unnoticed , wasted , to

little by little lose [her]91-anne beauty , [her]91-anne dignity , [her]91-anne grandeur , [her]91-anne whole imaginative aroma ; or the rare plant of beauty was to be cherished , nursed into perfection , till it burst out in maturity of splendour , a thing of delight for the present and of wonder for the future . Either [Anne Brown]91-anne must turn into [a sordid nursery?governess]833-a sordid nursery?governess , or into [the avowedly most beautiful woman in [England]41-england]834-the avowedly most beautiful woman in england that is to say , in [the particular pre?Raphaelite society which constituted [England]41-england to [him]93-hamlin]835-the particular pre?raphaelite society which constituted england to him .

Yet not necessarily ; there was still a middle course [she]91-anne might marry [some small shopkeeper]836-some small shopkeeper or [teacher of languages at [Florence]5-florence]837-teacher of languages at florence ; or , perhaps , [some artist]838-some artist might notice [her]91-anne , make [her]91-anne [[his]93-hamlin mistress]839-his mistress , perhaps [[his]93-hamlin wife]459-his wife . This last thought of [Anne Brown]91-anne as [the possible wife of [some other Melton Perry]842-some other melton perry]841-the possible wife of some other melton perry for [they]843-they were all [Melton Perrys]113-the little perrys at [Florence]5-florence filled [Hamlin]93-hamlin with a vague disgust and irritation . Much better that [she]91-anne should end [her]91-anne life as [a nursery?maid]844-a nursery?maid , or [a daily governess]1941-a daily governess at a franc the hour . Still , it was dreadful to think that something so

unique should be lost , wasted for ever . " Such things must be , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin to [himself]93-hamlin ; " it is sad , but it can t be helped . "[93-hamlin] And [he]93-hamlin wrote two sonnets , " Lost Loveliness , "[93-hamlin] and " Stillborn Joy , "[93-hamlin] which were extremely beautiful , and quite among the finest [he]93-hamlin ever wrote . But this did not despatch the subject . The sense of having made the most of the fact that this loveliness was to be wasted , this joy of beauty to be stillborn , did not make up for the consciousness that the waste , the abortion , had not actually taken place , might yet be prevented , and were dreadful in [themselves]843-they . Was [he]93-hamlin , [Hamlin]93-hamlin , to marry [Anne Brown]91-anne ? [He]93-hamlin shrank in terror from so Quixotic , and at the same time so commonplace , so school?girlish a thought . But if [he]93-hamlin did not marry [her]91-anne [no other man]846-no other man could ; at least , [no other man who was to prevent the act of wastefulness to be consummated]847-no other man who was to prevent the act of wastefulness to be consummated . [She]91-anne might marry [a clerk]848-a clerk , [a shopkeeper]849-a shopkeeper , even [a servant]1947-a servant , or even [some miserable little Anglo?Florentine artist]851-some miserable little anglo?florentine artist ; but if [she]91-anne married [a man above that]852-a man above that , [a man to appreciate and

make the most of [her]91-anne]853-a man to appreciate and make the most of her , [that man]854-that man must evidently be [himself]854-that man . It is difficult to follow the logic of this notion ; but certain it is that [Hamlin]93-hamlin never doubted for a second that either [Anne Brown]91-anne must bloom for [him]93-hamlin and by [him]93-hamlin , must be [his]93-hamlin most precious possession and [his]93-hamlin most precious loan to [the world]241-the world or that [Anne Brown]91-anne must be simply and deliberately buried under a bushel . Such arguments are matters of character , [I]0-i suppose ; be it as it may , the argument was absolutely cogent .

When [Hamlin]93-hamlin had got thus far [he]93-hamlin stopped for a long time , revolving the matter in [his]93-hamlin mind in a purely abstract way , without attempting to realise how things might be settled . [He]93-hamlin was not [a man of action or of resolves]856-a man of action or of resolves , and would usually let things slip on and look at them slipping ; and during this ruminating condition , [he]93-hamlin did not once seriously ask [himself]93-hamlin whether [he]93-hamlin intended marrying [the Perrys nursemaid]735-the perrys nursemaid . But suddenly , the very day before [[his]93-hamlin friends]658-his friends were to carry [him]93-hamlin back to [England]41-england , a new notion came into [his]93-hamlin head . [His]93-hamlin life seemed

suddenly filled with romance . The matter was settled in a minute . [Anne Brown]91-anne was to be filched triumphantly from oblivion : [he]93-hamlin telegraphed [Perry]94-perry to hire [him]93-hamlin [rooms in [Florence]5-florence]859-rooms in florence . As the meeting of certain chemical substances will sometimes produce a new and undreamt?of something of wholly unprecedented properties , so ideas had come in collision in [Hamlin]93-hamlin s mind , and out of a mere perplexity had arisen [a stranger]417-a stranger scheme out of the question what should be the fate of [Anne Brown]91-anne , had originated the decision what was to be the future of [Walter Hamlin]93-hamlin . The situations seemed changed : instead of [his]93-hamlin being a mere possible , but by no means probable , instrument of a change in [her]91-anne life , [she]91-anne was the predestined instrument for the consummation of [his]93-hamlin life . [Anne Brown]91-anne should live for [the world]241-the world and for fame ; and [Walter Hamlin]93-hamlin s life should be crowned by gradually endowing with vitality , and then wooing , awakening the love of this beautiful Galatea whose soul [he]93-hamlin had moulded , even as [Pygmalion]151-pygmalion had moulded the limbs of

the image which [he]93-hamlin had made to live and to love . The idea , once present to [Hamlin]93-hamlin s mind , had been accepted at once ; and in another hour [he]93-hamlin had worked out all the details of the real romance in which [he]93-hamlin was embarking ; [he]93-hamlin had determined exactly where [he]93-hamlin would send [Anne Brown]91-anne to [school]862-school , where [he]93-hamlin would go during [her]91-anne stay [there]863-there , what settlements [he]93-hamlin would make to ensure [her]91-anne complete freedom of choice when [she]91-anne should choose [him]93-hamlin , in what part of [London]3-london [he]93-hamlin would buy [a house for [her]91-anne]864-a house for her , which of [[his]93-hamlin female relations]865-his female relations should have charge of [her]91-anne , by whom [she]91-anne should be introduced into [artistic society]866-artistic society ; [he]93-hamlin began to imagine all the details of [his]93-hamlin long courtship . Beyond the courtship , into [their]867-their actual married life , [his]93-hamlin fancy did not carry [him]93-hamlin ; it was that year , or two or three years of gradually growing devotion , upon which [he]93-hamlin cared to dwell . Whether such a scheme was wise or right it never occurred to [him]93-hamlin to question . [He]93-hamlin had determined on educating , wooing , and marrying [a woman like what [Anne Brown]91-anne]868-a woman like what anne brown seemed to be ,

as [a man]248-a man might determine to buy [a house in [a particular fishing or hunting district]871-a particular fishing or hunting district]870-a house in a particular fishing or hunting district the only thing is to make sure whether [the particular house]872-the particular house is [the suitable house]873-the suitable house .
