"[94-perry] Saying which [she]94-perry swept out of [the room]319-the room .

There was a moment s silence . " [I]91-anne have been to [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin s , [Anne]91-anne , "[91-anne] said [Brown]91-anne briefly , seating [himself]91-anne by the fire . " Well ? "[91-anne] The tone of voice was so resolute and even triumphant that [he]1067-i raised [his]1067-i head and looked up at [her]94-perry where [she]94-perry was standing by the table , a piece of needlework still in [her]94-perry hands . " Well , "[91-anne] answered [Brown]91-anne quietly , and watching the effect of each of [his]1067-i words on the pale , melancholy , but dispassionate face of [the girl]327-the girl , " [I]1067-i have spoken to [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin ; and [I]1067-i find that [you]93-hamlin were correct in [your]93-hamlin judgment , and that [I]1067-i was mistaken in [mine]1067-i . [He]93-hamlin is in earnest in [his]93-hamlin proposal , and honest in it . "[1067-i]

" [I]91-anne knew that ; "[91-anne] and [Anne Brown]91-anne wondered whether this could be [the same cousin Dick]1069-the same cousin dick who was [a big boy]1070-a big boy , almost [a man]248-a man , when [she]327-the girl was [a tiny mite at [Spezia]13-spezia]1072-a tiny mite at spezia ; who took care of [her]327-the girl when [[her]327-the girl mother]1073-her mother was ill and [[her]327-the girl father]1966-her father was drunk ; who used to shoulder [[his]1075-his uncle]1076-his uncle and drag [him]1076-his uncle off to bed when , in a fit of

intoxication , [he]1076-his uncle would come in and threaten to throw [the babies]1077-the babies out of the window . [She]91-anne recognised the small features , the dark skin and hair , the heavy intellectual brow ; but [he]1076-his uncle seemed to have changed in expression , to have grown hard , and arrogant , and coarse .

" [I]91-anne knew that , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne repeated , " though [you]1076-his uncle would not believe it . So , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne added , with a certain hardness in [her]91-anne manner , " [I]91-anne suppose [I]91-anne am left free to decide , and that [you]1076-his uncle are ready to let [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin do what [he]93-hamlin chooses . "[91-anne] " [You]91-anne are free to decide , "[1076-his uncle] [he]1076-his uncle answered . " [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin , as [I]91-anne have said , is serious and honest , and willing to make every provision which can bind [him]93-hamlin and leave [you]91-anne free , legally . [I]91-anne can not , as [[your]91-anne guardian]958-your guardian , say no . But , "[91-anne] and [his]1076-his uncle voice assumed a threatening tone , " as [[your]91-anne kinsman]2193-your kinsman , and as [the representative of [[your]91-anne father]1787-your father]2194-the representative of your father , [I]1076-his uncle most earnestly dissuade [you]91-anne from accepting this proposal . "[1076-his uncle] [Anne]91-anne reddened . " But [you]1076-his uncle can no longer oppose it , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne said quickly .

" [I]91-anne have told [you]91-anne before that [you]91-anne are free ,[91-anne]

[Anne]91-anne . And because [you]91-anne are free , " continued [Brown]91-anne , a sort of despair coming over [him]1076-his uncle at the sight of [the girl]327-the girl s indifference "[0-i] because [you]91-anne are free , [I]0-i want [you]91-anne to listen to [me]0-i . This proposal is one which , in the eyes of [the world]241-the world , will change [your]91-anne life for the better : [you]91-anne will be educated , get the manners of [a lady]1783-a lady , be rich [yourself]91-anne , and marry [a rich man]1080-a rich man . But will [you]91-anne stand higher in [your]91-anne own opinion ? Would [you]91-anne stand as high as [you]91-anne should in that of [[your]91-anne father]1787-your father , if [he]1787-your father were alive ? [You]91-anne , having bartered [your]91-anne freedom , having accepted all from [this one man]1082-this one man ? "[91-anne]

[Anne]91-anne did not answer .

" Of course , "[166-richard brown] went on [Richard Brown]166-richard brown eagerly , " [you]91-anne will have every worldly advantage . But will [you]91-anne be happy taken out of [your]91-anne own sphere of life , knowing [yourself]91-anne to be bound in gratitude to [this man]1022-this man , who will always continue to feel [your]91-anne superior , to look down upon [you]91-anne as [a beggar whom [he]1082-this one man has fed]2198-a beggar whom he has fed , or a chattel which [he]1082-this one man has bought ? [This man]1022-this man is , for [his]1082-this one man class and ideas , honourable : [he]1082-this one man wishes to leave [you]91-anne free[166-richard brown]

to marry [him]1082-this one man only if [you]91-anne please ; [he]1082-this one man wishes to marry [you]91-anne really and truly . But in reality [he]1082-this one man is making [you]91-anne [[his]1082-this one man slave]1083-his slave ; for how can [you]91-anne refuse [him]1082-this one man the only thing which [you]91-anne , [[my]0-i poor Nan]1084-my poor nan , can give [him]1082-this one man in return for [his]1082-this one man money ? And in reality [he]1082-this one man is making [you]91-anne [[his]1082-this one man mistress]839-his mistress ; for what sort of marriage is it which is a marriage merely before the world where [the one]1086-the one buys and the other is bought ? "[91-anne]

[Anne]91-anne flushed still deeper , and trembled from head to foot as [she]91-anne leaned against the table . A dull pain clawed [her]91-anne at the heart , a lump rose up to [her]91-anne throat . But [she]91-anne did not speak . [Richard Brown]166-richard brown misunderstood [her]91-anne silence . [He]166-richard brown rose and approached the table , and tried to put [his]166-richard brown arm paternally on [her]91-anne shoulder . [She]91-anne shrank back , but let [his]166-richard brown heavy hand rest on [her]91-anne shoulder . What did [his]166-richard brown touch matter when there were [his]166-richard brown words ?

" [Annie]91-anne , [dear]2200-dear , "[91-anne] said [Brown]91-anne more gently , " [you]91-anne know [I]91-anne am [a rough man]2201-a rough man , and don t know how to mince matters and say things to [women]1795-women ; but [you]91-anne know that [I]91-anne am fond of[91-anne]

[you]91-anne . Don t [you]91-anne recollect when [you]91-anne were [a wee lassie]1087-a wee lassie , and [I]0-i used to carry [you]91-anne about on [my]0-i back , and go into [the water]1088-the water to get [you]91-anne the sea?weeds and the little nautiluses . [I]0-i suppose [you]91-anne don t any longer . But still , [you]91-anne know [I]0-i would not for [the world]241-the world hurt [[my]0-i poor little Nan]1090-my poor little nan . "[0-i]

[Anne]91-anne held on to the table , and as [she]91-anne recognised that familiar intonation , hot tears rolled down [her]91-anne cheeks . [Her]91-anne whole childhood seemed to return to [her]91-anne .

" Don t cry don t cry ! "[91-anne] exclaimed [Brown]91-anne , taking [her]91-anne hand . " [Poor child]2181-poor child ! [I]91-anne know it must be very hard for [you]91-anne who are so young ; [I]91-anne know what it must be to be tempted with [a lady]1783-a lady s education , and money , and [a fine gentleman]1044-a fine gentleman , who s in love with [one]368-one , for [a husband]2207-a husband . But remember what [[your]91-anne poor dad]2208-your poor dad used to tell [us]2209-we , that [we]2209-we [common folk]2210-common folk must make [our]2209-we own way make [the others]1900-the others feel that [we]2209-we re as good as [they]1900-the others , and not accept anything from [them]1900-the others . D [you]1091-you remember how [he]1093-i used to say to [me]91-anne , Work and be proud ? Well , and [I]91-anne[91-anne]

have worked and have been proud , and it s that that has enabled [me]0-i to rest a little . And [you]1091-you , too , must be proud , and work , [[my]0-i little [Annie]91-anne]1092-my little annie . "[91-anne]

" Look here , "[1093-i] [he]1093-i went on , " [you]1091-you must not think [you]1091-you are never to be anything but [a servant]1947-a servant . [I]1093-i feel [I]1093-i ve been to blame , and neglected [you]1091-you too long . [You]1091-you see , [I]1093-i ve had to work hard for [my]1093-i life , out in [England]41-england ; but now [I]1093-i am quite safely off indeed much better off than [I]1093-i ever anticipated : [[my]1093-i employer]2213-my employer is going to take [me]1093-i into partnership next year . Well , since [you]1091-you wish to go to [school]862-school , [I]1093-i will send [you]1091-you [there]863-there . [You]1091-you shall come back with [me]1093-i to [England]41-england , and [I]1093-i will send [you]1091-you to [the very best school to be found]2216-the very best school to be found : [you]1091-you shall be as good as [any lady]2217-any lady , and [you]1091-you shall owe nothing to [any one]1923-any one . [Annie]91-anne , do say yes . "[1093-i]

[He]1094-he spoke , [this rough man]1095-this rough man , almost as one might to [a sick child]1096-a sick child ; and as [he]1094-he spoke , [he]1094-he tried to pass [his]1094-he arm round [the girl]327-the girl s waist . But [Anne]91-anne shuddered , and freed [herself]91-anne from [his]1094-he grasp . There was something in [this big dark

man]1098-this big dark man , with [his]1098-this big dark man bushy hair and beard , which made [her]91-anne shrink physically , although [she]91-anne felt no suspicion of [him]1098-this big dark man morally . The thought of [Hamlin]93-hamlin passed across [her]91-anne mind [Hamlin]93-hamlin , who was everything which [Richard Brown]166-richard brown was not .

" [You]166-richard brown are very good , [Dick]172-dick , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne said , feeling ashamed of [her]91-anne ingratitude ; " but but oh no , no , [I]91-anne can t , [I]91-anne can t ! "[91-anne] and [she]91-anne hid [her]91-anne tears with [her]91-anne hands . " Can t what ? "[166-richard brown] exclaimed [Brown]166-richard brown , and [his]166-richard brown voice and face changed ; " can t what ? Can t accept [my]166-richard brown offer ; can t owe anything to [me]166-richard brown , to [[your]91-anne cousin]2150-your cousin , to [the man to whom [[your]91-anne father]1787-your father confided [you]91-anne]2220-the man to whom your father confided you ? No ! [you]91-anne won t be under such an obligation , eh ? Nay , don t humbug [me]166-richard brown . [You]91-anne can t give up the money , [the land]2222-the land , [the house]254-the house , the fine name all the things which [he]2220-the man to whom your father confided you can give [you]91-anne and [I]166-richard brown can t ; for [I]166-richard brown can only give [you]91-anne an education , and [I]166-richard brown was such a fool as to think that [you]91-anne wanted that ! "[166-richard brown] and [Brown]166-richard brown laughed a loud , bitter laugh .

" [You]91-anne want to marry [that man]854-that man , "[166-richard brown] [he]166-richard brown went

on brutally ; " well , do so . But remember what marriage means . [You]91-anne are [a girl of the people]2225-a girl of the people , who has had to take care of [herself]91-anne not [a fine young lady]2226-a fine young lady , as yet , thank [God]138-god , with all the fine names which [fine folk]2227-fine folk have for nasty things . [You]91-anne know what marriage means . It means being [a man]248-a man s chattel , more than [his]248-a man beast of burden , [his]248-a man plaything , the toy of [his]248-a man caprice and sensuality . It means , also , that [you]91-anne must smother all love for [a worthier man]2229-a worthier man , or degrade [yourself]91-anne in [your]91-anne own eyes . Will [you]91-anne be this , sell [yourself]91-anne thus ? "[166-richard brown]

" [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin does not wish [me]327-the girl to degrade [myself]327-the girl , "[327-the girl] cried [the girl]327-the girl . " [He]93-hamlin respects [me]327-the girl , yes , [he]93-hamlin does ; and [you]166-richard brown [you]166-richard brown don t ! "[327-the girl] " [He]93-hamlin respects [you]327-the girl ! "[166-richard brown] sneered [Brown]166-richard brown . " And [he]93-hamlin does not want to degrade [you]327-the girl . Of course , [he]93-hamlin s [a respectable , highly moral man]2230-a respectable , highly moral man . But , upon [my]166-richard brown soul , [I]166-richard brown would rather [you]327-the girl had been seduced by [a man [you]327-the girl loved]2231-a man you loved , than that [you]327-the girl should have sold [yourself]327-the girl coldly in this way . "[166-richard brown]

[Anne]91-anne felt [herself]91-anne choking . For a moment [she]91-anne could not utter a word . Then suddenly ,

with a strange look in [her]91-anne eyes , [she]91-anne cried , in a tone which smote [[her]91-anne cousin]1100-her cousin on the mouth

" [I]91-anne love [him]2231-a man you loved ! "[91-anne] [Brown]91-anne turned and looked [her]91-anne in the face . [She]91-anne was very flushed , and [her]91-anne slate?grey eyes gleamed feverishly . But [her]91-anne face was calm , and [she]91-anne returned [his]1100-her cousin taunting gaze , which sought for the proof that [she]91-anne lied , with a look of irrepressible contempt . " [I]91-anne love [him]2231-a man you loved ! "[91-anne] [she]91-anne repeated . [Brown]91-anne took [his]1100-her cousin hat . " Good?bye , "[1100-her cousin] [he]1100-her cousin said , stretching out [his]1100-her cousin hand ; " [I]1100-her cousin left the choice in [your]91-anne hands , and [you]91-anne have chosen . Then [I]1100-her cousin shall go . Goodbye . [I]1100-her cousin wish [you]91-anne joy of [your]91-anne choice "[1100-her cousin] [he]1100-her cousin paused " [you]91-anne mercenary thing ! "[91-anne] [Anne]91-anne did not move .

[Richard Brown]166-richard brown had already turned the handle of the door when [he]1100-her cousin stopped . " One thing more , "[1100-her cousin] [he]1100-her cousin said , " which [I]1100-her cousin desire [you]91-anne[1100-her cousin]

to know . [You]91-anne have taken care of [yourself]91-anne hitherto , and [you]91-anne are prudent enough in all conscience , and world?wise enough , and heartless enough , to do so in future ; so this piece of information may be of use to [you]91-anne . To?morrow [he]1100-her cousin will sign a paper , which [I]0-i shall keep till [you]91-anne come of age , declaring that , although [he]1100-her cousin leaves [you]91-anne complete freedom in the choice of [a husband]2207-a husband , [he]1100-her cousin binds [himself]1100-her cousin to marry [you]91-anne whenever [you]91-anne may call upon [him]1100-her cousin to do so . [You]91-anne will doubtless know how to turn this to profit . Good?bye . "[91-anne]

[Anne]91-anne sank into a chair , excited , exhausted , all [her]91-anne blood in movement , [she]91-anne scarcely knew why insulted , maligned , and yet with a great sense of joyfulness in [her]91-anne heart .

BOOK III .

CHAPTER I.

A MONTH later , [the little Perrys]400-the little perrys were being taken for [their]400-the little perrys walk in [the Boboli Gardens]1103-the boboli gardens by [a Swiss bonne in a quilted cap]1104-a swiss bonne in a quilted cap ; and [Anne Brown]91-anne was unpacking [her]91-anne things in [a room overlooking [the yellowish?green Rhine]57-the rhine , with [its]57-the rhine oscillating bridge of [boats]1106-boats]1105-a room overlooking the yellowish?green rhine , with its oscillating bridge of boats , and facing [the rocks and bastions of [Ehrenbreitstein]53-ehrenbreitstein]1107-the rocks and bastions of ehrenbreitstein .

When [Richard Brown]166-richard brown had returned to [England]41-england with the signed documents in [his]166-richard brown pocket , [Hamlin]93-hamlin had immediately written two letters , one to [[his]93-hamlin lawyers]1108-his lawyers , instructing [them]1108-his lawyers to settle the capital of five hundred a?year , that is to say , one quarter of [[his]93-hamlin property]1109-his property , on [Anne Brown]91-anne ; the other , narrating the history of [his]93-hamlin engagement if engagement it might be called , to [the widow of [[his]93-hamlin former tutor]1111-his former tutor]1110-the widow of his former tutor , and asking

[her]1110-the widow of his former tutor to admit [the young lady in whom [he]93-hamlin was interested into [[her]1110-the widow of his former tutor school at [Coblenz]54-coblenz]1113-her school at coblenz]1112-the young lady in whom he was interested into her school at coblenz . It was the Easter holidays , and [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson had taken advantage of the fact to come to [Florence]5-florence in order to take back [[her]174-mrs simson pupil]1114-her pupil [herself]174-mrs simson .

There was still a fortnight before [the school]1115-the school would reopen , so [Hamlin]93-hamlin suggested that [they]1116-they should slowly travel north , and it was settled that [he]93-hamlin should accompany [the schoolmistress]1117-the schoolmistress and [[his]93-hamlin ward]1014-his ward . The greater part of that fortnight was spent at [Venice]55-venice , where [Anne Brown]91-anne had never been , and [Hamlin]93-hamlin parted company from [them]1116-they to return to [England]41-england , only at [Munich]56-munich .

[Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson was of that particular type of Englishwoman which , however much it may marry , always seems to remain [an old maid]1119-an old maid ; but [an old maid whose old?maidishness is an incapacity of feeling any difference of age between [herself]174-mrs simson and [[her]174-mrs simson youngers]1121-her youngers , of maintaining any stateliness of superior age and experience : a hopeful , believing , shrewd , happy?go?lucky , enthusiastic creature , invariably making

[one]368-one think of [a remarkably good?natured old grey mare]1123-a remarkably good?natured old grey mare]1120-an old maid whose old?maidishness is an incapacity of feeling any difference of age between herself and her youngers , of maintaining any stateliness of superior age and experience : a hopeful , believing , shrewd , happy?go?lucky , enthusiastic creature , invariably making one think of a remarkably good?natured old grey mare . Youth was the greatest attraction in [the world]241-the world to [her]174-mrs simson , and [she]174-mrs simson identified [herself]174-mrs simson completely with [the young women that came under [her]174-mrs simson influence]1125-the young women that came under her influence . [Hamlin]93-hamlin had known [her]174-mrs simson in [his]93-hamlin boyish days , and lately , passing along [the Rhine]57-the rhine , had stayed with [her]174-mrs simson for a day or two in [[her]174-mrs simson old?fashioned house]1126-her old?fashioned house by [the confluence of [the Rhine]57-the rhine and [the Mosel]58-the mosel]1127-the confluence of the rhine and the mosel . The impression that [this school]1128-this school was so utterly unlike [any of [the girls schools [he]93-hamlin had read of in novels]1130-the girls schools he had read of in novels]1129-any of the girls schools he had read of in novels ; the impression that [a young woman]325-a young woman might develop there into whatever pleasant thing nature intended , had been so strong , that from the moment of [his]93-hamlin first contemplating a possible marriage with [the Perrys servant]1013-the perrys servant , [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson and [[her]174-mrs simson school at [Coblenz]54-coblenz]1113-her school at coblenz had formed an essential part of [his]93-hamlin plans . [The lady]1731-the lady , on the other hand , was exactly [the kind of woman to whom a situation like this would appeal]1135-the kind of woman to whom a situation like this would appeal : [Hamlin]93-hamlin , whom [she]1731-the lady had entertained on buns and ginger?beer , and then , in later years , raved over after the first sonnet which [he]93-hamlin sent to

[the Athen?um]1136-the athen?um , had always been [her]1731-the lady especial object of adoration ; and [his]93-hamlin adoption of [a beautiful and strange young woman]1137-a beautiful and strange young woman , [his]93-hamlin preparation of [a bride]1138-a bride for [himself]93-hamlin , was for [her]1731-the lady the finishing touch to [his]93-hamlin perfection . [She]1731-the lady would indeed have preferred had [Anne Brown]91-anne been small and fair , and garrulous and impish , and shown a love for mathematics and flirtation ; but , nevertheless , [Anne Brown]91-anne , inasmuch as [she]91-anne was the elect of [Walter Hamlin]93-hamlin , and inasmuch as [she]91-anne was [a beautiful young creature]1139-a beautiful young creature , immediately won the facile but not fickle heart of [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson . The whole business seemed to [her]1731-the lady as natural as possible ; and it was [she]1731-the lady who proposed that [Hamlin]93-hamlin should accompany [her]1731-the lady and [[his]93-hamlin ward]1014-his ward part of [their]1141-their way northwards .

What was [Anne]91-anne s own condition ? During those hours in [the train]829-the train , when [Hamlin]93-hamlin was for ever jumping out and overwhelming [them]1141-their with coffee and stale cakes and newspapers at [every station]1143-every station ; during those days at [Venice]55-venice , when [they]1141-their stayed at [the same hotel]1144-the same hotel [the headwaiter]1145-the headwaiter quite spontaneously wrote " [Mrs[1145-the headwaiter]

Sim]175-mrs sim ?

[son

Simson]1146-son simson

and [niece]1147-niece " in the strangers book , and spent [their]1141-their days in [picture?galleries]2233-picture?galleries and [churches]2234-churches and gondolas , and [their]1141-their evenings at [theatres]2235-theatres , during all that journey [Anne]91-anne was as cold , and silent , and melancholy as [she]91-anne had been when first [they]1141-their had met at [the Villa Arnolfini]2-the villa arnolfini ; indeed [any man]2236-any man but [Hamlin]93-hamlin , and [any woman]2237-any woman except [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson , would probably have been disheartened and disgusted by this apparent stolidity of behaviour . But [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson had already made up [her]174-mrs simson character of [Anne Brown]91-anne , and fallen in love with it quite independent of realities ; and [Hamlin]93-hamlin was rather pleased that the creature whom [he]93-hamlin was going to teach how to think and how to feel , did not manifest any particular mode of thinking and feeling of [her]961-the poor girl own . So [they]1141-their were both extremely assiduous to [Anne Brown]91-anne , and in reality thought much more about what [she]961-the poor girl was going to be than about what [she]961-the poor girl actually was .[1147-niece]

The fact was that [the poor girl]961-the poor girl was in a dazed condition that all this journey seemed

to [her]961-the poor girl unreal , and all the things around [her]961-the poor girl unsubstantial . [Her]961-the poor girl head felt hollow , [she]961-the poor girl seemed to be informed about [her]961-the poor girl feelings rather than to experience them , [her]961-the poor girl own words sounded as if through a whispering?gallery . A couple of weeks ago [she]961-the poor girl had had so strong a consciousness of identity and existence , of [her]961-the poor girl own desires and hopes ; now [she]961-the poor girl could not well understand how [she]961-the poor girl came to be where [she]961-the poor girl was . Sometimes , while mechanically talking with [[her]961-the poor girl companions]1149-her companions or walking in [their]1149-her companions company , [she]961-the poor girl used to ask [herself]961-the poor girl how it had all come about , and then [she]961-the poor girl could see no reason for it all ; it seemed accidental , inexplicable , causeless , and almost incredible . Whenever , on the other hand , [she]961-the poor girl awakened to the reality of things , [she]961-the poor girl was depressed by a sense of transition ; [she]961-the poor girl was afraid of speaking , and almost of feeling . As long as [she]961-the poor girl had been [the Perrys servant]1013-the perrys servant , [she]961-the poor girl had experienced no shyness with [Hamlin]93-hamlin ; as far as [her]961-the poor girl taciturn nature would allow , [she]961-the poor girl had spoken out whatever [she]961-the poor girl had thought or

felt , without considering whether or not it might surprise , annoy , or amuse [him]93-hamlin . Now , on the contrary , [she]961-the poor girl gradually became conscious of a fear lest [Hamlin]93-hamlin should have cheated [himself]93-hamlin in choosing [her]961-the poor girl . Unable to tell any one of this feeling , [she]961-the poor girl let it overshadow [her]961-the poor girl . One evening at [Munich]56-munich , two or three days before [they]1151-they parted company with [Hamlin]93-hamlin , [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson , coming into [[Anne]91-anne s room]1152-anne s room , found [the girl]327-the girl seated with [her]327-the girl head in the pillows of [her]327-the girl bed , sobbing .

The excellent and somewhat romantic heart of [the schoolmistress]1117-the schoolmistress immediately melted at this sight . " [[My]174-mrs simson dear child]2238-my dear child , "[174-mrs simson] [she]174-mrs simson cried , looking more than ever like [a friendly grey old mare]1155-a friendly grey old mare , " what is the matter with [you]2238-my dear child ? "[174-mrs simson] But [Anne]91-anne merely buried [her]91-anne head deeper in the pillows , and sobbed harder than before . " What is the matter ? "[176-mrs sireson] repeated [Mrs Sireson]176-mrs sireson , laying [her]176-mrs sireson hand on [Anne]91-anne s shoulder . " Oh , leave [me]327-the girl , leave [me]327-the girl ! "[327-the girl] moaned [the girl]327-the girl .

[Mrs Simpson]177-mrs simpson gently passed [her]177-mrs simpson arm under

[the prostrate girl]1157-the prostrate girl s breast , and lifted [her]1157-the prostrate girl up from the bed .

" What is the matter with [you]2238-my dear child , [[my]177-mrs simpson dear]2056-my dear ? "[177-mrs simpson] [she]177-mrs simpson asked . " Nothing nothing , "[91-anne] sobbed [Anne]91-anne , trying to hide [her]91-anne cried?out eyes with [her]91-anne hands . " Nonsense ; nothing ! "[174-mrs simson] said [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson , briskly . " [You]2238-my dear child are unhappy about something , [[you]2238-my dear child poor little thing]2240-you poor little thing . "[174-mrs simson] [Girls]1158-girls , and especially [girls in distress]1159-girls in distress , invariably appeared little to [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson , even when , like [Anne Brown]91-anne , [they]1158-girls overtopped [her]174-mrs simson by a good head . " Something is the matter with [you]2238-my dear child , "[174-mrs simson] [she]174-mrs simson insisted . " Now just let [us]2241-us see together what it may be ; "[174-mrs simson] and [she]174-mrs simson made [the reluctant girl]1160-the reluctant girl sit down by [her]174-mrs simson side on the sofa . " Are [you]2238-my dear child homesick ? do [you]2238-my dear child feel very strange , [poor dearie]2242-poor dearie , with [strange people]2243-strange people ? are [you]2238-my dear child frightened a little by the sudden change in [your]2238-my dear child life ? it s very natural , [[my]174-mrs simson dear little girl]2244-my dear little girl , but [you]2238-my dear child ll get over it soon . "[174-mrs simson]

[Anne]91-anne shook [her]91-anne head . But the

impossibil ?

ity

impossibility

of making [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson understand what depressed [her]174-mrs simson , sent the sobs once more into [her]174-mrs simson voice .

" No , no , "[174-mrs simson] [she]174-mrs simson said ; " oh no , no [you]174-mrs simson can t understand . [I]174-mrs simson don t feel lonely [I]174-mrs simson don t feel unhappy but it s only because [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin "[174-mrs simson] " Because [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin is going away , [[my]174-mrs simson dear]2056-my dear ? "[174-mrs simson] [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson smiled as [she]174-mrs simson kissed [Anne]91-anne on the crisp iron?black hair , for [the girl]327-the girl would not loosen [her]174-mrs simson hands from [her]174-mrs simson face " Because [he]93-hamlin is going away ? That s very natural too ; but it won t be for long , [dearest]2246-dearest . "[174-mrs simson] [Anne]91-anne broke loose from [her]174-mrs simson embrace . " It s not that ! it s not that ! "[174-mrs simson] [she]174-mrs simson sobbed ; " please go away [you]91-anne can t understand it s not that ! Oh no , [I]174-mrs simson shall be glad when [he]93-hamlin be gone away ! "[174-mrs simson] [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson rose . At first [she]174-mrs simson felt pained , disgusted ; but [her]174-mrs simson frigidness melted with the speedy reflection that [girls]1158-girls don t know what the matter is with [them]1158-girls in such cases .

" Good?bye , [dear]2200-dear , "[174-mrs simson] [she]174-mrs simson said ; " [I]174-mrs simson shall send [you]2200-dear up some tea in a few minutes ; that will set [you]2200-dear all right . But don t fret because[174-mrs simson]

[Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin is going . [You]91-anne will see [him]93-hamlin soon again . "[93-hamlin]

" [I]91-anne shall be glad when [he]93-hamlin is gone ! "[91-anne] repeated [Anne]91-anne , in a paroxysm of grief . It was not a mere foolish , hysterical falsehood . It was a real relief when , one morning at [Frankfurt]59-frankfurt , [Hamlin]93-hamlin was standing on [the platform of [the station]1164-the station]1163-the platform of the station , speaking to [them]1165-them at the door of [[their]1165-them carriage]1166-their carriage . [The guard]1167-the guard came to slam the door . " Good?bye , [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " [Good?bye]178-good?bye , [Miss Brown]91-anne . "[93-hamlin] " Good?bye , [sir]1717-sir , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne answered , extending [her]91-anne hand . [He]93-hamlin kissed it hurriedly . The door was slammed . [The train]829-the train moved on slowly , and [Hamlin]93-hamlin walked along [its]829-the train side . Gradually it went quicker and quicker , and [Anne Brown]91-anne saw [Hamlin]93-hamlin for a minute on [the platform]1169-the platform ; [he]93-hamlin was pale , but radiant . [He]93-hamlin waved [his]93-hamlin hand .

" [A rivederci]2249-a rivederci ! "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin cried , waving [his]93-hamlin hat .

A pillar of [the station]1164-the station hid [him]93-hamlin . [Anne]91-anne turned away from the window and opened a

book which [he]93-hamlin had given [her]91-anne . [She]91-anne read so assiduously all that day , that poor [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson , who was [a sociable woman]1171-a sociable woman , resorted , in sheer despair , to talking with [the other travellers]1172-the other travellers , who stared in puzzled surprise at [the tall girl with the melancholy pale face and masses of crimp black hair who sat opposite [her]91-anne]1173-the tall girl with the melancholy pale face and masses of crimp black hair who sat opposite her .

When [they]1174-they had got out of [the train]829-the train , rattled over the round stones of [Coblenz]54-coblenz , and were finally following [the obstreperously welcoming cook]1176-the obstreperously welcoming cook and [housemaid]1177-housemaid up the stairs of [[Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson s house]1178-mrs simson s house , [Anne]91-anne felt relieved . And when [she]91-anne had been left alone in [[her]91-anne room]1179-her room , [she]91-anne felt a weight off [her]91-anne . When [she]91-anne had taken some things out of [her]91-anne box , [she]91-anne went to the window . The last flare of sunset was on the marblelike brownish?green swirls of [the Rhine]57-the rhine ; and filaments of reddish gold streaked the sky above [Ehrenbreitstein]53-ehrenbreitstein , whose windows gleamed crimson . [A steamer]1180-a steamer was puffing and whistling by [the wharf]1181-the wharf ; the trumpets of the rappel shrieked through [the streets]1937-the streets and were reechoed from [the opposite shore]1183-the opposite shore . From inside

[the house]254-the house rose the sound of a piano ; [some one]1185-some one was playing [Bach]179-bach s " Mein glÎ£ubiges Herz . "[1185-some one]

It was the beginning of a new life . [Anne Brown]91-anne left the window , hung [her]91-anne clothes in [the wardrobe]1186-the wardrobe , folded [her]91-anne linen in the drawers . Then [she]91-anne took from [her]91-anne trunk a framed photograph of [Hamlin]93-hamlin , and stuck it on [her]91-anne dressing?table ; [he]93-hamlin was very handsome , with [his]93-hamlin straight , keen?featured , almost beardless Norman face and waves of light hair : [she]91-anne looked at it long . Then [she]91-anne dived to the bottom of [her]91-anne trunk and brought out two little books ; the " Petrarch "[91-anne] [he]93-hamlin had given [her]91-anne at [Lucca]8-lucca , and the volume of [his]93-hamlin own poems . [She]91-anne sat down by the open window and began reading them , and glancing at the redness dying away from river and sky . [She]91-anne felt very solemn and happy . " [I]91-anne must become worthy of [him]93-hamlin , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne thought .

CHAPTER II .

LIFE was monotonous enough at [[Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson s at [Coblenz]54-coblenz]1187-mrs simson s at coblenz ; but it was a kind of monotony which to [Anne Brown]91-anne was positively exciting . It was for [her]91-anne a process of absorption into another class of life ; and as such , represented a daily influx of new ideas and habits , a daily surprise , effort , and adjustment . By virtue of [her]91-anne half?Italian nature , [Anne]91-anne required but little to make [her]91-anne , in education and manners , [a lady]1783-a lady . With [her]91-anne wide?open but rather empty mind , [her]91-anne seriousness and dignity of person , extreme simpleness , as the reverse of complexity of character , it was wholly unnecessary that [she]91-anne should unlearn anything , or even that [she]91-anne should absorb anything absolutely new ; the only thing was to fill up the magnificent design

which already existed in [her]91-anne . [No one]1744-no one ever required to say to [Anne]91-anne , " [You]91-anne must not do , or think , or say such or such a thing . "[1744-no one] [She]91-anne surprised [people]322-people only by [her]91-anne timidity , [her]91-anne silence , [her]91-anne passiveness , and by a sort of haughtiness which accompanied [them]322-people strangely enough ; a certain solemn , and , at the same time , abrupt way of judging of things and treating [people]322-people , and which was the mental counterpart of [her]91-anne look , gait , nay , even of the folds which [her]91-anne dresses took on [her]91-anne . Ignorant though [she]91-anne was , [she]91-anne seemed at [her]91-anne ease with the new culture with which [she]91-anne was presented , just as , for all [her]91-anne habits of waiting on instead of being served , [she]91-anne seemed at ease in [her]91-anne behaviour . But it was difficult for [Anne]91-anne to tune [herself]91-anne or get [herself]91-anne tuned to the pitch of the everyday feelings and life of [[her]91-anne companions]1149-her companions ; [she]91-anne could not understand [these young ladies]1193-these young ladies . [The girls at [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson s]1194-the girls at mrs simson s did not exceed half?a?dozen , and [they]1194-the girls at mrs simson s were [none of [them]1194-the girls at mrs simson s [schoolgirls]1196-schoolgirls]1195-none of them schoolgirls in the ordinary sense . [They]1194-the girls at mrs simson s were , like [Anne]91-anne , [eccentrically placed young women]1197-eccentrically placed young women ; [orphans]1198-orphans , or [girls

whose parents]1199-girls whose parents were in [the colonies]1200-the colonies , or [girls who could not get on at [home]1995-home]1201-girls who could not get on at home , [girls]1158-girls , all of [them]1194-the girls at mrs simson s , with a certain pretension to superiority , and a great habit of independence , which was fostered by [the schoolmistress]1117-the schoolmistress , whose theory was that [women]1795-women could not possibly be left too much to [their]1795-women own devices .

[Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson was very fond of preaching this gospel of higher education , to the great scandal of [the respectable German matrons whom [she]174-mrs simson visited]1206-the respectable german matrons whom she visited . " [Narrow?minded , vicious creatures]2250-narrow?minded , vicious creatures , "[174-mrs simson] [she]174-mrs simson used to say , who shook [their]1194-the girls at mrs simson s heads at [the young ladies attending public lectures , walking about by [themselves]1194-the girls at mrs simson s , and flirting in the most stalwart and open manner quite unsentimental and unwomanly , said [the Germans]1208-the germans with [the Prussian officers]1209-the prussian officers]1207-the young ladies attending public lectures , walking about by themselves , and flirting in the most stalwart and open manner quite unsentimental and unwomanly , said the germans with the prussian officers . [Of [these girls]1211-these girls two were [orphans]1198-orphans , and had been sent to [Coblenz]54-coblenz as a convenient riddance by [[their]1210-of these girls two were orphans , and had been sent to coblenz as a convenient riddance by their guardians guardians]1213-their guardians]1210-of these girls two were orphans , and had been sent to coblenz as a convenient riddance by their guardians ; [one]368-one had been deposited in [Europe]43-europe by [[her]368-one parents]1215-her parents , to be called for when educated , and shipped off to [New Zealand]60-new zealand ; [one , a huge damsel approaching thirty]1216-one , a huge damsel approaching thirty , was studying eye ?

surgery with [a famous Rhenish oculist]1217-a famous rhenish oculist ; [the fifth]1218-the fifth was going to [Girton]61-girton and was studying German ; [the sixth]1219-the sixth had found [[her]1219-the sixth home]1220-her home too much for [her]1219-the sixth , and was perpetually complaining of the hardness of [her]1219-the sixth fate and the viciousness of [her]1219-the sixth own character , aspiring to impossible ideals of knowledge and usefulness and self?sacrifice , and spending [her]1219-the sixth leisure making up frocks in which to disport [herself]1219-the sixth at the garrison balls .

Each of [them]1221-them studied whatsoever [she]1219-the sixth thought fit : [Greek and Latin professors]1222-greek and latin professors , [piano and singing masters]1223-piano and singing masters , [German governesses]1224-german governesses , were perpetually going in and out of [the house]254-the house ; [the girls]1226-the girls were continually running to lectures on botany or physiology or comparative philology , where [the youth of [the town]599-the town]1227-the youth of the town eyed [the Sch ne EnglÎ£nderinnen]180-the sch ne englÏnderinnen with rapture , sending [them]1226-the girls anonymous bouquets and verses , and bringing [them]1226-the girls serenades , and even , to poor [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson s horror , slipping love?letters of the most burning description into the door?hinges . Among [these girls]1211-these girls poor [Anne]91-anne would have felt utterly lost , had [she]91-anne not been accustomed for years to be

[her]91-anne own sole company , letting [her]91-anne life brush by that of [other folk]438-other folk , without ever mixing . It seemed to [her]91-anne quite natural to exchange one kind of isolation for another : to drudge on at improving [her]91-anne own mind as [she]91-anne had formerly drudged on at mending the clothes and making the beds of [the little Perrys]400-the little perrys , interesting [herself]91-anne as little in , and awakening as little interest among , [[her]91-anne companions]1149-her companions as [she]91-anne had done among [[her]91-anne fellow?servants in [Italy]1-italy]1233-her fellow?servants in italy . [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson had received full instructions from [Hamlin]93-hamlin as to all the things which [she]91-anne was and was not to teach or have taught to [[his]93-hamlin ward]1014-his ward ; and [Anne]91-anne would have been perfectly satisfied with working for [her]91-anne French and [German masters]1235-german masters , preparing [her]91-anne lessons of geography and history , and reading such books as [Hamlin]93-hamlin would send [her]91-anne , but [the other girls]1236-the other girls were not at all so minded .

[Anne Brown]91-anne s arrival created a tremendous sensation in [[Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson s establishment]1237-mrs simson s establishment . [Her]91-anne strange kind of beauty , which did not strike [the conventional spectator]1238-the conventional spectator as being beauty

at all , excluding , as it did , fairness , rosiness , youthfulness , daintiness , liveliness , voluptuousness , sentimentalness , or any of the orthodox ingredients of female charm , [her]91-anne wholly unlike?everyone?else appearance , [her]91-anne silence , sullenness , haughtiness , all took [the girls]1226-the girls by surprise . [Her]91-anne shyness , ignorance , newness in [her]91-anne position , was obvious from the very first day . The knowledge of what [she]91-anne had been and what [she]91-anne was going to be , all this romance was quickly wheedled out of [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson by [the misunderstood little girl who wished to turn [sister of mercy]1241-sister of mercy]1240-the misunderstood little girl who wished to turn sister of mercy , and carried on a simultaneous flirtation with [a lieutenant]1242-a lieutenant , [a Bonn student]1243-a bonn student , [a painter]245-a painter , and [a piano?master]1245-a piano?master ; and bullied out of [her]91-anne by [the bouncing amazon who talked about nothing but retinal impressions and optic nerves]1246-the bouncing amazon who talked about nothing but retinal impressions and optic nerves . From that moment [Anne]91-anne became a subject of intense interest at [the school]1115-the school : [most of [the girls]1226-the girls]1248-most of the girls had heard of [Hamlin]93-hamlin in [England]41-england , and [all of [them]1250-all of them]1250-all of them had heard of [him]93-hamlin from [the enthusiastic schoolmistress]1251-the enthusiastic schoolmistress . To possess in [their]1250-all of them midst [his]93-hamlin chosen one was a great privilege ,

although [they]1250-all of them sometimes made fun of [Anne]91-anne and [him]93-hamlin behind [her]91-anne back , drawing pictures of [the solemn and tragic girl dressed in the most draggled]1252-the solemn and tragic girl dressed in the most draggled ? sthetic manner , surrounded by a circle of [young]1253-young ? sthetes copied out of [Punch Bunthome]181-punch bunthome did not exist at that time holding lilies and swinging censers as [she]91-anne went . [They]1250-all of them all thought [Anne]91-anne [a strange , awe?inspiring , and , at the same time , somewhat ridiculous person]1254-a strange , awe?inspiring , and , at the same time , somewhat ridiculous person ; but [they]1250-all of them all got to like [her]91-anne , although [the misunderstood High Church flirt]1255-the misunderstood high church flirt could never be got to see why [Anne]91-anne should despise [officers]754-officers and [garrison balls]1257-garrison balls ; and [the scientific girl of twenty?eight]1258-the scientific girl of twenty?eight thought ? stheticism and ? sthetic poets idiotic and immoral ; and each of [the others]1900-the others found some reservation to make about [the Italian]1260-the italian , as [they]1250-all of them called [her]91-anne . Yet , as [I]0-i said , [they]1250-all of them did grow to like [her]91-anne ; and [Anne]91-anne , who was unaccustomed to friendliness , was so touched by the familiarity and good?nature of [[her]91-anne companions]1149-her companions , that [she]91-anne gradually began to take a great and serious interest in [their]1250-all of them concerns . [She]91-anne became quite enthusiastic about ocular

surgery , listening with scarcely any shudders to the narration of the most complicated operations ; [she]91-anne let [herself]91-anne be overwhelmed with discourses about Middle High German and Gothic , and the connection with [Sanskrit]182-sanskrit ; [she]91-anne firmly believed in the mystical fervours , the desire of self?sacrifice , the wasted passion of [the little fair?haired flirt]1262-the little fair?haired flirt , reasoning seriously about [them]1250-all of them , and trying to check what [she]91-anne believed to be a suicidal tendency ; [she]91-anne was greatly touched by the home?sickness and family squabbles of [the other girls]1236-the other girls . Not that [Anne]91-anne was [a fool]1264-a fool , or made to be [a dupe]1265-a dupe ; on the contrary , [she]91-anne saw well enough the funniness of the contrasts between [[her]91-anne friends]1266-her friends words and [their]1266-her friends life ; but [Anne]91-anne was so earnest , so simple , so homogeneous of nature , [she]91-anne was so fervent in all [her]91-anne feelings , that [she]91-anne always imagined that the serious things which [people]322-people said or affected must be the reality ; and , as in [her]91-anne own case , the levity , the frivolousness , the fickleness , must be the mere exterior clothing of social fictions . Thus [she]91-anne gave [her]91-anne sympathy wherever it was asked

for , while asking for no sympathy [herself]91-anne . [The girls]1226-the girls used often to remark upon this , and complain that for all [they]1226-the girls did , [Anne Brown]91-anne remained surrounded by a sort of moral moat , alone , isolated , impregnable in a kind of moral fortress .

CHAPTER III .

AS [Hamlin]93-hamlin had fancied , while painting [Anne]91-anne s portrait , so [the girls at [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson s]1194-the girls at mrs simson s used to fancy that there could not be much going on inside [this taciturn and undemonstrative creature]1270-this taciturn and undemonstrative creature . But it was not so . While [Anne]91-anne looked so quiet , said so little and least of all about [herself]91-anne during those two years of school , a drama nay , a whole life?poem was incessantly going on within [her]91-anne . [She]91-anne worked indefatigably at [her]91-anne lessons , read every book [she]91-anne could lay hold of , was taken to concerts , lectures , burgher tea?parties and garrison balls , and on excursions up and down [the Rhine]57-the rhine and into [the neighbouring hills]1271-the neighbouring hills ; but all this was but as an exterior life surrounding an interior one , as the movement of [the ship]1272-the ship to the movement of [the passengers]1273-the passengers on [its]1272-the ship deck .

The real life was not with [these girls]1211-these girls and [these teachers]1275-these teachers , but with [Hamlin]93-hamlin ; not in [this Rhineland town]1276-this rhineland town , but in [the distant places where [he]93-hamlin travelled]1277-the distant places where he travelled . [He]93-hamlin wrote to [her]91-anne very often , from [London]3-london , from [Italy]1-italy , from [Greece]62-greece and [Egypt]34-egypt , and wherever [he]93-hamlin roamed about . At first [she]91-anne was surprised by the frequency of [his]93-hamlin letters ; then [she]91-anne became accustomed to it as to a necessity of [her]91-anne existence , but a necessity to which [she]91-anne had no right . It seemed to [her]91-anne wonderful that [he]93-hamlin should write so often , and yet that the time which elapsed between [his]93-hamlin letters should be intolerable . In [her]91-anne great desire for [them]1278-them [she]91-anne used to have recourse to all manner of unconscious sophistications . [She]91-anne tried to train [herself]91-anne to disappointment , to chastise [her]91-anne own impatience and greediness , saying to [herself]91-anne , on the days when [she]91-anne thought that a letter might come , " It is impossible that there should be one to?day , "[91-anne] although [her]91-anne heart fell when the prophecy sometimes came true ; and [she]91-anne stayed up?stairs , [her]91-anne eyes pinned to [her]91-anne book ,

when [she]91-anne heard the postman s ring at the door , although that ring put [her]91-anne all into a tremble , and made [her]91-anne feel faint when [she]91-anne heard it . Thus with the letters from [him]93-hamlin . It was almost worse about [her]91-anne own answers . Often [she]91-anne could stand it no longer , and would begin a letter to [Hamlin]93-hamlin only a few lines , which might be finished when [his]93-hamlin next letter should be received . The few lines turned to pages ; yet the next day no letter would come , and [she]91-anne was unable to resist the temptation of writing even more ; then , when the long?wished letter at last came , there came with it such a number of new things to say , that [her]91-anne previous epistle must needs be torn up . Also , on re?reading what [she]91-anne had written in answer to [Hamlin]93-hamlin , [she]91-anne was often filled with shame and fear . [She]91-anne had entertained [him]93-hamlin with such trifles , or been so pedantic , or put things in such a horrid way , [she]91-anne must needs tear it up and write once more . Then the length , the frequency of [her]91-anne letters frightened [her]91-anne : [he]93-hamlin would grow weary and impatient ; [she]91-anne tried

to write briefly , but failed ; [she]91-anne tried to write rarely , making solemn resolutions to let two , three , or four days pass without answering [him]93-hamlin ; but it was not of much use . [She]91-anne was dreadfully afraid lest [Hamlin]93-hamlin should think [her]91-anne a drag upon [him]93-hamlin , lest [he]93-hamlin should write one single letter more than [he]93-hamlin would naturally have done , from goodness to [her]91-anne . [She]91-anne never told [him]93-hamlin with what tremulous expectancy [she]91-anne waited for the post ; with what heartburn [she]91-anne saw it come empty?handed ; with what avidity [she]91-anne read [his]93-hamlin letters , re?read them furtively by snatches , carried them about in [her]91-anne pocket , made them last over days , till [she]91-anne knew them by heart , and , even then , how [she]91-anne was for ever doing up and undoing again the packet in which [she]91-anne kept them : if [he]93-hamlin knew that , [he]93-hamlin might feel obliged , being so kind , to write oftener ; and that must not be .

[Any one who had seen these letters which were [her]91-anne soul s food]1279-any one who had seen these letters which were her soul s food , would have been surprised how they could awaken such a longing , how they could produce such emotion and

keep alive such passion . In accordance with [his]93-hamlin whole plan of proceedings , [Hamlin]93-hamlin never once wrote to [Anne]91-anne as if there were any question of [her]91-anne ever becoming [[his]93-hamlin wife]459-his wife . " [[My]1281-they dear]2056-my dear [Miss Brown]91-anne , "[1281-they] [they]1281-they all ceremoniously began , and ended off " [Yours]91-anne sincerely , "[1281-they] or " [[Your]91-anne sincere friend]2252-your sincere friend , [Walter Hamlin]93-hamlin . "[1281-they] Affectionate [they]1281-they were , and even adoring , in the sense of looking up , or affecting to look up , at [her]91-anne as [a sort of superhuman and wonderful creature]1282-a sort of superhuman and wonderful creature , not quite conscious of its wonderfulness , perhaps , and certainly not responsible for it ; the mental attitude of [an artist]446-an artist before [a beautiful model]1284-a beautiful model , of [some Italian medieval poet]1285-some italian medieval poet before [a Platonic mistress]1286-a platonic mistress . There was not much perception of the reality of [Anne Brown]91-anne s personality , nor indeed of [her]91-anne having any personality at all , being a thing with feelings , thoughts , hopes , interests of [her]91-anne own . Sometimes even [poor Anne]91-anne felt , on reading [his]1287-his letters , as if a lump of ice had been laid on [her]91-anne heart , when [she]91-anne came upon certain sentences ; [she]91-anne could scarcely tell [you]1288-you why , but

those sentences made [her]91-anne feel numb and alone , like a wrecked sailor at [the north pole]1289-the north pole , for days . Then a reaction came ; a burning indignation with [herself]91-anne , a burning adoration of [Hamlin]93-hamlin . [She]91-anne felt as if [she]91-anne had done [him]1287-his some injury ; and once or twice , amid tears of shame , [she]91-anne wrote that [she]91-anne had become unworthy of [his]1287-his friendship why , [she]91-anne could not well explain . But [she]91-anne tore it all up , or left only dim hints which [Hamlin]93-hamlin misunderstood , and became more respectful and adoring than ever , imagining that [he]1287-his must have said something to slight [her]91-anne . [He]1287-his really was adoring ; it was such a lovely Madonna this , that it seemed to [him]1287-his that all the most beautiful and precious things of [his]1287-his mind , and [other men]1290-other men s minds , must be heaped up before [her]91-anne , like offerings of flowers , and rich ointments , and jewels , and music . [He]1287-his copied out pages of poetry and prose in [his]1287-his letters , and wrote to [her]91-anne the most lovely descriptions of things [he]1287-his saw or things [he]1287-his felt . Whenever [he]1287-his recollected a fine poem , or saw a beautiful scene ,

or was struck by a beautiful thought or a happy expression , [he]1287-his hastened to offer it to [Anne]91-anne , as [the kings of [the East]42-the east]1291-the kings of the east offered gold and frankincense and embroidered raiment to [the little Christ]1292-the little christ . That this was the result of [his]1287-his love , [she]91-anne never thought ; for [she]91-anne never ventured to think that [he]1287-his condescended , or even would ever condescend , to love [her]91-anne ; but it was in [her]91-anne eyes the result of [his]1287-his greatness , [his]1287-his generosity , the largesse , as it were , of [his]1287-his sublimity . About [himself]1287-his [Hamlin]93-hamlin would also write a great , great deal . Of singularly delicate mental fibre , and somewhat weak will , [he]1287-his was for ever tormented or pretending to [himself]1287-his to be tormented , for to be so was pretty well a matter of choice by unattainable ideals , by conflicts in [his]1287-his own nature : mysterious temptations of unspeakable things , beckoning [his]1287-his nobler nature into the mud , which [he]1287-his never at all specified , but which moved [Anne]91-anne to agonies of grief and admiration . [The poor girl]961-the poor girl , not understanding how such things will shoot up in the poetic mind as a result of mere

reading , and be nurtured there for a day for the sake of [their]1294-their strange colour , would screw up all [her]961-the poor girl might to help [him]1287-his , writing to [him]1287-his to be patient , to be strong and bold , to remember the nobility of [his]1287-his nature , strange passionately earnest entreaties written in tears , or in moods like those which send [people]322-people to the stake ; and which , in [their]1294-their ludicrous disproportionateness to [their]1294-their cause , would bring the tears to almost [any one s eyes who should read them]1296-any one s eyes who should read them .

A strange correspondence ; and of which [Hamlin]93-hamlin s half , although beautiful with all manner of artistic prettinesses , would have struck one as the less beautiful and interesting part : the suppressed passionateness , unconscious of itself , of [the girl]327-the girl s letters , [her]327-the girl mixture of prim literary daintiness , absorbed from [her]327-the girl reading , and of homely , tragically?hurled?about imagery [Hamlin]93-hamlin used , without revealing [the author]1298-the author , to read out some of these metaphors of [Anne]91-anne s to [[his]93-hamlin friends]658-his friends , pointing out [their]658-his friends Elizabethan , Webster?like character , were much

more really striking . But [Anne]91-anne thought that what [she]91-anne wrote was unworthy to be seen by [Hamlin]93-hamlin ; [his]93-hamlin condescension was mere goodness .

[Hamlin]93-hamlin , indeed , was very good to [her]91-anne very gentle , courteous , generous , and assiduous . There was scarcely a book read by [Anne Brown]91-anne which was not of [his]93-hamlin selecting ; and even in the midst of [his]93-hamlin journeys [he]93-hamlin used to elaborately select things for [her]91-anne reading , cutting out all but a very few pieces out of books of poetry , and copying and pasting into them all manner of extracts . " [I]93-hamlin should be grieved to think that anything save the very best should ever be read by [you]91-anne , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin often wrote . Thus , in the most singular way , [Anne]91-anne , [only a nursemaid a few months before]1300-only a nursemaid a few months before , became more deeply versed in poetry and poetical and picturesque history than [most girls]1301-most girls ; Greek lyrism , Oriental mysticism , French ? stheticism , but above all , things medieval and pseudo?medieval ; imbued with the imagery and sentiment of that strange eclectic school of [our]1302-our days which [we]1302-our still call pre?Raphaelite . And

such an education , while putting [her]91-anne in complete harmony with [Hamlin]93-hamlin s aspirations and habits , also brought home to [her]91-anne the merit of [Hamlin]93-hamlin s own work . Of [his]93-hamlin pictures , [she]91-anne had , indeed , only vague recollections , besides the little sketches , wonderful jewel?coloured things , full of poetic suggestion , which [he]93-hamlin would send [her]91-anne at Christmas and on [her]91-anne birthday , to the amazement of [the whole school]1303-the whole school . But [he]93-hamlin sent [her]91-anne a good deal of [his]93-hamlin poetry , and that only of the best . [She]91-anne did not always understand exactly the things to which [he]93-hamlin alluded , seeing only the beauty , the vague passionate wistfulness , the delicate sadness of what [he]93-hamlin wrote . [His]93-hamlin greatness perfectly confounded [her]91-anne . [She]91-anne found allusions to it in everything : in reading of [dead poets]1304-dead poets , of [Shelley]183-shelley , [Keats]184-keats , [Goethe]185-goethe , a kind of passionate interest thrilled through [her]91-anne , for [she]91-anne seemed to be reading about [Hamlin]93-hamlin . And the same held good as to [artists]1305-artists ; [they]1305-artists were all [[his]93-hamlin kinsmen]1306-his kinsmen , of [his]93-hamlin blood nay , [they]1305-artists all , in a mystic manner , foreshadowed [him]93-hamlin .

Of these matters [she]91-anne never spoke to [any of [the girls]1226-the girls]1307-any of the girls . But often , while walking with [them]1305-artists , [her]91-anne pride would swell with the thought that [she]91-anne belonged to [him]93-hamlin that [he]93-hamlin had chosen [her]91-anne . And when [the New Zealander , who was musical and had a fine voice]1309-the new zealander , who was musical and had a fine voice , used sometimes to sing [Schumann]186-schumann s song , " Er der herrlichste von allen , "[93-hamlin] the words and the music sent a flood of love and pride to [her]91-anne heart ; it was [he]93-hamlin , " [he]93-hamlin the most glorious of all , "[93-hamlin] who was thus gracious and good to [her]91-anne .

CHAPTER IV .

THUS one year went by ; and then , slowly , another , while [Anne Brown]91-anne was being transformed from [a nursemaid]364-a nursemaid into [a lady]1783-a lady . [Hamlin]93-hamlin saw [her]91-anne twice during that time . Once , while [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson and [Anne]91-anne were staying in [Paris]26-paris for [he]93-hamlin had begged that [her]91-anne holidays might be spent either in [Switzerland]63-switzerland , or in some place where [she]91-anne might see pictures and statues when [he]93-hamlin suddenly turned up for a day on [his]93-hamlin way from [England]41-england to [Greece]62-greece ; and once at [Coblenz]54-coblenz . [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson was giving a party : suddenly into [the parlour]1312-the parlour , filled with [German matrons and [damsels , with a sprinkling of professors]1314-damsels , with a sprinkling of professors and [soldiers]1315-soldiers]1313-german matrons and damsels , with a sprinkling of professors and soldiers , was introduced [a slight , fair man]1316-a slight , fair man , who looked very young till [you]1317-you saw [him]1316-a slight , fair man closely , and at whose sight [that

sombre , quiet , strange , half?Italian girl]1318-that sombre , quiet , strange , half?italian girl had suddenly turned crimson , and clutched a chair , as if afraid to fall , while [the company]1319-the company stared and whispered . [Hamlin]93-hamlin left that same evening ; and as the day in [Paris]26-paris had been spent in seeing and talking about pictures , so this afternoon passed in trifling conversation at [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson s table . Alone , [Anne]91-anne scarcely saw [him]93-hamlin for an instant . Only , when [he]93-hamlin left [Coblenz]54-coblenz , [he]93-hamlin seized [her]91-anne hand as [he]93-hamlin stood at the door , and kissed it fervently . It seemed to [her]91-anne , during the long months of absence , that [she]91-anne would give all [her]91-anne life to see [him]93-hamlin again , to be able to tell [him]93-hamlin how grateful [she]91-anne was to [him]93-hamlin . Yet , in reality , [his]93-hamlin presence passed like the picture of a magic?lantern on a wall ; and [she]91-anne felt as if [her]91-anne lips were glued together : it was a vision , and no more . But on that second visit [Hamlin]93-hamlin had been dazzled . [He]93-hamlin had recognised from the first the exotic beauty and strangeness of [the Perrys servant]1013-the perrys servant ; [he]93-hamlin had seen in [Paris]26-paris that [his]93-hamlin judgment had been correct ; but when , after eighteen months of schooling , [he]93-hamlin

suddenly saw [Anne]91-anne again , it was as if [he]93-hamlin had never seen [her]91-anne before , a fresh revelation . A year and a half of [a lady]1783-a lady s life , without bodily fatigue or mental weariness , had developed to the full [the girl]327-the girl s marvellous beauty : strange , mysterious , amazonian it was as ever ; but it was as the regalness of [a triumphant queen]1323-a triumphant queen by the side of [the queenliness of [a deposed Amazon chief]1325-a deposed amazon chief]1324-the queenliness of a deposed amazon chief . The haughtiness which had struck [him]93-hamlin in [the nursemaid of [the little Perrys]113-the little perrys]1326-the nursemaid of the little perrys , was not diminished , but softened , by a kind of quiet graciousness and goodness . [Hamlin]93-hamlin remarked that [she]91-anne seemed , now that [she]91-anne was no longer humbled and cramped , to have a much kindlier spirit and a sense of humour which had at first seemed scarcely to exist , or to exist only in bitterness . But what struck [him]93-hamlin most of all was an indefinable change in [Anne]91-anne s expression : the soul , which had lain as a tiny germ at the bottom of [her]91-anne nature , had expanded and come to the surface . [She]91-anne was as beautiful and singular as ever , but more manifold and subtle : [her]91-anne mind had increased threefold . [Hamlin]93-hamlin

went away , intending that [Anne]91-anne should remain at [Coblenz]54-coblenz another year . But [he]93-hamlin found that [his]93-hamlin patience , hitherto inexhaustible , had suddenly departed . [He]93-hamlin found the time intolerably heavy on [his]93-hamlin hands . [He]93-hamlin travelled about in [out?of?the?way countries]1327-out?of?the?way countries , having fragmentary love?affairs , in a dreamy , irresponsible way , with [other women]1328-other women ; and sending [Anne]91-anne more letters than usual , and presents of all manner of outlandish stuffs silver ornaments and so forth which used to create great excitement at [the school]1115-the school ; but [he]93-hamlin fretted with impatience . Impatience , be it well understood , not to marry [Anne]91-anne , for [he]93-hamlin always thought of marriage as the return from , the end of , a sort of spiritual honeymoon ; but impatience to commence that long courtship which had , from the beginning , been the object of [his]93-hamlin desires . [He]93-hamlin grew tired of [their]1330-their correspondence , found that [he]93-hamlin had exhausted all the delights of unconsciously revealed love , love budding and developing with [the girl]327-the girl s mind . It began to be mere repetition ; and [he]93-hamlin scarcely knew

what to write about now : the prologue had lasted long enough ; the piece must begin .

One day , some two years or so after [her]91-anne arrival at [Coblenz]54-coblenz , [Anne Brown]91-anne received a letter in which [Hamlin]93-hamlin reminded [her]91-anne that [she]91-anne was twenty?one , and that [his]93-hamlin guardianship had consequently come to an end already some months before ; and suggested that , as [he]93-hamlin heard that [her]91-anne education was now completed , at least in so far as [Coblenz]54-coblenz went , [he]93-hamlin thought that it might be wiser if [she]91-anne came to [England]41-england , where [she]91-anne would have better opportunities of continuing any special studies . Moreover , that [[his]93-hamlin aunt]1332-his aunt , [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor , [a widow without any children]1333-a widow without any children , was coming to settle in [London]3-london , and that [he]93-hamlin thought it might be a good arrangement that [she]187-mrs macgregor and [Anne]91-anne should live together , as [Anne]91-anne could scarcely take [a house]1334-a house by [herself]91-anne . What did [Miss Brown]91-anne think of this arrangement ? And would [she]187-mrs macgregor authorise [him]93-hamlin to settle everything for [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor and [her]187-mrs macgregor ? Faintly and vaguely [Anne]91-anne thanked [him]93-hamlin for [his]93-hamlin forethought , and acquiesced in

everything which [he]93-hamlin might be kind enough to decide upon . [She]91-anne had never realised [her]91-anne situation , [she]91-anne was not [the sort of mind which has clear conceptions of the future]1335-the sort of mind which has clear conceptions of the future , and [she]91-anne had been far too much absorbed , these two years , in the unreal present . Besides , [Anne]91-anne felt a confused pain , a disappointment , which prevented [her]91-anne attending to anything else . [Hamlin]93-hamlin had said nothing about [himself]93-hamlin , not a word as to whether [he]93-hamlin also would settle in [London]3-london , or whether [he]93-hamlin intended continuing [his]93-hamlin wandering life . And [she]91-anne had not the courage to ask [him]93-hamlin . [She]91-anne was conscious of a coldness and emptiness in [her]91-anne heart , of the disappointment of some vague , unspoken hope . But why feel disappointed ? or did [she]91-anne really feel disappointed at all ? [She]91-anne believed that [she]91-anne cared for [Hamlin]93-hamlin only as for [a benefactor]1336-a benefactor , [a divinity]1337-a divinity , a creature who might bestow affection but could not be asked for it ; and this being the case , and knowing [herself]91-anne to have been perfectly satisfied and happy hitherto ,

[she]91-anne persuaded [herself]91-anne that [she]91-anne really did not feel disappointed about anything , when [Hamlin]93-hamlin thus wrote about [her]91-anne education and [her]91-anne plans and nothing else .

But as the winter drew to a close , there came another letter from [Hamlin]93-hamlin all the intermediate ones had been only the usual talk about [himself]93-hamlin , and about books and scenery telling [her]91-anne that , with a view to [her]91-anne living with [[his]93-hamlin aunt]1332-his aunt , [he]93-hamlin had , as [her]91-anne ex?guardian [he]93-hamlin always spoke of [himself]93-hamlin as [[her]91-anne guardian]1065-her guardian , completely ignoring [Richard Brown]166-richard brown deemed it wise to employ part of [her]91-anne capital , which had been accumulating in [his]166-richard brown hands , in the purchase of the lease of [a house at [Hammersmith]36-hammersmith , which [he]166-richard brown was having prepared and furnished against [her]91-anne coming in May.]1340-a house at hammersmith , which he was having prepared and furnished against her coming in may. " [It]1340-a house at hammersmith , which he was having prepared and furnished against her coming in may. is in [a pretty neighbourhood]2253-a pretty neighbourhood , with [the river]2254-the river in front and [old houses]2255-old houses and [gardens]1761-gardens all round , "[166-richard brown] [he]166-richard brown wrote . " What determined [my]166-richard brown choice , as [I]166-richard brown am sure it would have determined [yours]1346-you also , is that [the house]254-the house is [itself]254-the house more than a century and a[166-richard brown]

half old , and has some fine trees in [the garden]431-the garden . Flowers seem to grow well , as it is pretty well beyond reach of smoke . There are also some fine elms and poplars in front , all along [the river?side]1342-the river?side , which is old?fashioned , and .not yet made into [a modern embankment]1343-a modern embankment . It is rather far from [the world]241-the world ; but [the world]241-the world is hideous , and the farther away from it the better , don t [you]1346-you think ? [[My]0-i aunt]2108-my aunt is busy about the practical household properties ; [I]0-i am getting in some of the more useless furniture . If [you]1346-you should dislike the arrangement , it can all be easily undone . [I]0-i hope [you]1346-you will not disapprove of this step ; [the house]254-the house is pretty well unique , and [I]0-i had to decide on taking it , unless [some one else]974-some one else was to snap it up ; otherwise [I]0-i should certainly have consulted [you]1346-you first . [I]0-i trust [you]1346-you will forgive [me]0-i . "[1346-you]

[Anne]91-anne put the letter down , and wondered whether [she]91-anne was dreaming . What was all this about buying and consulting [her]91-anne , employing [her]91-anne capital ? What capital had [she]91-anne

got ? What right to be consulted ? For a moment [she]91-anne felt quite bewildered ; and then the full consciousness of [Hamlin]93-hamlin s goodness rushed out and overwhelmed [her]91-anne , and [she]91-anne let [her]91-anne head fall on [her]91-anne desk and cried for sheer happiness . Then [she]91-anne thought it must all be a dream , and snatched the letter where it lay all crumpled , and smoothed it out trembling . Yes , there it all was . And then , as postscript , came this sentence , which made [her]91-anne heart leap :

" There are [two rooms additional on [the garden]431-the garden]2258-two rooms additional on the garden , having a separate entrance from [the embankment]2260-the embankment , and which [I]1351-the girl from new zealand think [you]1346-you will not at present require for [yourself]1346-you . Would [you]1346-you perhaps let [me]1351-the girl from new zealand rent [them]2258-two rooms additional on the garden for [a studio]990-a studio ? [[My]1351-the girl from new zealand own lodgings]2262-my own lodgings are a long way from [St John s House]64-st john s house that is [its]64-st john s house name , for [it]64-st john s house was [a priory]2263-a priory once ; but if [I]1351-the girl from new zealand had [[my]1351-the girl from new zealand workshop]2264-my workshop [there]863-there , [I]1351-the girl from new zealand might hope to see [you]91-anne almost every day , if [you]91-anne would let [me]1351-the girl from new zealand . "[1351-the girl from new zealand]

The first dinner?bell rang , and [Anne]91-anne , having hastily washed [her]91-anne eyes and smoothed [her]91-anne

hair , ran down?stairs , not knowing very well why the bell rang , or what it was all about . In [the sitting?room]1350-the sitting?room [she]91-anne found [the girl from [New Zealand]60-new zealand]1351-the girl from new zealand , [a little nervous creature , whom [she]91-anne had nursed through a bad fever , in [her]91-anne cold , absent way , and who had conceived a shy , intense passion for this beautiful strange creature , who seemed to [her]91-anne an unapproachable being from [another world]1353-another world]1352-a little nervous creature , whom she had nursed through a bad fever , in her cold , absent way , and who had conceived a shy , intense passion for this beautiful strange creature , who seemed to her an unapproachable being from another world .

" [I]91-anne am going away , "[91-anne] cried [Anne]91-anne [she]91-anne felt [she]91-anne must say it " going away from [school]862-school to [London]3-london , next month . "[91-anne] [The thin , nervous , an?mic little girl]1354-the thin , nervous , an?mic little girl turned ashy?white . " Oh , are [you]1354-the thin , nervous , an?mic little girl really going ? "[91-anne] [she]91-anne exclaimed faintly , for with [Anne]91-anne disappeared all [the poor child]1355-the poor child s sunshine and ideal from this dreary , worse than orphaned life , among [girls who had too many occupations and interests to care for [her]1354-the thin , nervous , an?mic little girl]1356-girls who had too many occupations and interests to care for her . " Are [you]1354-the thin , nervous , an?mic little girl really going , [Annie]91-anne ? . . . Oh , [I]1356-girls who had too many occupations and interests to care for her am so sorry ! "[1356-girls who had too many occupations and interests to care for her]

" Sorry ? "[91-anne] cried [Anne]91-anne ; " it is very nasty[91-anne]

of [you]1354-the thin , nervous , an?mic little girl to be sorry [I]0-i am glad ; oh , so glad ! so glad ! "[1357-the little new zealander]

[The little New Zealander]1357-the little new zealander had gone to the window , and was looking through its panes at [the rainy street]1358-the rainy street ; [she]1357-the little new zealander gave a little suppressed sob . [Anne]91-anne felt as if [she]91-anne had committed a murder . [She]91-anne ran to the window , and seized the struggling small creature in [her]91-anne powerful arms , and knelt down before [her]1357-the little new zealander , clasping [her]1357-the little new zealander round the waist . " Oh , forgive [me]91-anne ! forgive [me]91-anne ! "[91-anne] cried [Anne]91-anne , as the consciousness of [the girl]327-the girl s love , which [she]91-anne had never before perceived , came upon [her]91-anne , together with the shame and remorse at [her]91-anne heartlessness ; " forgive [me]188-the new zealander , forgive [I]188-the new zealander am [a brute a beast]2267-a brute a beast oh dear , oh dear , that happiness should make [me]188-the new zealander so wicked ! "[188-the new zealander] [The New Zealander]188-the new zealander smiled and buried [her]188-the new zealander thin yellow face in the masses of [Anne]91-anne s dark crisp hair . " Will [you]93-hamlin remember [me]188-the new zealander sometimes ? "[188-the new zealander] [she]188-the new zealander asked ; " [I]188-the new zealander love [you]93-hamlin so much . "[188-the new zealander]

[Anne]91-anne kissed the poor , pale , tear?stained cheeks . " Oh yes , [I]91-anne will always remember [you]93-hamlin , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne said . But [she]91-anne was already thinking of [Hamlin]93-hamlin .

CHAPTER V.

DURING that last month at [school]862-school [Anne]91-anne was indefatigable : in the face of the vague future which was so rapidly approaching , [she]91-anne felt bound to clutch hold of the present , thinking that time which was employed in some way went less quickly . The fact was that [she]91-anne was in a state of great excitement half impatience and half terror ; [she]91-anne wished the days to go by quicker , and [she]91-anne wished them to go by slower ; [she]91-anne was at once dragged wearisomely , and hurried along . At length it became a question no longer of weeks but of days . And then came another letter from [Hamlin]93-hamlin . [He]93-hamlin remembered the desire [she]91-anne had once expressed to go down [the Rhine]57-the rhine , to be on [the sea]2090-the sea : [he]93-hamlin proposed that [she]91-anne should come through [Belgium]65-belgium and cross from [Antwerp]66-antwerp to

[London]3-london . " [I]93-hamlin am sure [you]91-anne will enjoy it much more than the vile , vulgar , usual route , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin wrote . But [he]93-hamlin did not tell [her]91-anne that [he]93-hamlin was unwilling [she]91-anne should get any impressions of [England]41-england before meeting [him]93-hamlin , however slight they might be ; that [he]93-hamlin preferred to meet [her]91-anne , in the evening , on [the Thames wharf]1362-the thames wharf , to receiving [[his]93-hamlin Amazon Queen]1363-his amazon queen , [[his]93-hamlin mysterious and tragic Madonna]1364-his mysterious and tragic madonna , rather than in [the shed at [Victoria]67-victoria or [Charing Cross]68-charing cross]1365-the shed at victoria or charing cross . [Anne]91-anne did not care how [she]91-anne was to go : [she]91-anne was to go , to embark on a new life , to see [him]93-hamlin , to be seen by [him]93-hamlin . This thought , which had never struck [her]91-anne before , began to haunt [her]91-anne now : if [he]93-hamlin should be disgusted with [her]91-anne ? if [he]93-hamlin should recognise that [he]93-hamlin had been mistaken in [his]93-hamlin choice ?

The morning before [her]91-anne departure , [Mrs Sireson]176-mrs sireson handed [Anne]91-anne a letter at breakfast . " [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin has sent [a girl]1945-a girl to fetch [you]91-anne , [dear]2200-dear , "[176-mrs sireson] [she]176-mrs sireson said . " To fetch [me]91-anne ? "[91-anne] cried [Anne]91-anne , in astonishment .

[Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson opened the door " Pray , come in , "[174-mrs simson] [she]174-mrs simson said . [A young woman]325-a young woman entered , whose immaculate smartness and cheerful alertness never would have let one guess that [she]325-a young woman had just been travelling twenty?four hours . " This is [Miss Brown]91-anne , "[174-mrs simson] said [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson . [The girl]327-the girl curtsied , and waited for [Miss Brown]91-anne to speak . But [Anne]91-anne could not utter a word . " [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor , [[Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin s aunt]2270-mr hamlin s aunt , engaged [me]330-the young woman as [[your]91-anne travelling?maid]2271-your travelling?maid , [miss]2272-miss , "[330-the young woman] said [the young woman]330-the young woman , handing a note to [Anne]91-anne . It was from [Hamlin]93-hamlin , and ran briefly

" [[MY]330-the young woman DEAR]2056-my dear [MISS BROWN]91-anne , [[My]330-the young woman aunt]2108-my aunt is unfortunately too delicate to admit of [my]330-the young woman asking [her]2108-my aunt to fetch [you]91-anne from [Coblenz]54-coblenz ; but [she]2108-my aunt has engaged [the bearer]2275-the bearer to be [[your]91-anne maid]2276-your maid , unless [you]91-anne have some previous . choice at [Coblenz]54-coblenz , in which case , please forgive [our]2277-our interference .
