For some unaccountable reason [Anne]91-anne felt quite angry . [She]91-anne did not require [any one]1923-any one to travel with [her]91-anne ; [she]91-anne did not want [a maid]1373-a maid . [The very word maid]1374-the very word maid seemed to bring up [her]91-anne whole past .

" [You]327-the girl had better go and rest [yourself]327-the girl , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne said to [the girl]327-the girl coldly . " How sweet and considerate ! , " and as if every moment of silence were a kind of deceit . At last [she]91-anne could bear it no longer[0-i]

The next evening , among the lamentations of [[Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson s establishment]1237-mrs simson s establishment , [Anne Brown]91-anne set off for [Cologne]69-cologne . This first short scrap of journey moved [her]91-anne very much : when [the train]829-the train puffed out of [the station]1164-the station , and the familiar faces were hidden by [outhouses]1388-outhouses and [locomotives]1389-locomotives , the sense of embarking on unknown waters rushed upon [Anne]91-anne ; and when , that evening , [[her]91-anne maid]455-her maid bade [her]91-anne good night at [the hotel at [Cologne]69-cologne]1391-the hotel at cologne , offering to brush [her]91-anne hair and help [her]91-anne to undress , [she]91-anne was seized with intolerable

[home]1995-home ?

sickness

homesickness

for [the school]1115-the school , [the little room [she]91-anne had just left]1394-the little room she had just left , and [she]91-anne would have implored [any one]1923-any one to take [her]91-anne back . But the next days [she]91-anne felt quite different : the excitement of novelty kept [her]91-anne up , and almost made it seem as if all these new things were quite habitual ; for there is nothing stranger than the way in which excitement settles one in novel positions , and familiarises one with the unfamiliar . Seeing a lot of sights on the way , and knowing that a lot more remained to be seen , it was as if there were nothing beyond these three or four days as if the journey would have no end ; that an end there must be , and what that end meant seemed a thing impossible to realise . [She]91-anne scarcely began to realise it when [the ship]1272-the ship began slowly to move from [the wharf]1181-the wharf at [Antwerp]66-antwerp ; when [she]91-anne walked up and down [the deserted and darkened deck]1398-the deserted and darkened deck watching [the widening river]1399-the widening river under the clear blue spring night , lit only by a ripple of moonlight , widening mysteriously out of sight , bounded only by the shore?lights , with here or there the

white or blue or red light of [some ship]1400-some ship , and its long curl of smoke , making [you]1401-you suddenly conscious that close by was another huge moving thing , more human creatures in this solitude , till at last all was mere moonlight?permeated mist of sky and [sea]1402-sea . And only as the next day as [the boat]1403-the boat cut slowly through [the hazy , calm sea]1404-the hazy , calm sea was drawing to its close , did [Anne]91-anne begin to feel at all excited . At first , as [she]91-anne sat on [deck]1405-deck , the water , the smoke , the thrill of [the boat]1403-the boat , the people walking np and down , [the children]1713-the children wandering about among the piles of rope , and leaning over [the ship]1272-the ship s sides all these things seemed the only reality . But later , as [they]1409-they got higher up in [the Thames]70-the thames , and the unwonted English sunshine became dimmer , a strange excitement arose in [Anne]91-anne an excitement more physical than mental , which , with every movement of [the boat]1403-the boat , made [her]91-anne heart beat faster and faster , till it seemed as if it must burst , and a lot of smaller hearts to start up and throb all over [her]91-anne body , tighter and tighter , till [she]91-anne had to press [her]91-anne

hand to [her]91-anne chest , and sit down gasping on a bench .

The afternoon was drawing to a close , and [the river]2254-the river had narrowed ; all around were rows of [wharves]1412-wharves and groups of [ships]1413-ships ; [the men]1414-the men began to tug at the ropes . [They]1414-the men were in [the great city]1415-the great city . The light grew fainter , and the starlight mingled with the dull smoke?grey of [London]3-london ; all about were the sad grey outlines of [the old houses on [the wharves]1417-the wharves]1416-the old houses on the wharves , [the water]1088-the water grey and the sky also , with only a faint storm?red where the sun had set . The rigging , interwoven against the sky , was grey also ; the brownish sail of [some nearer boat]1419-some nearer boat , the dull red sides of [some steamer hard by]1420-some steamer hard by , the only colour . [The ship]1272-the ship began to slacken speed and to turn , great puffs and pants of the engine running through its fibres ; [the sailors]1422-the sailors began to halloo , [the people]639-the people around to collect [their]639-the people luggage : [they]639-the people were getting alongside of [the wharf]1181-the wharf . [Anne]91-anne felt [the maid]1376-the maid throw a shawl round [her]91-anne ; heard [her]1376-the maid voice , as if from a great distance , saying , " There s [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin , [miss]2272-miss ; "[1376-the maid] felt [herself]91-anne

walk ?

ing

walking

along as if in a dream ; and as if in a dream a figure come up and take [her]91-anne hand , and slip [her]91-anne arm through [his]1426-his , and [she]91-anne knew [herself]91-anne to be standing on [the wharf]1181-the wharf , in the twilight , the breeze blowing in [her]91-anne face , all [the people]639-the people jostling and shouting around [her]91-anne . Then a voice said " [I]93-hamlin fear [you]91-anne must be very tired , [Miss Brown]91-anne . "[93-hamlin] It was at once so familiar and so strange that it made [her]91-anne start ; the dream seemed dispelled . [She]91-anne was in reality , and [Hamlin]93-hamlin was really by [her]91-anne side .

BOOK IV .

CHAPTER I.

IT is sad to think how little even the most fervently loving among [us]1429-we are able to reproduce , to keep within recollection , the reality of [the absent beloved]1430-the absent beloved ; certain as [we]1429-we seem to be , living as appears the phantom which [we]1429-we have cherished , [we]1429-we yet always find , on the day of meeting , that [the loved person]1431-the loved person is different from the simulacrum which [we]1429-we have carried in [our]1429-we hearts . As [Anne Brown]91-anne sat in [the carriage]582-the carriage which was carrying [her]91-anne to [[her]91-anne new home]1433-her new home , the feeling which was strongest in [her]91-anne was , not joy to see [Hamlin]93-hamlin again , nor fear at entering on this new phase of existence , but a recurring shock of surprise at the voice which was speaking to [her]91-anne , the voice which [she]91-anne now recognised as that of [the real Hamlin]1434-the real hamlin , but

which was so undefinably different from the voice which had haunted [her]91-anne throughout those months of absence . [Hamlin]93-hamlin was seated by [her]91-anne side , [the maid]1376-the maid opposite . [The carriage]582-the carriage drove quickly through a network of [dark streets]1437-dark streets , and then , on , on , along [miles of embankment]1438-miles of embankment . It was a beautiful spring night , and the mists and fogs which hung over [river]1439-river and [town]593-town were soaked with moonlight , turned into a pale?blue luminous haze , starred with the yellow specks of gas , broken into , here and there , by the yellow sheen from [some open hall?door or lit windows of [a party?giving house]1442-a party?giving house]1441-some open hall?door or lit windows of a party?giving house : out of the faint blueness emerged the unsubstantial outlines of things bushes , and overhanging tree?branches , and distant spectral towers and belfries .

" [You]91-anne must be very tired , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " Oh no , "[91-anne] answered [Anne]91-anne , that repeated revelation of the real voice still startling [her]91-anne " not at all . "[93-hamlin]

[He]93-hamlin asked [her]91-anne how [she]91-anne had left those at [Coblenz]54-coblenz , and about [her]91-anne journey ; [she]91-anne had to

tell [him]93-hamlin about every picture and church [she]91-anne had seen at [Cologne]69-cologne , [Brussels]71-brussels , [Bruges]72-bruges , and [Antwerp]66-antwerp . It is strange how people whose hearts have seemed full to bursting with things [they]1443-they have so long been waiting to say , will talk , when [they]1443-they meet again , like [persons introduced for the first time at a dinner?party]1444-persons introduced for the first time at a dinner?party . On [they]1443-they rolled , and on , through the pale moonlight mist by [the river]2254-the river .

" [I]93-hamlin hope , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin , when [they]1443-they had done discussing [Van Eyck]191-van eyck , and [Rubens]73-rubens , and [Memling]192-memling " [I]93-hamlin hope [you]91-anne will like [the house]254-the house and the way [I]93-hamlin have had [it]254-the house arranged ; and , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin added , " [I]93-hamlin hope [you]91-anne will like [[my]93-hamlin aunt]2108-my aunt . [She]2108-my aunt is rather misanthropic , but it is only on the surface . "[93-hamlin]

[[His]93-hamlin aunt]1332-his aunt ! [Anne]91-anne had forgotten all about [her]1332-his aunt ; and [her]91-anne heart sank within [her]91-anne as [the carriage]582-the carriage at last drew up in front of some garden railings . [The house]254-the house door was thrown open , and a stream of yellow light flooded [the strip of garden]1449-the strip of garden and the railings . [Hamlin]93-hamlin gave [Anne]91-anne [his]93-hamlin arm ; [the maid]1376-the maid followed . [A

woman?servant]1451-a woman?servant was holding the door open , and raising a lamp above [her]1451-a woman?servant . [Anne]91-anne bent [her]91-anne head , feeling that [she]91-anne was being scrutinised . [She]91-anne walked speechless , leaning on [Hamlin]93-hamlin s arm , and those steps seemed to [her]91-anne endless . It was all very strange and wonderful . [Her]91-anne step was muffled in thick , dark carpets ; all about , the walls of [the narrow passage]1452-the narrow passage were covered with tapestries , and here and there came a gleam of brass or a sheen of dim mirror under the subdued light of some sort of Eastern lamp , which hung , with yellow sheen of metal discs and tassels , from the ceiling . Thus up the narrow carpeted and tapestried stairs , and into [a large dim room]1453-a large dim room , with strange?looking things all about . Some red embers sent a crimson flicker over the carpet ; by the tall fireplace was a table with a shaded lamp , and at it was seated [a tall , slender woman , with the figure of [a young girl]1455-a young girl , but whose face , when [Anne]91-anne saw it , was parched and hollowed out , and surrounded by grey hair]1454-a tall , slender woman , with the figure of a young girl , but whose face , when anne saw it , was parched and hollowed out , and surrounded by grey hair .

" This is [Miss Brown]91-anne , [Aunt Claudia]193-aunt claudia , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin . [The old lady]920-the old lady rose , advanced , and kissed [Anne]91-anne frigidly on both cheeks . " [I]920-the old lady am glad to see [you]91-anne , [[my]920-the old lady dear]2056-my dear , "[920-the old lady] [she]920-the old lady said , in a tone which was neither cold nor insincere , but simply and utterly indifferent . [Anne]91-anne sat down . There was a moment s silence , and [she]91-anne felt [the old lady]920-the old lady s eyes upon [her]91-anne , and felt that [Hamlin]93-hamlin was looking at [[his]93-hamlin aunt]1332-his aunt , as much as to say , " Well , what do [you]920-the old lady think of [her]1332-his aunt ? "[93-hamlin] and [she]91-anne shrank into [herself]91-anne . " [You]920-the old lady have had a bad passage , doubtless , "[187-mrs macgregor] said [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor after a moment , vaguely and dreamily . " Oh no , "[91-anne] answered [Anne]91-anne , faintly , " not at all bad , thank [you]93-hamlin . "[91-anne] " So much the better , "[920-the old lady] went on [the old lady]920-the old lady , absently . " Ring for some tea , [Walter]93-hamlin . "[93-hamlin] [Hamlin]93-hamlin rang . In a moment tea?things were brought . [Hamlin]93-hamlin handed a cup to [Anne]91-anne , and offered [her]91-anne some cake .

" It is a long drive , "[187-mrs macgregor] said [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor

" a long drive all the way from [Charing Cross]68-charing cross . "[187-mrs macgregor]

" [Miss Brown]91-anne came by [the Antwerp boat St Catherine s Wharf]2293-the antwerp boat st catherine s wharf in [the City]2294-the city , [aunt]2295-aunt , "[93-hamlin] corrected [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " Ah , yes , to be sure perhaps [she]91-anne would like some more milk in [her]91-anne tea . There is always such a delay at [Charing Cross]68-charing cross , isn t there , [Walter]93-hamlin ? "[93-hamlin] But while [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor s mind and words seemed to ramble vaguely about , [her]187-mrs macgregor eyes were fixed upon [Anne]91-anne large , melancholy dark eyes . " [You]91-anne are glad to be back in [London]3-london , aren t [you]91-anne ? "[187-mrs macgregor] [she]187-mrs macgregor asked . " This is the first time [I]91-anne am in [England]41-england , "[91-anne] answered [Anne]91-anne , shyly ; all [this dim room]1460-this dim room , with [its]1460-this dim room vague sense of beautiful things all round , [this absent?minded lady]1461-this absent?minded lady , all seemed to harmonise with [her]1461-this absent?minded lady own dreamlike sensations . " [Miss Brown]91-anne was born in [Italy]1-italy , "[93-hamlin] explained [Hamlin]93-hamlin , probably for the hundredth time .

" Oh yes , of course ; how stupid [I]93-hamlin am ! And ,[93-hamlin]

" All right , "[93-hamlin] interrupted [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " Won t [you]187-mrs macgregor have another cup , [Margaret]195-margaret ? "[187-mrs macgregor] asked [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor . "[194-chough] Thus [they]1464-they went on for another half?hour ; [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor calling [Anne]91-anne by one wrong name after another , alluding to things which [she]187-mrs macgregor could not possibly know anything about , and [Hamlin]93-hamlin trying to set matters right and induce [Anne]91-anne to talk . " It is getting late , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said , " and [I]93-hamlin fear [Miss Brown]91-anne must be tired after [her]91-anne long journey . [I]93-hamlin think [you]187-mrs macgregor had better not keep [her]91-anne up any longer , [aunt]2295-aunt . "[93-hamlin] " [I]91-anne am not tired , "[91-anne] protested [Anne]91-anne . " [You]91-anne will be tired to?morrow , "[920-the old lady] said [the old lady]920-the old lady .

" Yes , "[93-hamlin] added [Hamlin]93-hamlin , " and [I]93-hamlin must go . Good?bye , [aunt]2295-aunt . Good night , [Miss Brown]91-anne ; [I]93-hamlin hope [you]187-mrs macgregor will have good dreams to welcome [you]187-mrs macgregor home to [England]41-england . " Good night , [buon riposo e sogni felici]2299-buon riposo e sogni felici . "[93-hamlin]

The few words of [Italian]197-italian almost brought the tears to [Anne]91-anne s eyes ; [she]91-anne felt so strange here , so far from everything and yet what had [she]91-anne left behind ? nothing , and [no one who loved [her]91-anne]1466-no one who loved her , except [that little girl from [New Zealand]60-new zealand]1467-that little girl from new zealand . [She]91-anne felt terribly alone in [the world]241-the world . [Hamlin]93-hamlin had evidently not trusted to [[his]93-hamlin aunt]1332-his aunt to send [Anne]91-anne to bed , for [the maid]1376-the maid came in uncalled , and asked whether [Miss Brown]91-anne would not like to go up to [[her]91-anne room]1179-her room .

" Of course , "[1376-the maid] said [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor ; and taking a heavy old?fashioned silver candlestick , [she]1376-the maid led [Anne]91-anne to [[her]91-anne room]1179-her room . [The poor girl]961-the poor girl was too weary and dazed to see what it was like . [She]91-anne sank on to a chair , and

passively let [the maid]1376-the maid take off [her]1376-the maid hat and cloak .

" Shall [I]1376-the maid undress [you]91-anne , [ma am]2300-ma am ? "[1376-the maid] [she]1376-the maid asked . [Anne]91-anne shook [her]91-anne head . " No , thanks . "[91-anne] [The girl]327-the girl retired , but [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor remained standing by [Anne]91-anne s side , looking at the reflection in the glass of [her]91-anne pale , sad , tired face . " Undo [your]91-anne hair , [[Eliza]114-monna lisa dear]2301-eliza dear , "[187-mrs macgregor] said [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor . [Anne]91-anne mechanically pulled out the hair?pins , and the masses of iron?black crisp hair fell over [her]91-anne shoulders . [The old lady]920-the old lady looked at [her]91-anne for a moment . " [You]91-anne are [a beautiful girl]2302-a beautiful girl , [Anne]91-anne , "[920-the old lady] [she]920-the old lady said , at last hitting the right name , " and , "[920-the old lady] [she]920-the old lady added , with a curious compassionate look , as [she]920-the old lady kissed [the girl]327-the girl s forehead , " are [you]91-anne really in love with [Watty]124-watty ? "[920-the old lady] [Anne]91-anne did not answer ; but [she]91-anne felt [herself]91-anne redden .

" Marriage without love is a terrible thing , "[920-the old lady] said [the old lady]920-the old lady , " and in so far love is a mitigation of evil ; but at the best it is only[920-the old lady]

delusion . [People]322-people must marry , but it is the misfortune of [their]322-people lives . Good night , [[my]0-i dear]2056-my dear . "[2056-my dear]

The words went on in [Anne]91-anne s head , but [she]91-anne was too worn out to understand them . [She]91-anne soon fell asleep , and dreamed that [Melton Perry]94-perry had painted a picture , and that in a storm [the ship s crew]1481-the ship s crew said it must be used as [a raft]1482-a raft ; and somehow it all took place at [Florence]5-florence , in [the large pond in [the Boboli Gardens]1103-the boboli gardens]1483-the large pond in the boboli gardens .

CHAPTER II .

[ANNE BROWN]91-anne awoke with a vague sense of gladness , but no very clear notion of where [she]91-anne was . Then it came upon [her]91-anne that this was [[Hamlin]93-hamlin s house]1485-hamlin s house , that [she]91-anne would actually see [him]93-hamlin again in a few hours ; for it was as if [she]91-anne had not seen [him]93-hamlin at all the previous evening . The sun was streaming through the blinds , filling [the room]319-the room with a yellowish light ; from without came a sound of leaves , of twittering birds , and the plash of the steamer?paddles in [the river]2254-the river . [Anne]91-anne looked round [her]91-anne and wondered . [She]91-anne had never seen such [a room as this]1488-a room as this in [her]91-anne life : the wails were all panelled white , except where the panelling was interrupted by expanses of pale?yellow chintz ; the furniture also was of old?fashioned chintz ; the

mirror was like what [she]91-anne had seen in the illustrations to an old copy of [Sir Charles Grandison]198-sir charles grandison which had belonged to [Miss Curzon]120-miss curzon ; the tapered chairs and tables to match . There were blue?and?white jars and pots all about , and old?fashioned china things on the dressing?table : except for the fac?similes of drawings by [Mantegna]199-mantegna and [Botticelli]200-botticelli , and the coloured copies of famous Italian pictures which dotted the walls , [the room]319-the room might have been untouched since the days of the first [Georges]201-georges . [She]91-anne remembered that [Hamlin]93-hamlin had told [her]91-anne that [the house]254-the house was an old one ; but [she]91-anne could not understand how everything came to look so very spick and span and new . [She]91-anne got up and went to the window . Below , in [the little garden]1491-the little garden , was a lilac?tree bursting into flower , and a yellow laburnum . [A milkman]1492-a milkman s cart was drawn up before the door . In front were the trees , in tender leaf , and [the wooden parapet of [the river?walk]1494-the river?walk]1493-the wooden parapet of the river?walk ; then [the Thames]70-the thames , still wide , but so different from what [she]91-anne had seen it the previous evening : [a clear grey stream

reflecting green banks]1495-a clear grey stream reflecting green banks and cloudy blue sky , with here and there [a barge or boat]1496-a barge or boat moored by [the shore]1497-the shore . The sky was blue , but covered with moist clouds , and it seemed to [Anne]91-anne that [she]91-anne could almost see where it arose on the horizon , so low did it seem . There was a scent of recent rain in the air , a shimmer of moisture on the leaves and grass . Was this [[London]3-london , which [she]91-anne had always fancied so noisy , and grimy , and vulgarly new]1498-london , which she had always fancied so noisy , and grimy , and vulgarly new ?

[Anne]91-anne was already half dressed ; but [she]91-anne spent some time wondering which of [her]91-anne frocks [she]91-anne should put on : they had been made expressly for [London]3-london , and greatly admired by [the girls at [Coblenz]54-coblenz]1499-the girls at coblenz , but now one looked more absurd and frumpish than the other . At last [she]91-anne put on a sort of greyish?blue tweed , such as were then worn on [the Continent]75-the continent , and having looked at [herself]91-anne rather anxiously in the glass , [she]91-anne opened [her]91-anne door and hesitatingly went out into [the passage]316-the passage . All was perfectly quiet as [she]91-anne went down [the carpeted stairs]1501-the carpeted stairs , wondering at the tapestry and brazen wrought shields and

plaster casts and curious weapons which covered [its]3-london walls ; [she]91-anne could hear only the ticking of the old clock , which stood in its tall inlaid case in [the hall]297-the hall . After the bustle of [girls]1158-girls and [[servants]1780-servants at [the Coblenz school]1506-the coblenz school]1505-servants at the coblenz school , and the hundred and one noises of screeching well?pulleys , whirring buckets , whistling starlings , singing and chattering [servants]1780-servants , clattering crockery , which greet [the early riser in [an Italian house]1509-an italian house]1508-the early riser in an italian house , this silence seemed to [her]91-anne almost eerie , and [she]91-anne wandered about over [the noiseless floors]1510-the noiseless floors like [the knight in [the palace of the sleeping beauty]1512-the palace of the sleeping beauty]1511-the knight in the palace of the sleeping beauty . [She]91-anne found [her]91-anne way into [the drawing?room]1513-the drawing?room , where [she]91-anne had been received the previous evening ; there was another next to [it]1513-the drawing?room , and [a kind of little library beyond]1514-a kind of little library beyond . [It]1515-it was , indeed , [an enchanted palace]1516-an enchanted palace ; the walls were all hung with pictures and drawings , and pieces of precious embroidery , and burnished oriental plates , and the floors spread with oriental carpets and matting , which gave out a faint , drowsy , sweet scent . The curious furniture was covered with old brocade and embroidery ,

and in all corners , on brackets and tables and in cabinets , were all manner of wonderful glass and china , and strange ivory and inlaid Japanese toys . There were flowers , also , about everywhere , and palms in the windows . In [the library]1517-the library were more books than [Anne]91-anne had almost ever seen ; and in [the chief drawing?room]1518-the chief drawing?room a beautiful grand piano , not made like those of [our]1519-our days , but with slight straight legs and a yellow case painted with faded?looking flowers . [Anne]91-anne looked at everything with astonishment and awe : it was like [the rooms in [Walter Crane]202-walter crane s fairy books , with their inlaid chests and brocade couches]1520-the rooms in walter crane s fairy books , with their inlaid chests and brocade couches , and majolica vases full of peacocks feathers .

It took [her]91-anne a long time to take it all in . [She]91-anne stole to the piano , opened it gently , and played the accompaniment of a song of Carissimi s , which [Hamlin]93-hamlin was fond of , but inaudibly , without letting [her]91-anne fingers press down the keys . Then [she]91-anne looked at everything once more . [She]91-anne was beginning to get familiarised with the pictures on the wall ; the pale , delicate

bits of landscape ; the deep?coloured pictures of [ladies]1957-ladies in wonderful jewel?like robes , with mysterious landscapes behind [them]1957-ladies ; the drawings of strange , beautiful , emaciated , cruel?looking creatures , [men]1522-men or [women , with wicked lips and combed?out locks]1523-women , with wicked lips and combed?out locks , all these things , which were like so many points of interrogation when the door opened and [the maid]1376-the maid appeared .

" [I]1376-the maid have been looking for [you]91-anne everywhere , [miss]2272-miss , "[1376-the maid] [she]1376-the maid said . " [I]1376-the maid thought , as [you]91-anne didn t answer when [I]1376-the maid knocked , that [you]91-anne must still be asleep , so [I]1376-the maid carried [your]91-anne tea down again . [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor is going to have breakfast now , and says , would [you]91-anne mind having it in [[her]187-mrs macgregor room]1179-her room with [her]187-mrs macgregor , [miss]2272-miss , as [she]187-mrs macgregor never goes down till lunch ? "[1376-the maid] [Anne]91-anne followed [the servant]1525-the servant to [[Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor s room]1526-mrs macgregor s room , where [she]91-anne found [the old lady]920-the old lady in [her]920-the old lady dressing?gown , before a table spread with eighteenth?century china , or what to [Anne]91-anne seemed such .

" What an hour [you]91-anne do get up at , [Charlotte]203-charlotte ! "[187-mrs macgregor]

!

said [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor , kissing [Anne]91-anne on both cheeks . " [We]2306-we never think of getting up[187-mrs macgregor]

here before half?past nine . [Walter]93-hamlin never comes in till luncheon?time , because [he]93-hamlin has so far to come , and is up so late every night . Turn round ; let [me]0-i see what [you]91-anne look like this morning . "[0-i]

And [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor made [Anne]91-anne turn round slowly . [She]187-mrs macgregor looked at [her]91-anne approvingly .

" [You]91-anne re [a handsome girl]2307-a handsome girl , certainly , "[187-mrs macgregor] [she]187-mrs macgregor said ; " not the style that used to be admired in [my]187-mrs macgregor time , "[187-mrs macgregor] and [she]187-mrs macgregor smiled with the faint smile of [an old belle]1528-an old belle , " [girls]1158-girls had to be slight , and fair , and with little features then . But [you]91-anne re just what [they]1158-girls like now . [I]187-mrs macgregor m thankful at least that [Walter]93-hamlin has not brought [home]1995-home a bag of bones like the other beauties of [his]93-hamlin set . Loveliness in decay , that s what [I]187-mrs macgregor call [their]1158-girls style ; but [you]91-anne look [a good flesh?and?blood girl]2310-a good flesh?and?blood girl . "[187-mrs macgregor]

[Anne]91-anne did not know what to answer ; [she]91-anne poured [herself]91-anne out a cup of tea in silence , and vaguely ate some bread and butter . [The old lady]920-the old lady was good?natured , garrulous , flighty ; but yet , beneath the shiftiness of [her]920-the old lady exterior , there seemed to be something real , something

sad and bitter , when [you]1530-you looked at [her]920-the old lady thin drawn mouth and melancholy eyes .

" That s a pretty frock [you]91-anne have on , [[my]920-the old lady dear]2056-my dear , "[920-the old lady] [she]920-the old lady pursued , " and [I]920-the old lady think it very becoming . But [you]91-anne ll see that [Watty]124-watty won t like it . [He]124-watty s quite the what do [you]91-anne call it ? medieval sort of thing , no stays , and no petticoats , and slashings , and tags and boot?laces in the sleeves , and a yard of [draggled train]2312-draggled train that sort of thing . Oh , [you]91-anne ll find it [a queer world]2313-a queer world , [the world of [[Watty]124-watty s friends]2315-watty s friends]2314-the world of watty s friends . Do [you]91-anne ever see [Punch]181-punch bunthome ? That s the sort of thing . [They]2316-they re all great beauties and [great painters]2317-great painters and [great poets]2318-great poets , [every man and [woman of them]2320-woman of them]2319-every man and woman of them . Wait till [you]91-anne see [little Chough]194-chough and [young Posthlethwaite]204-young posthlethwaite [I]920-the old lady forget [his]124-watty real name . Ah , well , it s perhaps better , after all , this kind of fooling , and masquerading , and writing verses about things [people]322-people would horsewhip [a man]248-a man for saying in prose ; it s perhaps better , after all , for [Watty]124-watty , than the sort of life which [we]2323-we led when [he]124-watty was young "[920-the old lady] and [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor became suddenly very silent .

After breakfast [Anne]91-anne was free until luncheon?time , as [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor proceeded to lie down on [her]187-mrs macgregor sofa and read [Leigh Hunt]205-leigh hunt s Religion of the Heart , or [Fox]206-fox s Religious Ideas , which [Anne]91-anne saw lying on [her]91-anne table . [[Hamlin]93-hamlin s aunt]1531-hamlin s aunt had evidently been an esprit fort in [her]1531-hamlin s aunt youth , and possessed in [[her]1531-hamlin s aunt bedroom]1532-her bedroom a whole library of what were once deemed [literary firebrands]1533-literary firebrands , but might nowadays be described as mild , old?fashioned free?thinking literature . [Anne]91-anne roamed about [the drawing?room]1513-the drawing?room once more , looking again and again at the pictures , and opening the books , as [people]322-people do in [a strange house]1536-a strange house , before [they]322-people can settle down . [She]91-anne timidly also opened the piano , but shut it again after a minute . Then [she]91-anne took a volume of [Jean Paul]207-jean paul out of a shelf , and carried it up into [[her]91-anne room]1179-her room . Finding it too dull to read , and with an irritating sense that [she]91-anne ought to be doing something definite , [she]91-anne wrote a letter to [Mrs Simson]174-mrs simson , and one to [the little New Zealander]1357-the little new zealander . [She]91-anne felt so much like a fish out of water that [Coblenz]54-coblenz seemed more than [[her]91-anne

birthplace]1539-her birthplace , and [the people there]1540-the people there more than [mother]1541-mother and [sisters]768-sisters . At last [she]91-anne heard one o clock strike , and soon after there came a knock at [the house?door]1543-the house?door , and running to the window [she]91-anne saw [Hamlin]93-hamlin standing on the doorstep . [She]91-anne withdrew [her]91-anne head quickly , and went down to meet [him]93-hamlin .

[He]93-hamlin was more respectful than ever , asked [her]91-anne how [she]91-anne had slept , and what [she]91-anne thought of [the house]254-the house . " It s lovely , "[91-anne] said [Anne]91-anne , " and it is so nice having everything old about one . "[91-anne] " Everything old ? "[93-hamlin] asked [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " Yes ; all the hangings , and chairs , and tables , and mirrors , are of the time of the building of [the house]254-the house , aren t [they]2325-they ? "[93-hamlin] " Oh goodness , no , "[93-hamlin] answered [Hamlin]93-hamlin , sadly ; " [I]93-hamlin only wish [they]2325-they were . [They]2325-they re bran?new , every stick of them . [Everybody]2326-everybody has [them]2325-they now ; [nobody]2327-nobody makes anything except imitation old?world things . "[93-hamlin]

" Why don t [they]2325-they try and make something good and new something out of [their]2325-they own[93-hamlin]

heads , as [the old workmen]1545-the old workmen did ? " asked [Anne]91-anne , looking with wonder upon these new things which seemed so old .[1545-the old workmen]

" There is nothing to nourish art nowadays , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin , seating [himself]93-hamlin opposite [her]91-anne and looking [her]91-anne full in the face as [he]93-hamlin used to do long ago at [the studio in [Florence]5-florence]1546-the studio in florence . " Art can t live where life is trivial and aimless and hideous . [We]2328-we can only pick up the broken fragments of the past and blunderingly set them together . "[93-hamlin] " But why should the life of [to?day]76-to?day be trivial and aimless and hideous ? "[91-anne] asked [Anne]91-anne , a vague remembrance of things which [she]91-anne had heard [[her]91-anne father]1966-her father say years ago about progress and modern achievements returning to [her]91-anne mind as it had never done when , in the letters which [he]93-hamlin used to write to [her]91-anne at [Coblenz]54-coblenz , [Hamlin]93-hamlin had said before what [he]93-hamlin was saying now . " [I]93-hamlin don t know why it should be , "[93-hamlin] replied [Hamlin]93-hamlin , " but so it is . "[93-hamlin]

" Can t [we]2329-us prevent it ? "[91-anne] asked [Anne]91-anne , scarcely thinking of what [she]91-anne was saying ; conscious

only that [she]91-anne was really once more in [his]93-hamlin presence .

[Hamlin]93-hamlin shook [his]93-hamlin head sadly . " Why can not [we]2329-us revive those ? "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said , pointing to a bunch of delicate pale?pink roses , which drooped withered in a Venetian glass . " What is dead is dead . The only thing that remains for [[us]2329-us late comers]2330-us late comers to do is to pick up the faded petals and keep them , discoloured as they are , to scent [our]2329-us lives . [The world]241-the world is getting uglier and uglier outside [us]2329-us ; [we]2329-us must , out of the materials bequeathed to [us]2329-us by [former generations]2332-former generations , and with the help of [our]2329-us own fancy , build for [ourselves]2329-us [a little world within [the world]241-the world]2333-a little world within the world , a world of beauty , where [we]2329-us may live with [[our]2329-us friends]2335-our friends and keep alive whatever small sense of beauty and nobility still remains to [us]2329-us , that it may not get utterly lost , and [those who come after [us]2329-us]2336-those who come after us may not be in a wilderness of sordid sights and sordid feelings . [Ours]2329-us is not the mission of [the poets and artists of former days]2337-the poets and artists of former days ; it is humbler , sadder , but equally necessary . "[93-hamlin]

" Oh , but [you]93-hamlin must not say that ! "[91-anne] cried

[Anne]91-anne . " What [you]93-hamlin do will last , don t [you]93-hamlin know , like the things which [people]322-people were able to do formerly . "[91-anne]

[Hamlin]93-hamlin shook [his]93-hamlin head , and remained for some time with [his]93-hamlin beautiful greenish?blue eyes fixed on [Anne]91-anne , as [she]91-anne sat twisting and untwisting the fringe on the arm of [her]91-anne chair . " There is one consolation , [Miss Brown]91-anne , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin , rising from [his]93-hamlin chair and leaning against the chimney?piece , all covered with Japanese cups and curious nick?nacks , and not taking [his]93-hamlin eyes off [her]91-anne , " and that is , that even now , Nature , which is so barren of [painters]2339-painters and [poets]2340-poets , can produce creatures as wonderful as those who inspired [the painters and poets of former times]2341-the painters and poets of former times a consolation , and at the same time a source of despair . "[93-hamlin] [Hamlin]93-hamlin spoke these lover?like words in a tone so cold , so sad , that [Anne]91-anne did not at first understand to whom [he]93-hamlin was alluding , and looked up rather in interrogation than in embarrassment . A bell rang . " There s lunch , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " [We]2342-we must finish [our]2342-we discussion afterwards . "[93-hamlin]

CHAPTER III .

" WON T [you]93-hamlin take [her]91-anne out for a drive , [Walter]93-hamlin ? "[187-mrs macgregor] asked [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor , after lunch . " [She]91-anne must be curious to see something of [London]3-london . "[187-mrs macgregor]

[Hamlin]93-hamlin looked at [Anne]91-anne , as much as to say , " Do [you]91-anne really wish to go ? "[93-hamlin] " [I]93-hamlin am sure [Miss Brown]91-anne is too tired from [her]91-anne journey , [aunt]2295-aunt , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said ; " and what is there to take [her]91-anne to see in [this beastly city]2344-this beastly city ? "[93-hamlin] " [I]187-mrs macgregor thought [we]2345-we might have a brougham and take [her]91-anne to see [a few of [[your]93-hamlin friends]2347-your friends]2346-a few of your friends , [Walter]93-hamlin , "[187-mrs macgregor] suggested [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor . [Poor Anne]208-poor anne felt a sort of horror go all down [her]208-poor anne . " Oh , please don t ! "[208-poor anne] [she]208-poor anne cried " not to?day ; don t take [me]93-hamlin to see [any one]1923-any one , please . "[93-hamlin] " It s much wiser to let [her]91-anne rest , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin , in a tone of annoyance .

" Won t [you]93-hamlin just take [the poor girl]961-the poor girl to [Mrs Argiropoulo]209-mrs argiropoulo s , [Watty]124-watty ? "[1332-his aunt] insisted [[his]93-hamlin aunt]1332-his aunt . " It s a sin to keep [her]91-anne mewed up at [Hammersmith]36-hammersmith all day ; and [you]93-hamlin know [Mrs Argiropoulo]209-mrs argiropoulo was so anxious to see [her]91-anne at once . "[1332-his aunt] " Confound [Mrs Argiropoulo]209-mrs argiropoulo ! "[93-hamlin] exclaimed [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " [I]93-hamlin beg [your]93-hamlin pardon , [Miss Brown]91-anne , but do [you]93-hamlin feel inclined , after [your]93-hamlin long journey , to go and see [a fat , fashionable lion?huntress]2350-a fat , fashionable lion?huntress , with a snob of [a husband who sells currants]2351-a husband who sells currants ? "[93-hamlin] " Not at all , "[91-anne] answered [Anne]91-anne , laughing . " [I]91-anne would much rather stay at [home]1995-home , really . "[91-anne] " Very well ; then [I]1332-his aunt will show [you]93-hamlin [the garden]431-the garden and [[my]1332-his aunt studio]2354-my studio , if [you]93-hamlin don t mind ; and [a great friend of mine]2355-a great friend of mine , [Cosmo Chough]194-chough , [I]1332-his aunt think [I]1332-his aunt sent [you]93-hamlin some of [his]194-chough poems about music . . . . "[1332-his aunt] " Oh yes , "[91-anne] cried [Anne]91-anne ; " they are lovely "[91-anne] " [I]187-mrs macgregor think [little Chough]194-chough s poems perfectly indecent , "[187-mrs macgregor] interrupted [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor . " [I]187-mrs macgregor would much sooner let [a girl]1945-a girl read [Don Juan]210-don juan , or even [Candide]211-candide , any day . "[187-mrs macgregor]

[Hamlin]93-hamlin reddened , but laughed . " Opinions differ ; at any rate , [Miss Brown]91-anne knows only [Chough]194-chough s best things ; and when [he]194-chough is at [his]194-chough best , [Chough]194-chough is really very good and pure and elevated . "[93-hamlin] " Ah , well , "[187-mrs macgregor] merely remarked [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor . " [Cosmo Chough]194-chough said [he]194-chough would look in about four , "[93-hamlin] went on [Hamlin]93-hamlin . " [He]194-chough is [a strange creature]2357-a strange creature , and sometimes says odd things . "[93-hamlin] " Very odd things , "[1332-his aunt] put in [[his]93-hamlin aunt]1332-his aunt . " But [he]194-chough is as pure?minded [a man]248-a man as [I]93-hamlin know , and [a real poet]2359-a real poet , "[93-hamlin] went on [Hamlin]93-hamlin " indeed quite one of the best ; and [he]194-chough is [a great musician]2360-a great musician , and [a most entertaining fellow]2361-a most entertaining fellow [his]194-chough only weakness is that [he]194-chough is [a great republican and democrat]2362-a great republican and democrat , but would like to be thought [the son of]2363-the son of [a duke]2364-a duke . "[93-hamlin] " [The son of [a duke]2364-a duke]2365-the son of a duke ? "[91-anne] asked [Anne]91-anne , in surprise .

" Oh , [the natural son]2367-the natural son , of course forgive [me]187-mrs macgregor , [[my]187-mrs macgregor dear]2056-my dear , "[187-mrs macgregor] said [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor . " [People]322-people nowadays like anything illegitimate it s a[187-mrs macgregor]

distinction . It wasn t in [my]0-i day , but things have changed ; and [Mr Cosmo Chough]194-chough would dearly like to be thought [a bastard]1550-a bastard , especially [a duke]2364-a duke s. "[194-chough]

[Hamlin]93-hamlin smiled . " [Poor Chough]212-poor chough ! [Some one]1185-some one told [him]194-chough [he]194-chough was like [Richard Savage]213-richard savage one day , and that s [his]194-chough pose . Would [you]1557-her like to come into [the garden]431-the garden , [Miss Brown]91-anne ? "[93-hamlin]

[They]1552-they went together into [the strip of garden which lay behind [the house]254-the house]1553-the strip of garden which lay behind the house . There were not many flowers out as yet , only a few peonies and lilacs , and a belated tulip or hyacinth , but there was green , daisied grass , and big grey?mossed apple?trees still in blossom ; and across the low walls , covered with creepers , [you]1555-you saw big waving tree?branches , and [old brick houses]1556-old brick houses covered with ivy : the birds were singing , and some hens clucking next door . It was very quiet and old?world . [Hamlin]93-hamlin showed [her]1557-her all the rose?buds which might soon come out , and the place where the lilies would be , and the espaliers for the sweet?peas . Then

[they]1552-they went into [the two ground?floor rooms which [he]93-hamlin was arranging for [[his]93-hamlin studio]891-his studio]1558-the two ground?floor rooms which he was arranging for his studio : there were quantities of beautiful rare books and volumes of prints , and Persian and Japanese and old Italian metal?work , and pottery all about , and easels with unfinished pictures evcrywhere a great and beautiful confusion .

When [he]93-hamlin had showed [her]1557-her [his]93-hamlin properties , and [she]1557-her had reverently handled the things which had once belonged to [Shelley]183-shelley and [Keats]184-keats , and the bundles of unpublished manuscripts , entrusted to [Hamlin]93-hamlin by [living poets]1560-living poets , [they]1552-they sat down in [the studio]540-the studio and began to discuss various matters : [Anne]91-anne s school life , [her]91-anne readings and lessons , [Hamlin]93-hamlin s work , art , poetry , life , all sorts of things , a long and drowsy afternoon s talk , such as is possible only after a long correspondence between [people]322-people become familiar without much personal intercourse , who , knowing [each other]338-each other s mind , are now beginning to know [each other]338-each other s face and ways and heart ; and which has a charm quite peculiar to itself , like that of hearing

for the first time , with full symphony of voices and instruments , some piece of music which [we]1565-we have learned to know and love merely from the dry score .

[Anne]91-anne had never felt so happy in all [her]91-anne life , and [Hamlin]93-hamlin not often happier in [his]93-hamlin , as [they]1552-they sat in [the studio]540-the studio , talking over abstract questions , which seemed to acquire such a quite personal interest from those who were discussing [them]1552-they . [They]1552-they were thus engaged when [the servant]1525-the servant announced [Mr Cosmo Chough]194-chough . [Anne]91-anne s heart sank at the thought of confronting [one of [[Hamlin]93-hamlin s most intimate friends]1569-hamlin s most intimate friends]1568-one of hamlin s most intimate friends , and [one of [the poets who constituted the stars of [his]93-hamlin solar system]1571-the poets who constituted the stars of his solar system]1570-one of the poets who constituted the stars of his solar system . To [Anne]91-anne s surprise [Mr Chough]194-chough did not at all resemble either [Shelley]183-shelley or [Keats]184-keats , as [she]91-anne imagined ; [he]194-chough was [a little wiry man]1572-a little wiry man , with fiercely brushed coal?black hair and whiskers , dressed within an inch of [his]194-chough life , but in a style of fashionableness , booted and cravated , which was quite peculiar to [himself]194-chough .

" [Miss Brown]91-anne , "[93-hamlin] said [Hamlin]93-hamlin , " let [me]93-hamlin introduce [[my]93-hamlin old friend]2372-my old friend , [Cosmo Chough]194-chough . "[93-hamlin]

[Mr Chough]194-chough made a most fascinating bow , and swooped gracefully to the other end of [the studio]540-the studio to fetch [himself]194-chough a chair near [Anne]91-anne s. [He]194-chough was quite touchingly concerned in [Anne]91-anne s journey and [her]91-anne sensations after it ; and asked [her]91-anne whether [she]91-anne liked [London]3-london , with a sort of expansive chivalry of manner , as of [Sir Walter Raleigh]214-sir walter raleigh spreading embroidered cloaks across puddles for [Queen Elizabeth]215-queen elizabeth , which struck [her]91-anne as rather ridiculous , but very agreeable , as [she]91-anne had rather anticipated being scorned by [[Hamlin]93-hamlin s poetical friends]1574-hamlin s poetical friends . [Anne]91-anne thought [Mr. Chough]194-chough decidedly nice , with [his]194-chough oriental style of politeness , and magnificent volubility , constantly quoting poetry in various languages in a shrill and chirpy voice ; moreover , [he]194-chough seemed to adore [Hamlin]93-hamlin , and this was enough to put [him]194-chough in [her]91-anne good graces . [Mr Chough]194-chough rapidly informed [her]91-anne what [the principal poets in [London]3-london and [Paris]26-paris]1575-the principal poets in london and paris for [he]194-chough spoke of French things with an affectation

of throaty accent and allusions to [[his]194-chough " real country "[194-chough] which greatly puzzled [Anne]91-anne were writing]1576-his " real country " which greatly puzzled anne were writing ; and [Anne]91-anne felt so completely taken into confidence that [she]91-anne ventured to ask [him]194-chough whether [he]194-chough was [himself]194-chough writing anything at present , as [she]91-anne had greatly admired some short pieces of [his]194-chough which [Hamlin]93-hamlin had sent [her]91-anne .

[Mr Chough]194-chough was as modest as [he]194-chough was polite . [His]194-chough eyes shone , and [he]194-chough clasped [his]194-chough small hands in ecstasy at the idea of anything of [his]194-chough having pleased [Miss Brown]91-anne . [He]194-chough then proceeded to tell [her]91-anne that [he]194-chough had an idea for a long poem a sort of masque or mystery?play to be called the Triumph of Womanhood .

" [We]2373-we were trying over some of [Jomelli]216-jomelli s music a night or two ago , at [Isaac]78-isaac [the great composer]2374-the great composer s , "[194-chough] [he]194-chough explained ; " magnificent music , which [no one]1744-no one can sing nowadays , and [we]2373-we feebly crowed , when in the midst of the great burst of the "[194-chough] Gloria " [I]194-chough seemed to have revealed to [me]194-chough a vision of a mystic procession of [women]1795-women going in triumph ; [I]194-chough understood ,[194-chough]

in a sort of flash , the mysterious and real regalness of Womanhood . "[194-chough]

" It must have been very beautiful , "[91-anne] said [Anne]91-anne , naively . [Mr Chough]194-chough had opened the piano , and began playing , in a masterly way , a fragment of very intricate fugue . " Do [you]91-anne notice that ? "[194-chough] [he]194-chough asked : " that sudden modulation there ta ta ti , la la la from A minor to E major , that somehow mysteriously brought home to [me]194-chough one of the figures of that triumphal procession , and [her]91-anne [I]194-chough have tried to describe . If [you]91-anne like , [I]194-chough can repeat [you]91-anne the first few lines ; it is called [[Imperia]79-imperia of [Rome]32-rome]2377-imperia of rome . "[194-chough] " How good of [you]194-chough , "[91-anne] cried [Anne]91-anne . " [I]93-hamlin think [we]2378-we had better put off hearing it till [you]194-chough have composed rather more of the poem , "[93-hamlin] interrupted [Hamlin]93-hamlin . [Cosmo Chough]194-chough looked mortified , and [Anne]91-anne wondered why [Hamlin]93-hamlin should silence [[his]93-hamlin old friend]275-his old friend .

" Tell [me]91-anne all about [Imperia of [Rome]32-rome]2377-imperia of rome , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne

asked . " Who was [she]2377-imperia of rome ? had [she]2377-imperia of rome anything to do with [the Scipios]2380-the scipios , or [Cato]217-cato , or [Tarquin]218-tarquin ? "[91-anne]

" [Imperia]79-imperia was not [an ancient Roman]2381-an ancient roman , "[194-chough] explained [Chough]194-chough ; " [she]2377-imperia of rome lived at the beginning of the sixteenth century , and it is said that [all the cardinals and poets and artists of [Rome]32-rome]2382-all the cardinals and poets and artists of rome , nay , [the Pope]2383-the pope [himself]2383-the pope , accompanied [her]2377-imperia of rome coffin when [she]2377-imperia of rome died . "[194-chough] " Why , what had [she]2377-imperia of rome done ? was [she]2377-imperia of rome [a saint]688-a saint ? "[91-anne] " The inscription on [[her]2377-imperia of rome tomb]2385-her tomb is , [I]194-chough think , the most truly noble and Roman ever composed on [any woman]2237-any woman , "[194-chough] proceeded [Chough]194-chough ; " [Imperia]79-imperia . . . "[194-chough]

" [Miss Brown]91-anne doesn t understand Latin , Cosmo , "[93-hamlin] interrupted [Hamlin]93-hamlin , roughly , " and [I]93-hamlin am sure [she]91-anne would take no interest in [Imperia]79-imperia or [her]2377-imperia of rome epitaph . Supposing [you]91-anne let [Miss Brown]91-anne hear some of that beautiful Jomelli Mass [you]91-anne were speaking about . [Chough]194-chough is [one of the finest musicians [I]93-hamlin know]2387-one of the finest musicians i know , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin explained to [Anne]91-anne , " and [he]194-chough is quite famous[93-hamlin]

for singing all sorts of forgotten old Italian masters . "[93-hamlin]

[Chough]194-chough sat down and began to sing , in a warbling falsetto , but with the most marvellous old?world grace and finish . [Anne]91-anne did not attend . [She]91-anne was wondering about [Imperia of [Rome]32-rome]2377-imperia of rome . Why had [Hamlin]93-hamlin cut short [Chough]194-chough ? What had [Imperia]79-imperia done ? The remarks of [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor came to [her]91-anne mind ; and [she]91-anne felt indignant , and [her]91-anne indignation was all the greater , perhaps , because [Chough]194-chough s offence was vague and unknown how nobly and simply [Hamlin]93-hamlin had silenced [him]194-chough ! [She]91-anne wondered whether [he]93-hamlin was very angry with [Chough]194-chough , and whether [Chough]194-chough s feelings had been much hurt . [She]91-anne felt rather sorry for the sharp way in which [he]194-chough had been treated , and terrified lest [she]91-anne should be a source of misunderstanding between [Hamlin]93-hamlin and [[his]93-hamlin friends]658-his friends . [She]91-anne greatly praised [Chough]194-chough s singing .

" Will [you]194-chough sing ? "[1580-the little poet] cried [the little poet]1580-the little poet , supplicatingly ; " [you]194-chough must have a[1580-the little poet]

beauti ?

ful

beautiful

voice . [I]0-i know it from [your]194-chough way of speaking . "[194-chough]

[Anne]91-anne refused in terror . " Do sing , [Miss Brown]91-anne , "[93-hamlin] urged [Hamlin]93-hamlin . So [she]91-anne took [her]91-anne courage with both hands , as [she]91-anne expressed it , and sang an air by [Scarlatti]220-scarlatti , [Chough]194-chough accompanying . [She]91-anne made several false starts , and sang the wrong words almost throughout , for [she]91-anne felt a lump in [her]91-anne chest . [Anne]91-anne had a deep , powerful , rather guttural voice , not improved by singing modern German songs at [Coblenz]54-coblenz ; but the voice was fine , and [she]91-anne had caught something of the manner of [[her]91-anne former protectress]1581-her former protectress , [Miss Curzon]120-miss curzon , who had been a great singer in [her]91-anne day . [Chough]194-chough burst out into applause .

" A splendid voice ! "[194-chough] [he]194-chough cried ; " [you]91-anne must sing , [Miss Brown]91-anne [you]91-anne must study [I]194-chough will come and practise [your]91-anne accompaniments for [you]91-anne , if [you]91-anne will permit [me]194-chough . "[194-chough]

[Anne]91-anne looked at [Hamlin]93-hamlin ; such an offer , on so slight an acquaintance , surprised [her]91-anne .

" [You]91-anne will let [Chough]194-chough teach [you]91-anne , won t [you]91-anne ,[91-anne]

[Miss Brown]91-anne ? " asked [Hamlin]93-hamlin , approvingly . [He]194-chough afterwards told [her]91-anne that [Chough]194-chough spent whatever leisure remained from an inferior Government offce , in which , together with [a whole band of [other poets]2389-other poets]2388-a whole band of other poets , [he]194-chough was employed , in playing accompaniments for [various young ladies whom [he]194-chough considered , each singly , the most divine types of womanhood whom [he]194-chough had ever met]2390-various young ladies whom he considered , each singly , the most divine types of womanhood whom he had ever met .[91-anne]

[Chough]194-chough was in high spirits , and proceeded to display to [Anne]91-anne two or three relics which [he]194-chough carried on [his]194-chough person . [A fervent though not very orthodox Catholic]1582-a fervent though not very orthodox catholic , [he]194-chough was prone to religious mysticism : on [his]194-chough watch?chain hung a gold cross , containing a bit of wood from [[St Theresa]80-st theresa s house]1583-st theresa s house , which [a friend]1584-a friend had brought [him]194-chough from [Spain]81-spain ; by its side dangled a large locket , enclosing a wisp of yellow hair . " It is a lock of [Lucretia Borgia]221-lucretia borgia s , "[194-chough] [he]194-chough said , displaying it with as much unction as [he]194-chough had manifested for [St Theresa]80-st theresa " a bit of the one which [Byron]223-byron possessed , the most precious thing [I]194-chough have in all [the world]241-the world . "[194-chough]

" [She]2392-she was rather [an insignificant character though , on the whole]2393-an insignificant character though , on the whole , wasn t [she]2392-she ? "[91-anne] remarked [Anne]91-anne , not knowing what to say , " [a sort of characterless villain]2394-a sort of characterless villain , [the Germans]1208-the germans say . "[91-anne] [Cosmo Chough]194-chough was indignant . " Insignificant ! "[194-chough] [he]194-chough cried " a Borgia insignificant ! Why , [her]2392-she blood ran with evil as the Pactolus does with gold . [All women that have ever been , except [Sappho]224-sappho and [Vittoria Accoramboni]225-vittoria accoramboni]2396-all women that have ever been , except sappho and vittoria accoramboni , and perhaps [Faustina]226-faustina , were lifeless shadows by [her]2392-she side . . . "[91-anne] " [I]91-anne don t believe in [those sort of women]2397-those sort of women having been very remarkable , "[91-anne] said [Anne]91-anne , in [her]91-anne frank , stolid way , " except for disreputableness . "[91-anne] " But that is just it , that which [you]91-anne call disreputableness , [[my]194-chough dear]2056-my dear [Miss Brown]91-anne , "[194-chough] cried [Chough]194-chough , " therein is [their]2397-those sort of women greatness , in that fiery . . . "[194-chough] [Anne]91-anne shook [her]91-anne head contemptuously .

" [I]91-anne daresay [great women]2399-great women have often committed great crimes , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne said ; " but then [they]2399-great women have had great plans and ambitions ; [they]2399-great women[91-anne]

have not been [mere wretched slaves of passion]1585-mere wretched slaves of passion ; " and [she]91-anne relapsed into silence .[91-anne]

[She]91-anne had had what [Hamlin]93-hamlin used to call [her]91-anne Amazon or Valkyr expression as [she]91-anne spoke ; and [he]93-hamlin felt , as [he]93-hamlin had felt in [Florence]5-florence , the persuasion that [this proud and sombre woman]1586-this proud and sombre woman must have in [her]91-anne future some great decision , some great sacrifice of others or of [herself]91-anne . While [they]1587-they were talking , [the servant]1525-the servant entered to tell [Miss Brown]91-anne that [Mrs Argiropoulo]209-mrs argiropoulo was in [the drawing?room]1513-the drawing?room with [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor . " Confound [Mrs Argiropoulo]209-mrs argiropoulo ! "[93-hamlin] exclaimed [Hamlin]93-hamlin between [his]93-hamlin teeth , " to come intruding so soon . "[93-hamlin] " Is that [the lion?hunting lady]2400-the lion?hunting lady ? "[91-anne] asked [Anne]91-anne . " All [London]3-london has heard of [you]91-anne , [Miss Brown]91-anne , "[194-chough] exclaimed [Chough]194-chough enthusiastically , as [he]194-chough opened the door for [her]91-anne ; " at least all that deserves[194-chough]

to be called [London]3-london . [You]91-anne see [I]0-i have gained a march upon [her]209-mrs argiropoulo . "[0-i]

[Anne]91-anne did not answer , but [she]91-anne grew purple . So [every one]1592-every one was curious to see [this nursery?maid whom [the great Hamlin]93-hamlin had cast [his]93-hamlin eyes on]1593-this nursery?maid whom the great hamlin had cast his eyes on , and whom [he]93-hamlin had generously educated ; for the first time [her]91-anne heart burst with indignation and ruffled pride . But after a moment , as [she]91-anne sat in [the drawing?room]1513-the drawing?room , after frigidly returning [the fat and fashionable lion?huntress]1595-the fat and fashionable lion?huntress s affectionate greeting , [her]91-anne conscience smote [her]91-anne : who was [she]91-anne , that [she]91-anne should feel thus ? if [she]91-anne did depend entirely on [Hamlin]93-hamlin s generosity , ought [she]91-anne not to be grateful merely , and proud ? and if [[his]93-hamlin friends]658-his friends felt curious to see [her]91-anne , was it not natural , [he]93-hamlin being what [he]93-hamlin was ; and had [she]91-anne a right to feel annoyed at [their]658-his friends curiosity , at [their]658-his friends knowing all about [her]91-anne ? It had been mean and unworthy . Yet [she]91-anne could not help feeling a sort of vague anger

at [she]91-anne knew not what , as [the lady]1731-the lady chattered away , in glib Greek?English , about [poets]2340-poets , and [studios]1599-studios , and dinner?parties ; and [she]1731-the lady answered [Mrs Argiropoulo]209-mrs argiropoulo only in monosyllables .

"[187-mrs macgregor]

not at all so sure about [her]209-mrs argiropoulo . [She]209-mrs argiropoulo seems to [me]0-i too big and lumpish and healthy?looking . This was an old joke , for [Mr Cosmo Chough]194-chough always surrounded [[his]194-chough dwelling?place]1613-his dwelling?place with mystery , and had [his]194-chough letters addressed to [[his]194-chough office]1614-his office . CHAPTER IV .

[ANNE BROWN]91-anne found that [Hamlin]93-hamlin , or , as [he]93-hamlin studiously put it , [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor , had made several engagements for [her]91-anne before [her]91-anne arrival ; and before [she]91-anne could thoroughly realise that [the school]1115-the school , the journey from [Coblenz]54-coblenz , were things of the past , [she]91-anne found [herself]91-anne being led about , passively , half unconsciously , through the mazes of [? sthetic [London]3-london]1622-? sthetic london . It was all very hazy : [Anne]91-anne was informed that this and [that person]1623-that person was coming to dinner or lunch at [Hammersmith]36-hammersmith ; that this or [that person]1623-that person hoped [she]91-anne would come and dine or take tea somewhere or other ; that such or [such a lady]1625-such a lady was going to take [her]91-anne to see some one or other s studio , or to introduce [her]91-anne at [[some other person]1626-some other person s house]1627-some other person s house . [She]91-anne knew that [they]1628-they were all

either [distinguished poets]1629-distinguished poets , or [critics]1630-critics , or [painters]2339-painters , or [musicians]1632-musicians , or distinguished relations and [friends of the above]1633-friends of the above ; that [they]1628-they all received [her]91-anne as if [they]1628-they had heard of [her]91-anne from [their]1628-they earliest infancy ; that [they]1628-they pressed [her]91-anne to have tea , and strawberries , and claret?cup , and cakes , and asked [her]91-anne what [she]91-anne thought of this picture or that poem ; that [they]1628-they lived in [grim , smut?engrained houses in [Bloomsbury]86-bloomsbury]1634-grim , smut?engrained houses in bloomsbury , or [rose?grown cottages at [Hampstead]87-hampstead , with just the same sort of weird furniture , partly Japanese , partly [Queen Anne]230-queen anne]1635-rose?grown cottages at hampstead , with just the same sort of weird furniture , partly japanese , partly queen anne , partly medieval ; with blue?and?white china and embroidered chasubles stuck upon the walls if [they]1628-they were rich , and twopenny screens and ninepenny pots if [they]1628-they were poor , but with no further differences ; and , finally , that [they]1628-they were all intimately acquainted , and spoke of [each other]338-each other as being , or just having missed being , the most brilliant or promising specimens of whatever [they]1628-they happened to be .

At first [Anne]230-queen anne felt very shy and puzzled ; but after a few days the very vagueness which

[she]230-queen anne felt about [all these men]1637-all these men and [women]1795-women , [these artists]1639-these artists , [critics]1630-critics , [poets]2340-poets , and [relatives]1642-relatives , who were perpetually reappearing as on a merry?go?round , nay , the very cloudiness as to the identity of [these familiar faces]1643-these familiar faces the very confusion as to whether [they]1628-they were one , two , or [three different individuals]1644-three different individuals , produced in [Miss Brown]91-anne an indifference , an ease , almost a familiarity , like that which [we]1645-we may experience towards the vague , unindividual company met on [a steamer]1180-a steamer or at [a hotel]1647-a hotel .

And little by little , out of [this crowd of people who seemed to look , and to dress , and to talk very much alike]1648-this crowd of people who seemed to look , and to dress , and to talk very much alike , [venerable bearded men , who were [the heads of great schools of painting , or poetry , or criticism]1650-the heads of great schools of painting , or poetry , or criticism , or were [the papas of great offspring]1651-the papas of great offspring]1649-venerable bearded men , who were the heads of great schools of painting , or poetry , or criticism , or were the papas of great offspring ; [elderly , quaintly dressed ladies]1652-elderly , quaintly dressed ladies , who were [somebody s wife]1653-somebody s wife , or [mother]1541-mother , or [sister]1655-sister ; [youngish men , with manners at once exotically courteous , and curiously free and easy , in velveteen coats and mustard?coloured shooting?jackets or elegiac?looking dress?coats , all rising in poetry , or art , or

criticism]1656-youngish men , with manners at once exotically courteous , and curiously free and easy , in velveteen coats and mustard?coloured shooting?jackets or elegiac?looking dress?coats , all rising in poetry , or art , or criticism ; [young ladies , varying from sixteen to six?and?thirty , with hair cut like medieval pages]1657-young ladies , varying from sixteen to six?and?thirty , with hair cut like medieval pages , or tousled like m?nads , or tucked away under caps like [eighteenth?century housekeepers , habited in limp and stayless garments , picturesque and economical]1658-eighteenth?century housekeepers , habited in limp and stayless garments , picturesque and economical , with Japanese chintzes for brocade , and flannel instead of stamped velvets most of which [young ladies]1659-young ladies appeared at one period , past , present , or future , to own a connection with [the Slade school]1660-the slade school , and [all of whom , when not [poets]2340-poets or [painters]2339-painters [themselves]1664-themselves]1661-all of whom , when not poets or painters themselves , were the belongings of [some such]1665-some such , or madly in love with [the great sonneteer such a one]1666-the great sonneteer such a one , or [the great colourist such another]1667-the great colourist such another ; out of all this confusion there began gradually to detach [themselves]1664-themselves and assume consistency in [Anne]91-anne s mind one or two personalities , [some of whom attracted]1668-some of whom attracted , and some of whom repelled [her]91-anne , as [we]1669-we shall see further on ; but to [all these people]1670-all these people , vague or distinct , attractive or repulsive , [Miss Brown]91-anne felt a kind of gratitude something , in an infinitesimal degree , of the thankfulness for undeserved kindness and courtesy which

constituted a large part of [her]91-anne love for [Hamlin]93-hamlin .

It was a curious state of things , thus to be introduced by [a man whom [she]91-anne knew at once so much and so little , to [this exclusive and esoteric sort of people]1672-this exclusive and esoteric sort of people]1671-a man whom she knew at once so much and so little , to this exclusive and esoteric sort of people ; and whenever the thought would come upon [her]91-anne how completely and utterly [she]91-anne , [the daughter of [the dockyard workman of [Spezia]13-spezia]1674-the dockyard workman of spezia , [the former servant of [the little Perrys]113-the little perrys]1675-the former servant of the little perrys]1673-the daughter of the dockyard workman of spezia , the former servant of the little perrys , was foreign to all this , it made [her]91-anne feel alone and giddy , like [one standing on a rock]1676-one standing on a rock and watching [the waters below]1677-the waters below . Such was the condition of things when one morning , about three weeks after [Anne]91-anne s arrival , [Hamlin]93-hamlin put upon the luncheon?table a note addressed to [Miss Brown]91-anne . " It s an invitation to [Mrs Argiropoulo]209-mrs argiropoulo s big party on the twenty?seventh , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said ; " [you]91-anne must go , [Miss Brown]91-anne . [She]209-mrs argiropoulo s an awful being [herself]209-mrs argiropoulo ; but [you]91-anne ll see [all the most interesting people in [London]3-london]2437-all the most interesting people in london at [[her]209-mrs argiropoulo house]1863-her house . [Edith Spencer]231-edith spencer or [Miss Pringle]232-miss pringle can take [you]91-anne , if [Aunt Claudia]193-aunt claudia feel too tired . "[93-hamlin]

" [Aunt Claudia]193-aunt claudia always feels too tired , "[187-mrs macgregor] answered [Mrs Macgregor]187-mrs macgregor , in a bitter little tone . [Anne]91-anne could not quite understand [this amiable and cynical old lady , who was at once devotedly attached to [[her]1678-this amiable and cynical old lady , who was at once devotedly attached to her nephew , and perpetually railing at his friends nephew]1679-her nephew , and perpetually railing at [[his]1679-her nephew friends]658-his friends]1678-this amiable and cynical old lady , who was at once devotedly attached to her nephew , and perpetually railing at his friends . "[187-mrs macgregor]

[Anne]91-anne looked in amazement ; and [Hamlin]93-hamlin reddened . " [I]93-hamlin hope [you]93-hamlin will not deem it a liberty on [my]93-hamlin part , [Miss Brown]91-anne , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said ; " but as [I]93-hamlin knew that this invitation was coming , [I]93-hamlin ventured to make a sketch of the sort of dress which [I]93-hamlin think would become [you]93-hamlin , and to give it to [a woman who has made dresses from artists directions]2450-a woman who has made dresses from artists directions ; of course , if [you]93-hamlin don t think it pretty , [you]93-hamlin won t dream of putting it on . "[93-hamlin] [Miss Brown]91-anne scarcely knew what to say or feel : there was in [her]91-anne a moment s humiliation at being so completely [Hamlin]93-hamlin s property as to warrant this ; then [she]91-anne felt grateful and ashamed of [her]91-anne ingratitude . "[91-anne]

" Perhaps not , "[91-anne] answered [Anne]91-anne , thinking of

all the dresses for [Miss Curzon]120-miss curzon and the little Perrys which [she]91-anne had made in [her]91-anne day . " It was very good of [you]93-hamlin , [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin . "[91-anne]

" What [an idiot]2128-an idiot [I]187-mrs macgregor was to let the cat out of the bag ! " [I]187-mrs macgregor ve spoilt [your]93-hamlin pleasure in the frock ; and there s [Walter]93-hamlin sulking because [he]93-hamlin thinks [you]93-hamlin won t like it . "[187-mrs macgregor] " [I]91-anne am very ungrateful , "[91-anne] said [Anne]91-anne , sighing as [she]91-anne stooped over [her]91-anne book , and feeling all the same that [she]91-anne wished [Hamlin]93-hamlin would let [her]91-anne make up [her]91-anne dresses [herself]91-anne .

A few days later [the dressmaker]1687-the dressmaker came to try on the dress , or rather perhaps because [Hamlin]93-hamlin did not wish [Anne]91-anne to see it before it was finished its linings and a small amount of the Greek stuff of which it was made ; but it was not till the very afternoon of [Mrs Argiropoulo]209-mrs argiropoulo s party that the costume was brought [home]1995-home finished . [Miss Brown]91-anne was by this time tolerably accustomed to the eccentric garb of [? sthetic circles]1689-? sthetic circles , and [she]91-anne firmly believed that it was the only one which [a self?respecting

woman]1690-a self?respecting woman might wear ; but when [she]91-anne saw the dress which [Hamlin]93-hamlin had designed for [her]91-anne , [she]91-anne could not help shrinking back in dismay . It was of that Cretan silk , not much thicker than muslin , which is woven in minute wrinkles of palest yellowy white ; it was made , it seemed to [her]91-anne , more like a night?gown than anything else , shapeless and yet clinging with large and small folds , and creases like those of damp sculptor s drapery , or the garments of [[Mantegna]199-mantegna s women]1691-mantegna s women .

" [I]91-anne must get out a long petticoat , "[91-anne] said [Anne]91-anne , appalled . " Oh please , [ma am]2300-ma am , no , "[1687-the dressmaker] cried [the dressmaker]1687-the dressmaker . " On no account an additional petticoat it would ruin the whole effect . On the contrary , [you]91-anne ought to remove one of those [you]91-anne have on , because like this the dress can t cling properly . "[1687-the dressmaker] " [I]91-anne won t have it cling , "[91-anne] cried [Miss Brown]91-anne , resolutely . " [I]91-anne will let alone the extra petticoat , but that s as much as [I]91-anne will do . "[91-anne]

" As [you]91-anne please , [ma am]2300-ma am , "[1693-the woman] answered [the

woman]1693-the woman , and continued adjusting the limp garment with [the maid]1376-the maid s assistance .

[Anne]91-anne walked to the mirror . [She]91-anne was almost terrified at the figure which met [her]91-anne . [That colossal woman]1695-that colossal woman , with wrinkled drapery clinging to [her]1695-that colossal woman in half?antique , half?medieval guise , [that great solemn , theatrical creature]1696-that great solemn , theatrical creature , could that be [herself]1695-that colossal woman ? " [I]91-anne think , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne said in despair , " that there s something very odd about it , [Mrs Perkins]234-mrs perkins . It looks somehow all wrong . Are [you]1687-the dressmaker sure that something hasn t got unstitched ? "[91-anne] " No indeed , [madam]2186-madam , "[1687-the dressmaker] answered [the dressmaker]1687-the dressmaker , ruffled in [her]1687-the dressmaker dignity . " [I]91-anne have exactly followed the design ; and , "[91-anne] [she]91-anne added , with crushing effect , " as it s [I]91-anne who execute the most difficult designs for [the Lyceum]88-the lyceum , [I]91-anne think [I]91-anne may say that it could not be made differently . "[91-anne] [The Lyceum]88-the lyceum ! [Anne]91-anne felt half petrified . What ! [Hamlin]93-hamlin was having [her]91-anne rigged out by [a stage dressmaker]1698-a stage dressmaker !

. " [I]93-hamlin knew how such a dress must suit [you]91-anne , and yet it has given [me]93-hamlin quite a shock to see [you]91-anne in it . "[93-hamlin]

" Thank [you]91-anne , "[93-hamlin] [he]93-hamlin said ; " [I]93-hamlin must now go [home]1995-home and dress for that stupid dinner?party . "[93-hamlin] [He]93-hamlin looked at [her]91-anne with a kind of fervour , and left [the room]319-the room .

[Anne]91-anne sat down . Why did that dress make such a difference to [him]93-hamlin ? Why did [he]93-hamlin care so much more for [her]91-anne because [she]91-anne had it on ? Did [he]93-hamlin care for [her]91-anne only as a sort of live picture ? [she]91-anne thought bitterly . But , after all , it was quite natural on [his]93-hamlin part to be pleased , since [he]93-hamlin had invented the dress . And it was

very good of [him]93-hamlin to have thought of [her]91-anne at all . And thus , in a state of enjoyable repentance , [she]91-anne awaited the hour to go to [Mrs Argiropoulo]209-mrs argiropoulo .

[Mrs Spencer]233-mrs spencer , [a very lovable and laughable little woman , whose soul was divided between [her]233-mrs spencer babies and fierce rancours against [all enemies of pre?Raphaelitism]1704-all enemies of pre?raphaelitism , hereditary , in virtue of [[her]233-mrs spencer father]1966-her father , [Andrew Saunders]235-andrew saunders , in [[her]233-mrs spencer family]1747-her family]1703-a very lovable and laughable little woman , whose soul was divided between her babies and fierce rancours against all enemies of pre?raphaelitism , hereditary , in virtue of her father , andrew saunders , in her family , came punctually , marvellously attired in grey cashmere medieval garments , a garland of parsley and gilt oak?leaves in [her]233-mrs spencer handsome red hair . On seeing [Anne]91-anne , who stood awaiting [her]91-anne by the fireplace , [she]91-anne could not repress an exclamation of admiration . " Yes , "[91-anne] answered [Anne]91-anne , unaccustomed to have [her]91-anne looks admired at [Florence]5-florence and at [Coblenz]54-coblenz ; " it is a very wonderful costume , isn t it ? [Mr Hamlin]93-hamlin designed it for [me]91-anne . [I]91-anne think it was so kind of [him]93-hamlin ; don t [you]91-anne ? "[91-anne]
